为企业打造产品获赞

Praise for Building Products for the Enterprise

这是在企业软件领域实现产品与市场契合的罕见公司，并且有许多书籍介绍了这种神奇的客户发现过程。但到目前为止，还没有针对后续扩展阶段的指南。在企业软件中，最初的产品市场契合仅意味着用户、客户和潜在客户的需求不断增加。布莱尔和本在他们的书中阐述了产品管理的关键原则，使公司能够征服他们发现的软件市场，而不是迷失在他们自己创造的产品迷宫中。

Andrew Montalenti，Parse.ly 联合创始人兼首席技术官

It’s the rare company that achieves product-market fit in enterprise software, and many books have been written about that magical customer discovery process. But until now, there has been no guidebook for the scaling phase that follows. In enterprise software, initial product-market fit only means a growing pile of demands from users, customers, and prospects. In their book, Blair and Ben lay out the key principles of product management that allow companies to conquer the software markets they discover, rather than getting lost in a product maze of their own creation.

Andrew Montalenti, Cofounder and CTO of Parse.ly

伟大的产品经理是杂耍大师和茶叶阅读专家。本书是如何完善两者的指南。我向任何想要了解更多有关企业软件产品管理的人推荐它。

Joe Colopy，PeopleLove 首席执行官/联合创始人Bronto Software 首席执行官/联合创始人

Great product managers are master jugglers and expert tea leaf readers. This book is a guide in how to perfect both. I recommend it to anyone looking to learn more about product management for enterprise software.

Joe Colopy, CEO/Cofounder of PeopleLove CEO/Cofounder of Bronto Software

为企业构建产品是一本真正可以帮助您了解特定工作（产品管理工作）的稀有书籍之一。如果做得好，产品管理可以成为将整个组织凝聚在一起的粘合剂，也是最令人兴奋和最具创业精神的职业机会之一。如果您对该领域感兴趣并且想要掌握该领域，请阅读本书。

Brett A. Hurt，Bazaarvoice、Coremetrics、data.world和 Hurt Family Investments的创始人

Building Products for the Enterprise is one of those rare books that really helps you understand a particular job—that of product management. Product management can be the glue that holds the entire organization together when done well, and it is one of the most exciting and entrepreneurial career opportunities. Read this book if you are interested in—and want to master—the field.

Brett A. Hurt, founder of Bazaarvoice, Coremetrics, data.world, and Hurt Family Investments

有很多关于初创公司以及如何向公司引入产品管理的产品管理书籍。但是关于大型企业 SaaS 公司产品管理的书籍在哪里？当我遇到这个职位的准确比喻时，我被这本书迷住了：产品经理就像一只牧羊犬。这就是我们——产品经理，竭尽全力引导大众走上增长、颠覆和 SaaS 统治的道路。为企业构建产品对于产品经理来说是一个很好的“入门指南”，他们发现自己身处这些成长型企业，鼓励（并期望）产品管理真正成为业务驱动力。



Kathryn Murphy， Salesforce Commerce Cloud产品管理副总裁

There are a lot of product management books about startups and how to introduce product management to your company. But where are the books about product management at large enterprise SaaS companies? I was sold on this book when I encountered the accurate metaphor for the job: the Product Manager as a sheepdog. That’s who we are—Product Managers trying to steer the herd to the best of our ability on the path toward growth, disruption, and SaaS domination. Building Products for the Enterprise is an excellent “how-to” for Product Managers who have found themselves at these growing enterprises where product management is encouraged (and expected) to truly be a business driver.

Kathryn Murphy, Vice President of Product Management,

Salesforce Commerce Cloud

本和布莱尔将本书的部分收益捐赠给他们选择的以下慈善机构。我们鼓励所有读者了解并支持这些有价值的组织。

Ben and Blair are donating a portion of their proceeds from this book to the charities of their choice below. We encourage all of our readers to learn about and support these worthy organizations.

纽约市救援团是纽约最古老的无家可归者收容所。它的存在是为了给纽约市饥饿、无家可归和受伤的人们提供帮助和希望。请访问NYCRes​​cue.org了解更多信息。

The New York City Rescue Mission is New York’s oldest homeless shelter. It exists to provide help and hope to the hungry, homeless, and hurting men and women of New York City. Learn more at NYCRescue.org.

国际救援委员会是世界上最杰出的难民援助组织。IRC 帮助生活和生计因冲突和灾难而遭到破坏的人们生存、恢复并重新掌控自己的未来。请访问Rescue.org了解更多信息。

The International Rescue Committee is the world’s preeminent refugee aid organization. The IRC helps people whose lives and livelihoods are shattered by conflict and disaster to survive, recover, and regain control of their future. Learn more at Rescue.org.

为企业构建产品

Building Products for the Enterprise

企业软件中的产品管理

Product Management in Enterprise Software

布莱尔·里维斯和本杰明·盖恩斯

Blair Reeves and Benjamin Gaines

为企业构建产品

Building Products for the Enterprise

by Blair Reeves and Benjamin Gaines

[大规模集成电路]

[LSI]

前言

Foreword

产品管理火爆！为什么？原因有很多，其中最重要的是产品的重要性日益增强，我们现代竞争优势的许多来源都可以在让客户完全满意的产品中找到。但我也赞扬谷歌及其建立的非常成功的产品管理组织。也许无与伦比的是，谷歌雇佣并培训了一些邪恶的聪明人，他们开发了一些我们都知道和使用的最知名、最令人愉快的产品。许多人现在已成为首席执行官或风险投资家——我们当前技术生态系统中的权力掮客。围绕产品管理的大部分内容都是由这个神圣的社区驱动的。我很幸运能够与两个具有这种血统的人密切合作，并且遇到了更多这样的人，我有资格说他们是货真价实的。

Product management is hot! Why? A lot of reasons, not the least of which is the growing primacy of product, where many of our sources of modern competitive advantage are found in products that utterly delight customers. But I also credit Google and the wildly successful product management organization it has built. Perhaps without equal, Google has hired and trained wicked smart people who built some of the most recognizable and delightful products we all know and use. Many are now CEOs or venture capitalists—the power brokers in our current technology ecosystem. Much of the content around product management is driven by this hallowed community. I’m fortunate to work closely with two individuals with this pedigree and have encountered many more, and I’m qualified to say they are the real deal.

然而，他们的背景与我不同。谷歌是一家消费者至上的公司——至少在成立初期是这样。一些 Google 产品经理曾与销售人员进行过互动，但许多人还没有。我读到的许多理想主义对我来说都是鼓舞人心的，但它并没有反映我过去试图取得成功时所面临的现实。并非所有人都生活在一个可以在 Google 搜索中进行 A/B 测试并在一小时内获得数百万个数据点的世界。

Yet, their background is different than mine. Google is a consumer-first company—at least in its early days. Some Google product managers have interacted with sales, but many have not. Much of the idealism that I read about is inspiring to me, yet it doesn’t reflect the reality that I’ve faced trying to be successful in my past. Not all of us live in a world where we can A/B test something in Google search and get millions of datapoints in an hour.

现实情况是，企业或 B2B 产品管理本身就是野兽。这是一个重要的事情。企业产品管理正在推动我们的经济。我们正在设计人力资源部门、供应链、广告技术、数据中心以及所有主要基础设施的未来。

The reality is that enterprise or B2B product management is its own beast. And it’s an important one. Enterprise product management is driving our economy. We are designing the future of our human resources departments, our supply chain, advertising technology, data centers, and generally all major infrastructure.

读完这本书，我笑了。我笑了，因为这些故事和想法与我的经历如此密切地产生共鸣。这是一本为我而写的书。我是谁？自从 20 多年前开始我的职业生涯以来，我很高兴从事企业产品管理工作。我曾领导过产品团队，现在我是一家公司的首席执行官，该公司的客户（和用户）主要是产品团队。这些是我的人。如果您正在阅读本文，那么它们很可能也是您的。

As I read this book, I smiled. I smiled because the stories and ideas resonated so closely with my experience. This is a book written for me. Who am I? I’ve had the pleasure of being in enterprise product management since I began my career over 20 years ago. I’ve led product teams, and now I’m the CEO for a company whose customers (and users) are primarily product teams. These are my people. If you’re reading this, they’re likely yours, too.

但没有企业产品管理学位——至少我发现没有。我非常熟悉实用营销等计划以及其他经过良好培训的计划。但是，直到现在，我还没有找到能够完美体现企业产品管理工作的内容。

But there’s no degree in enterprise product management—at least no degree that I’ve found. I’m very familiar with programs like Pragmatic Marketing and others that have some good training. But, until now, I hadn’t found content that perfectly captured the job of enterprise product management.

如果您是企业产品经理，请享受这一点。这很可能成为我们的“圣经”。如果您不是企业产品经理，欢迎。我有偏见，但我觉得没有更好的角色了。对我来说，这是令人难以置信的回报，是实现任何和所有抱负（无论是专业还是其他方面）的令人惊叹的垫脚石。其他产品人员明白我的意思。

If you are an enterprise product manager, enjoy this. This may well become our “bible.” If you aren’t an enterprise product manager, welcome. I’m biased, but I feel there is no better role. For me, it has been incredibly rewarding, an amazing stepping stone for any and all ambitions, professionally and otherwise. Other product people understand what I mean.

享受！

Enjoy!

Todd Olson，Pendo.io 首席执行官，

北卡罗来纳州罗利

Todd Olson, CEO, Pendo.io,

Raleigh, North Carolina

前言

Preface

如果您不熟悉软件产品管理，或者只是想了解更多信息，您可能会自然地在网络上搜索该主题。不过，先煮点咖啡，因为你会得到很多东西。有些是好的，有些是好的。某种有趣但不完整的；坦率地说，其中很大一部分都是哗众取宠的噱头。（换句话说，这是科技行业主题的一个非常典型的细分。）多年来，本和我一直互相发送链接，指向我们偶然发现的糟糕或业余产品管理建议的特别令人震惊的例子。我们注意到的一件事是，即使是“好东西”通常也面向初创社区和消费科技世界，而这不是我们居住的地方。（从字面上看，我们都不住在硅谷。）因此，作为企业软件的产品经理，

If you’re new to software product management, or just looking to learn more about it, you might naturally do a search on the web on the topic. Brew some coffee first, though, because you’ll get a lot of stuff back. Some of it will be good; some kind of interesting but incomplete; and a large swath of it, frankly, will be clickbait claptrap. (In other words, a pretty typical breakdown on tech industry topics.) Over the years, Ben and I have taken to sending each other links to particularly egregious examples of bad or amateurish product management advice that we stumble across. One thing we’ve noticed is that even the “good stuff” is usually geared toward the startup community and consumer tech world, which isn’t where we live. (Literally—neither of us lives in Silicon Valley, either.) As a result, as product managers in enterprise software, we’ve mostly had to figure this stuff out for ourselves.

企业软件似乎常常生活在自己独立的宇宙中。这并不是科技媒体气喘吁吁地报道的泡沫状的、创业公司-风险投资-工业综合体旋风。这方面有一种说法，有时表明，主导企业市场的大公司又开始紧随其后，争先恐后地与那些正在吃午餐的、由风投资助的更灵活的初创公司竞争。事实上，有一个笑话说风险投资/创业文化喜欢抨击“大公司”。直到一家受青睐的初创公司想要进行收购。事实上，市场现实与叙述所暗示的完全不同。截至 2014 年，由 10 家公司组成的集团在企业软件领域创造了全球总收入的 45%。事实上，只有五家公司——微软、甲骨文、IBM、SAP 和赛门铁克——创造了其中 38% 的收入。同一榜单上只有两家公司是在过去 25 年中成立的，即 Salesforce（第 9 名）和 Google（第 20 名）。毫无疑问：整体企业软件业务非常健康且增长迅速，即使正在经历巨大的变化，例如适应云服务交付和基于订阅的定价模式。企业软件即服务 (SaaS) 的巨大发展成为当今企业软件事实上的默认模型，代表了这些趋势的顶峰。

Enterprise software often seems to live in its own separate universe. This isn’t the frothy, startup-VC-industrial complex whirlwind that’s covered breathlessly by the tech press. There’s a narrative on that side that sometimes suggests that the huge firms that dominate the enterprise market are back on their heels, scrambling to compete with nimbler VC-funded startups that are eating their lunch. Indeed, the joke goes that the VC/startup culture loves to bash “BigCos.” Until, that is, a favored startup wants an acquisition. Indeed, the market reality is something quite different than that narrative implies. As of 2014, a group of 10 companies generated 45% of all global revenue in the enterprise software segment. In fact, just five companies—Microsoft, Oracle, IBM, SAP, and Symantec—generated 38% of that revenue. Just two companies on that same list, Salesforce (#9) and Google (#20), have been founded in the past 25 years. Make no mistake: the overall enterprise software business is very healthy and growing fast, even while undergoing huge changes, like adapting to cloud service delivery and subscription-based pricing models. The enormous growth of enterprise Software as a Service (SaaS) into today’s de facto default model for enterprise software represents the culmination of these trends.

你们的作者 Ben（Adobe，榜单上排名第 11）和 Blair（SAS，排名第 13）在我们整个技术职业生涯中都站在了向企业 SaaS 世界转变的最前沿。我们生活的软件世界并不是我们在消费者方面经常看到的高速增长、繁荣与萧条的循环。这是一个缓慢增长的市场，一次又一次的谈判销售，重复的成功执行，展示的商业价值和组织协作，所有这些都随着时间的推移而持续。初创公司的相关性主要在于潜在的收购，而不是作为有意义的竞争对手。初创公司所称的“企业”层通常是我们的中小型细分市场，甚至是我们无法触及的账户规模。这并不是夸张，这只是我们在日常工作中面临的现实。

Your authors, Ben (Adobe, #11 on the list) and Blair (SAS, #13) have spent our entire tech careers at the forefront of that very shift to the world of enterprise SaaS. The software world we live in is not the hypergrowth, boom-and-bust cycle that we so often see on the consumer side. It’s a market of slow ramps, one negotiated sale after another, repeated successful execution, demonstrated business value and organizational collaboration, all sustained over time. Startups are relevant mainly as potential acquisitions, not so often as meaningful competitors. What the startups call their “enterprise” tier is frequently our small-to-mid-sized segment, or even too small an account size for us to touch. This isn’t hyperbole, it’s just the reality we face in our day-to-day jobs.

当今行业中关于产品管理的大部分流行智慧都源自 2000 年至 2008 年技术周期的经验教训，并重新应用于我们现在所处的下一个技术周期。在那个时代，谷歌和 Facebook 等“高速增长”的硅谷公司从初创公司转变为今天的巨头，由此产生的投资者和校友散居各地，传播了硅谷两家公司学到的产品经验教训。特别值得一提的是，谷歌的助理产品经理（“APM”）计划本身就定义了当今科技领域的许多传统产品智慧。当然，产品管理作为一项职能早在这一切之前就已经存在了（微软几十年来一直有类似的“项目经理”），

Much of the prevailing wisdom about product management in our industry today is derived from lessons learned from the 2000–2008 tech cycle, reapplied to the subsequent one that we’re in now. In that era, “hypergrowth” Silicon Valley firms like Google and then Facebook transformed from startups into the giants they are today, and the resulting diaspora of investors and alumni have evangelized the product lessons learned at both companies around the Valley. In particular, Google’s Associate Product Manager (“APM”) program alone is credited with defining much of today’s conventional product wisdom in tech. Product management as a function existed prior to all of this, of course (Microsoft has had its equivalent “program managers” for decades), but it took this cycle of the tech industry’s mega-growth for product managers to become a standard feature of software product development.

然而，我们谈论得越多，我们就越开始同意，我们在典型科技圈中读到的有关“PM”的内容与我们为企业构建软件产品的实际工作之间确实存在着越来越大的差距。经过检查，我们将其追溯到消费者软件和企业软件之间巨大的基本商业模式差异。谷歌、Facebook 和其他面向消费者的公司的产品领导者拥有丰富的智慧，但其中大部分根本不适用于我们的工作。我们在企业软件中面临的挑战非常独特，值得专门对待。这就是我们在本书中的目标。

Yet the more we talked about it, the more we began to agree that there was a real and growing gap between what we read about “PM” in the typical tech circles and what our jobs actually looked like building software products for businesses. Upon examination, we trace this back to the big fundamental business model differences between consumer and enterprise software. The leaders of product at Google, Facebook, and other consumer-facing companies have an awful lot of wisdom, but much of it simply isn’t applicable to what we do. The challenges we face in enterprise software are meaningfully unique, and deserve their own dedicated treatment. So that’s what we aim to do in this book.

你们的作者都是运营商。我们都是全职企业产品经理，而不是顾问、专业演讲者或“思想领袖”风险投资家。在日常工作中，我们研究如何为地球上一些最大、最有影响力的行业构建令人惊叹的云软件产品。我们的一些产品几乎肯定以某种方式影响了您的生活。我们都热爱自己的工作，并且觉得我们学到了一些其他企业产品经理以及那些对像我们这样的工作感到好奇的人可能能够使用的东西。因此，在一个反常温暖的冬夜，我们决定写一本书，以“内部人士”的视角来看待企业产品管理，然后……好吧，我们就到这里了。

Your authors are both operators. We are both full-time enterprise product managers—not consultants, professional speakers, or “thought leader” VCs. In our day jobs, we figure out how to build amazing cloud software products for some of the biggest and most impactful and influential industries on earth. Some of our products have almost certainly touched your life in some way. We both love our jobs, and feel like we’ve learned some stuff that other enterprise product managers, and those who are curious about a gig like ours, might be able to use. So, one unseasonably warm winter night over dinner, we decided that we’d write a book that gave our “insider’s” perspective on enterprise product management, and…well, here we are.

本书适合企业软件领域的产品经理，无论是那些现在正在从事工作的人，还是那些将来可能有兴趣进入企业产品管理的人。公平警告：我们没有所有的答案，我们也不会假装知道。这也是我们在本书中会再次讨论的主题，所以请牢记在心。科技行业是一个快速变化的行业，我们非常清楚，没有一种真正的产品管理方法。但我们学到了一些对我们有用的东西，也学到了一些绝对没有用的东西。我们将反驳一些关于“产品”的炒作和空洞的抽象概念，揭开一些您听说过的神话，并尝试提供一些实用、直接的指导，希望对您有所帮助。例如，我们将介绍：

This book is for product managers in enterprise software, both those doing the gig now or those who might be interested in getting into enterprise product management in the future. Fair warning: we do not have all the answers, and we don’t pretend to. That’s also a theme you’ll see us return to in this book, so take it to heart. The tech industry is a rapidly changing place, and we know all too well that there’s no one, true way to do product management. But we’ve learned some stuff that has worked for us, and we’ve learned some stuff that absolutely has not. We’re going to push back on some of the hype and airy abstractions of “product,” pop a few of the myths you’ve heard about, and try to give some practical, straightforward guidance that we hope will be helpful to you. We’re going to cover, for example, how we decide what products or features to build, how we build a roadmap, how we organize a product team, how we work with other key teams in our organizations, and much more.

我们将本书分为以下几章（有时是宽泛的章节）：

We’ve organized this book into the following, sometimes broad, chapters:

第 1 章，为什么企业中的产品管理有所不同
Chapter 1, Why Product Management in the Enterprise Is Different

促使我们写这本书的原因是我们注意到，讨论产品管理时所用的术语对我们这些从事企业软件工作的人来说并不真正适用。为公司而不是消费者构建软件会给我们的产品规划、设计、构建、管理、销售和分销方式带来巨大差异，所有这些都使得我们作为产品经理的工作与面向消费者的同事的工作有着显着的不同。

What prompted us to write this book was noticing that product management is often discussed in terms that don’t really work for those of us in enterprise software. Building software for companies rather than consumers introduces dramatic differences into how our products are planned, designed, built, managed, sold, and distributed, all of which makes our jobs as product managers meaningfully different than for our consumer-facing colleagues.

第 2 章，我们为谁而建？
Chapter 2, Who Are We Building For?

我们首先从根本上澄清用户问题与客户问题。这些是不同的人，掌握他们各自的需求是我们作为产品经理的通病。

We start with a fundamental clarification of user problems versus customer problems. These are different people, and grasping their respective needs is our currency as product managers.

第 3 章，产品经理需要寻求的三种知识
Chapter 3, Three Types of Knowledge for a Product Manager to Seek

我们知道，对企业产品经理的实践能力进行正确分类的最佳方法是组织知识、产品知识和行业知识。

The best way we know to categorize the right domains of practical competence for an enterprise product manager are as organizational, product, and industry knowledge.

第 4 章，组织知识
Chapter 4, Organizational Knowledge

企业产品经理应如何与其他内部团队（如开发、设计、营销、销售和高管）合作。

How enterprise product managers should aim to work with other internal teams, like development, design, marketing, sales, and executives.

第五章，产品知识
Chapter 5, Product Knowledge

企业产品经理应如何处理产品规划流程：产品生命周期、构建路线图、收集客户意见和衡量成功。

How enterprise product managers should approach their product planning process: the product life cycle, building the roadmap, gathering customer input, and measuring success.

第 6 章，利用数据构建更好的产品
Chapter 6, Building Better Products with Data

产品经理通常拥有无数有关其产品的数据源。如何筛选所有内容以确定哪些部分是可操作的以及以何种方式操作？

Product managers often have innumerable sources of data about their products. How to sift through it all to determine which parts are actionable, and in what way?

第七章行业知识
Chapter 7, Industry Knowledge

企业产品经理应该如何了解他们的市场或他们构建的所有内容的背景。从主要数据、第三方、您的同事以及最重要的是客户本身了解您的市场。

How enterprise product managers should understand their market or the context for everything they build. Learn about your market from primary data, third parties, your colleagues and, most of all, the customers themselves.

第 8 章，产品经理
Chapter 8, The Product Managers

如何进入产品管理、管理产品团队并确保您在该职位上不断成长。

How to get into product management, managing product teams, and making sure you continue to grow in the role.

此外，我们还非常荣幸地采访了多家公司的企业产品管理领域的几位杰出同行，了解他们对我们行业中构建软件产品所面临的挑战的看法。我们在每章末尾都包含了这些“PM 简介”。我们还没有完成！自出版以来，我们不断寻求领先企业产品经理的观点，并且我们将定期在我们的图书网站上发布新观点：BuildingForBusiness.com。

In addition, we’ve also enjoyed the great privilege of interviewing several of our outstanding peers in enterprise product management, across a range of companies, to get their perspectives on the challenges of building software products in our industry. We’ve included these “PM Profiles” at the end of each chapter. And we’re not finished! Since publication, we’ve continued to seek out perspectives from leading enterprise product managers, and we’ll be publishing new ones periodically at our book website: BuildingForBusiness.com.

我们也欣然承认（并在结论中重新审视这一点），公司制定有关产品战略、路线图和进入市场的决策的方式比我们在这些页面中全面涵盖的内容要复杂和多样化得多。当您阅读时，您可能会发现自己在想：“所有这些听起来都很棒，但在这里永远不会发生这种情况。” 这可能是真的。弄清楚如何将这些原则应用到当前的组织中可能是一个挑战，但我们已经看到许多产品经理开始到处实施这些想法，即使是在内部惯性很大的公司中也是如此。如果不出意外的话，我们希望我们已经为您提供了一种提问的方式：“我们为什么不这样做呢？” 并开始与您的同事和管理层进行诚实的对话，讨论如何提高您的产品重点。我们不做的一件事希望你读完这本书后，会因为我们所描述的内容与你认为你的团队目前所处的状况之间的鸿沟而感到沮丧。即使在您目前的情况下，我们也相信您可以为您的客户做出伟大的事情。所以，嘿，抬起头来！

We also readily admit (and revisit this in our conclusion) that the way companies make decisions about product strategy, roadmap, and go-to-market are much more complex and diverse than what we can comprehensively cover in these pages. As you read, you might find yourself thinking, “All of this sounds great, but it would never happen that way here.” That might be true. Figuring out how to adapt and work these principles into your current organization can be a challenge, but we’ve seen many product managers begin to implement these ideas, here and there, even in companies with heavy internal inertia. If nothing else, we hope we’ve given you a way to ask, “Why aren’t we doing it this way?” and begin an honest conversation with your peers and management about how you can improve your product focus. The one thing we do not want is for you to read this book and become discouraged by the chasm between what we describe and where you think your team currently is. Even in your current situation, we believe you can do great things for your customers. So, hey, keep your head up!

如果您不从事企业软件工作，我们认为您仍然可以从本书中学到一些有用的东西。消费者网络企业的运作方式通常与我们在企业中的运作方式非常不同，其方式对产品管理的完成方式产生重大影响。当然，这就是本书的起源。然而，清楚地认识到这些细分市场之间的差异可以帮助每个细分市场更好地了解自己。

If you don’t work in enterprise software, we think you’ll still be able to take something useful away from this book. Consumer web businesses often operate very differently than we do in enterprise, in ways that have big implications for how product management is done. That, of course, is the genesis of this book. Yet clearly recognizing the differences between these segments can help each better understand itself.

如果您从事企业市场工作，欢迎您。我们是同一个部落的一部分。我们了解您的目标，并且很可能与您分享这些目标。如果您看到我们在这里遗漏的内容，我们很乐意听取您的意见。正如我们所说，我们也在学习。

And if you do work in the enterprise market, welcome. We’re part of the same tribe. We understand your goals and, in all likelihood, share them. If you see stuff we’ve missed in here, we’d love to hear from you. Like we said, we’re still learning, too.

向前。

Onward.

奥莱利野生动物园

O’Reilly Safari

笔记

Safari（以前称为 Safari Books Online）是一个面向企业、政府、教育工作者和个人的会员制培训和参考平台。

Safari (formerly Safari Books Online) is a membership-based training and reference platform for enterprise, government, educators, and individuals.

会员可以访问来自 250 多家出版商的数千本书籍、培训视频、学习路径、交互式教程和精选播放列表，包括 O'Reilly Media、Harvard Business Review、Prentice Hall Professional、Addison-Wesley Professional、Microsoft Press、Sams、Que 、Peachpit Press、Adobe、Focal Press、Cisco Press、John Wiley & Sons、Syngress、Morgan Kaufmann、IBM Redbooks、Packt、Adobe Press、FT Press、Apress、Manning、New Riders、McGraw-Hill、Jones & Bartlett 和 Course技术等等。

Members have access to thousands of books, training videos, Learning Paths, interactive tutorials, and curated playlists from over 250 publishers, including O’Reilly Media, Harvard Business Review, Prentice Hall Professional, Addison-Wesley Professional, Microsoft Press, Sams, Que, Peachpit Press, Adobe, Focal Press, Cisco Press, John Wiley & Sons, Syngress, Morgan Kaufmann, IBM Redbooks, Packt, Adobe Press, FT Press, Apress, Manning, New Riders, McGraw-Hill, Jones & Bartlett, and Course Technology, among others.

欲了解更多信息，请访问http://oreilly.com/safari。

For more information, please visit http://oreilly.com/safari.

致谢

Acknowledgments

没有一个产品经理会独自完成这件事，即使“它”正在写一本书。我们感谢数十位使构建企业产品成为可能的支持和指导。首先，我们要感谢 O'Reilly 团队：Nikki McDonald、Angela Rufino、Nan Barber、Meg Foley 以及指导两位新手完成出版过程的其他所有人（成功，如果您正在阅读本文）。我们感谢我们出色的审阅团队，他们提供了无数的建议，使本文对您更有价值（并确保我们在如何构建出色的软件方面没有对您撒谎）；该团队包括产品资深人士 Matt LeMay、Ryan Harper、Sachin Agarwal、Kimen Warner 和 Jeremy Horn。我们很高兴也很感激托德·奥尔森为我们写了这本书的前言。《产品管理实践：21 世纪关键连接角色的现实指南》，也可从 O'Reilly Media 获取。

No product manager does it alone, even when “it” is writing a book. We are grateful for the support and guidance of dozens who made Building Products for the Enterprise possible. First, we’d like to thank the O’Reilly team: Nikki McDonald, Angela Rufino, Nan Barber, Meg Foley, and everyone else who guided two newbies through the publication process (successfully, if you are reading this). We are indebted to our outstanding review team, which offered countless suggestions to make this text more valuable to you (and also made sure we are not lying to you about how to build great software); this team included product veterans Matt LeMay, Ryan Harper, Sachin Agarwal, Kimen Warner, and Jeremy Horn. We were thrilled and appreciative to have Todd Olson write us the foreword that starts this book off right. This book would not have been possible without Matt LeMay providing general inspiration to us in his book, Product Management in Practice: A Real-World Guide to the Key Connective Role of the 21st Century, also available from O’Reilly Media.

布莱尔·里夫斯：我有机会与许多才华横溢、勤奋的人一起工作并向他们学习，没有他们的影响，这本书就不可能出版。第一个是最明显的：我要感谢 Ben，他除了是这次行动的大脑之外，还是一位出色的作家和产品经理，我从他身上学到了很多东西。我要感谢我的许多前任经理所提供的教训和经验，无论是简单的还是困难的，他们促成了本书的编写，尤其是克里斯·贝内代托、艾伦·邦斯、迈克·尼曼和芭芭拉·史迪威。我要感谢我的妻子劳拉（Laura）帮助我走上正轨，还要感谢我的狗艾比（Abby），感谢她可靠的眼神和忠实的鼓励。最后，我要感谢我们的女儿佩妮，她的预产期为我提供了完成这本书所需的严格期限。

Blair Reeves: I’ve had the opportunity to work with and learn from a great many brilliant and hard-working people, without whose influence this book would not have been possible. The first is the most obvious: I want to thank Ben, who, in addition to being the brains of this operation, is a terrific writer and product manager from whom I have learned a great deal. I’d like to thank many of my old managers for the lessons and experiences, both the easy and hard ones, that have led up to this book—in particular, Chris Benedetto, Alan Bunce, Mike Niemann and Barbara Stilwell. I wish to thank my wife, Laura, for her help keeping me on track, and my dog, Abby, for her reliable looks of faithful encouragement. Lastly, I want to thank our daughter, Penny, whose due date provided the hard deadline I needed to finish this book.

本·盖恩斯：整件事都是布莱尔的主意，没有他，这本书就不可能出现。他知识的深度和广度不断令我惊讶。还要感谢 Adob​​e 团队的成员，他们就本书中的特定主题提供了意见：Jordan Walker、Brandon George 和 Michael Malmgren。Adobe 产品团队的其他成员——太多的人无法一一列举——对本书大部分内容中长期积累的知识和经验做出了广泛的贡献，如果不感谢我的队友（现任和前任），我将一无是处。智慧和支持。我将特别提及那些在我从事产品管理期间直接管理过我的人，他们每一位都是杰出的老师和导师：JD Nyland、Bret Gundersen 和 Chris Wareham。最后但同样重要的是，感谢我的妻子托尼，感谢她不断的鼓励、耐心和爱；还有安娜、伊丽莎、卡尔文和贝卡，他们是我将成为的最伟大的创造物部分。

Ben Gaines: This whole thing was Blair’s idea, and without him there is no way this book would have happened. He constantly amazes me with the depth and breadth of his knowledge. Thanks also to members of the Adobe team who provided input on specific topics in the book: Jordan Walker, Brandon George, and Michael Malmgren. The rest of the Adobe product teams—far too many individuals to name—contributed extensively to the long-accrued knowledge and experience that went into much of this book, and I am nothing if not grateful for my teammates (current and former) for their wisdom and support. I’ll mention specifically those who have managed me directly during my time in product management, each of whom has been an outstanding teacher and mentor: J.D. Nyland, Bret Gundersen, and Chris Wareham. Last but certainly not least, thank you to my wife, Toni, for her constant encouragement, patience, and love; and to Anna, Eliza, Calvin, and Becca, who are the greatest creations I will ever be a part of.

第 1 章为什么企业中的产品管理有所不同

Chapter 1. Why Product Management in the Enterprise Is Different

即使您是一位经验丰富的产品经理，从商业模式到“客户”一词的含义，为公司构建产品与为消费者构建产品有很大不同。原因如下。

Even if you’re a seasoned product manager, from the business model to the meaning of the word “customer,” building products for companies is substantially different than building products for consumers. Here’s why.

产品很热。如果您关注科技行业，您就会知道我们在说什么。“产品经理”是新 MBA 毕业生最梦寐以求的职位之一。整个博客、时事通讯、会议、甚至训练营都在科技界涌现，以满足对该主题感兴趣的人们。尝试在您的 LinkedIn 个人资料中添加“产品经理”，并准备好看到您的招聘垃圾邮件稳步上升。事实上，有一个名为 Medium 的完整内容和社交网络，专门用于分享产品管理思想。

Product is hot. If you pay attention to the tech industry at all, you know what we’re talking about. “Product manager” is one of the most highly-coveted job titles for new MBA graduates. Entire blogs, newsletters, conferences, even boot camps have sprung up around the tech world catering to people interested in the topic. Try putting “product manager” in your LinkedIn profile, and get ready to see a steady uptick in your recruiter spam. There is, in fact, a whole content and social network called Medium dedicated solely to sharing product management thinkpieces.

然而，我们仍然很难向父母解释我们是做什么的。你经常看到的简洁的总结或简洁的陈词滥调（“产品经理就像一个迷你首席执行官！”）要么很愚蠢，要么充其量是非常不完整的。我们不是工程师。我们也不是营销人员。我们当然不是“产品的首席执行官”。但当有人对我们的产品、“它做得如何”、“它需要什么”或“[它/我们]下一步需要做什么”有疑问时，其他人都会向我们寻求帮助。我们最好对这些问题有一个好的答案，因为我们最终是唯一有责任知道这些问题的人。

Yet we still have difficulty explaining to our parents what we do for a living. Neat summaries or the kind of pithy clichés (“the product manager is like a mini CEO!”) you often see are either silly or, at best, very incomplete. We’re not engineers. Nor are we marketers. We’re certainly not “CEOs of the product.” But we’re the guys who everyone else looks to when there’s a question about our products, or “how it’s doing,” or “what it needs” or “what [it/we] need to do next.” And we better have a good answer for those questions, because we’re ultimately the only guys whose responsibility it is to know.

在成熟、高效的软件企业中，有很多团队致力于产品（或产品组）的不同方面：

In a mature, high-functioning software business, you have a lot of teams hustling around different aspects of a product (or group of products):

  • 显然有工程，它不仅构建他们被要求构建的东西，而且测试和修补它的稳定性、质量、缺陷等。

  • There is obviously engineering, which not only builds what they’re asked to build, but tests and patches it for stability, quality, defects, and more.

  • 在像我们这样的软件即服务 (SaaS) 企业中，有一个运营团队负责监控云平台和客户租户，并在发布时与工程人员（嗨，DevOps！）密切合作。

  • In Software as a Service (SaaS) businesses like ours, there’s an operations team that monitors the cloud platform and customer tenants and works closely with engineering (hi there, DevOps!) on releases.

  • 还有销售人员，他们是真正为您的业务注入活力的人。销售可以涵盖从首席开发代表或 LDR（有时称为客户开发经理或类似人员）到客户主管、客户成功经理、销售工程师（或解决方案顾问）的所有人，所有这些人都致力于获取、发展和保留商业。

  • There’s sales, the folks who actually breathe life into your business. Sales can encompass everyone from lead development reps, or LDRs (sometimes called account development managers or similar) to account executives, to customer success managers, to sales engineers (or solutions consultants), all of whom are dedicated to acquiring, growing, and keeping business.

  • 营销，其一系列专业功能令人眼花缭乱：数字、内容、需求生成、社交、活动、品牌、产品和解决方案等等。

  • Marketing, whose array of specialty functions can be dizzying: digital, content, demand generation, social, events, brand, product and solution, and more.

  • 有些“基础”服务，如财务、法律，甚至 IT，很容易被忽视，但对于一切正常运行来说绝对至关重要。除此之外还有很多。

  • There are “foundational” services like finance, legal, and even IT, that are easily overlooked but absolutely essential to making everything run. And there are plenty more besides.

所有这些团队（无论是上级还是下级，而是作为同行）的核心就是产品管理。“产品”引导定义产品愿景，制定实现目标的运营计划，然后执行它。它利用所有其他团队内置的激励措施，并使他们朝着同一个目标前进。这样，“PM”是一种运营角色，而不是真正的技术或专家角色。如果您允许我们用一个简洁的比喻的话，产品经理是一只牧羊犬；我们不一定决定目的地，尤其是在业务方面（执行团队经常这样做），但我们会以每个团队都能理解的方式制定一条到达目的地的路线，即“路线图”，如果你愿意的话。

Right at the nexus of all of these teams—neither above nor below, but working as a peer—is product management. “Product” leads in defining the product vision, establishing the operational plan to get there, and then executing on it. It harnesses the incentives built in to all of the other teams and aligns them toward a single destination. In this way, “PM” is an operational role, not really a technical or specialist one. If you’ll permit us just one pithy metaphor, the product manager is a sheepdog; we don’t necessarily dictate the destination, especially in business terms (an executive team often does that), but we generate a route to get there, a “roadmap,” if you will, in terms each team understands.

我们也不是任何人的老板。产品通常与其他团队合作，而不是超越他们。产品经理不是任何人的首席执行官，通常很少或没有正式的权力来告诉任何人该做什么。事实上，在大多数软件公司中，特别是在企业软件中，产品管理的核心功能之一就是与许多不同团队的跨职能协作，以确保团队作为一个整体朝着正确的方向前进。

We’re also no one’s boss. Product typically works with other teams, not over them. The product manager is no one’s CEO and usually works with little or no formal authority to tell anyone what to do. Indeed, in most software companies, and particularly in enterprise software, one of product management’s core functions is this cross-functional collaboration with many different teams to make sure that the team as a whole moves in the right direction.

在大多数高职能组织中，其他团队依靠产品来帮助他们更有效地完成工作。开发依靠产品管理来定义计划并编写用户故事、需求和验收标准来解释需要构建的内容。营销依赖于产品来获取产品信息、价值主张定义、商业案例材料、市场情报，有时还依赖于内容。销售在很大程度上依赖于产品，此外还确定目标细分市场、演示案例、回答详细询问并帮助完成交易。财务部门和产品部门相互依赖，通过确定定价、利润、折扣等来建立业务。领导力依赖于产品来执行整体产品和业务战略。在所有这些情况下，产品是关键指标，也是让所有产品朝着同一个目的地前进的原因。

In most high-functioning organizations, other teams rely on Product to help them do their jobs more effectively. Development relies on product management to define a plan and write user stories, requirements, and acceptance criteria that explain what needs to be built. Marketing relies on Product for product information, value proposition definitions, business case material, market intelligence and, sometimes, content. Sales relies on Product for much of the same, plus determining target market segments, demo cases, answering detailed inquiries, and helping to close deals. Finance and Product rely on each other to build the business through determining pricing, margins, discounting, and so forth. Leadership relies on Product for execution on overall product and business strategy. Across all of these cases, Product is the key index and what keeps all of them churning toward the same destination.

技术领域是如此广泛，特别是当您考虑消费者和企业细分市场时，我们怀疑将产品管理功能提炼为一个定义是否非常有用。没有两家公司会以完全相同的方式使用产品管理。也许成为“牧羊犬”并不能引起你的共鸣。如果没有，我们打赌这会：

The tech landscape is just so broad, especially when you consider both consumer and enterprise segments, that we doubt if it’s very useful to distill the product management function down into just one definition. No two companies will use the product management in exactly the same way. Perhaps being the “sheepdog” doesn’t resonate with you. If not, we bet this will:

我们的一位朋友马特·勒梅 (Matt LeMay)最近正在为 O'Reilly 教授一门关于产品管理的优秀课程。在其中，他给学生们进行了快速学习练习：他将他们分成小组，代表上述业务的不同部分。他给每个人一定的资源限制和解决产品困境的有限时间表。彼此交涉了一段时间后，他们又焦躁、困惑、还有点惊慌地回到他身边：“时间不够了！” 他们哭了。“我们无法在您要求的时间窗口内按顺序完成所有这些要求！我们先做什么？

A friend of ours, Matt LeMay,1 was recently teaching one of his excellent courses on product management for O’Reilly. In it, he gave his students a quick learning exercise: he separated them into teams, representing different parts of the aforementioned business. He gave each of them certain resource restraints and a finite timeline in which to solve a product quandary. After a period of negotiating with one another, they came back to him, harried, confused, and a little panicked: “There’s just not enough time!” they cried. “We can’t complete all of these requirements, in sequence, in the time window you’re asking for! What do we do first?”

当他向我们解释这个巧妙的练习后，我们笑了，因为我们都明白了这个笑话。“欢迎来到产品管理！”

After he explained this ingenious exercise to us, we laughed, because we all got the joke. “Welcome to product management!”

企业软件与众不同的三件事

Three Things that Make Enterprise Software Different

实际上，企业软件中的产品管理之所以与众不同，主要有三大要素：我们的业务模式、我们的专业化以及我们的客户和用户之间的划分。

There are really three big elements that make product management in enterprise software different: our business model, our specialization, and the split between our customers and users.

商业模式

The Business Model

在消费技术领域，有很多收入模式；广告支持显然很受欢迎，但也有双边市场、联属网络营销模式、直销（几乎总是自助服务）等等。在我们今天生活的赢者通吃的世界里，所有这些从根本上来说都是规模化企业。您拥有数百万（或数十或数百）的用户群，必须相应地做出产品、定价、基础设施和技术决策。

In consumer technology, there are lots of revenue models; advertising-supported is obviously very popular, but there are also two-sided marketplaces, affiliate models, direct sales (almost always self-service ones), and much more. In the winner-take-all world we live in today, all of these are fundamentally scale businesses. You have user bases in the millions (or tens, or hundreds thereof) and must make product, pricing, infrastructural, and technology decisions accordingly.

在企业市场，我们几乎完全采用直销模式运营，无论这意味着销售优质的老式许可证还是订阅（就像我们在 SaaS 中所做的那样）。企业很少是规模企业。尽管有一些有趣的例外，但我们主要依靠直接销售向相对较小的（与消费软件相比）复杂的客户群体销售复杂的产品和解决方案，并进行大额交易。这些交易经过数周、数月甚至数年的谈判、预算、实施和监控！销售周期长且复杂。（您可能已经看到了初创公司很难打入这个市场的一些明显原因。）

In the enterprise market, we operate almost exclusively on a direct-sales model, whether that means selling good old-fashioned licenses or subscriptions (as we do in SaaS). Enterprise is rarely a scale business. Though there are interesting exceptions, we mainly rely on direct sales to sell complicated products and solutions to a relatively small (compared to consumer software) group of sophisticated customers for large deal sizes. Those deals are negotiated, budgeted, implemented, and monitored for weeks, months, or even years! Sales cycles are long and complicated. (You can probably already see some obvious reasons why it can be very difficult for startups to crack this market.)

产品专业化

Product Specialization

企业软件通常也非常专业，并且是为满足特定的技术或业务需求而量身定制的。想想 CRM、业务分析或数据管理。这些解决方案领域很快就会变得非常复杂。作为产品经理，我们面临的挑战不仅是让这些工具通过新特性、功能、集成等随着时间的推移提供更多的业务价值；它还了解我们的用户如何工作，他们的工作和行业是什么样的，以及我们的产品如何融入他们的生活。当您的产品突破“单点解决方案”类别（即满足非常具体的、受限的业务需求）并发展到涵盖多个不同的用例、角色或行业之后，尤其如此。（我们稍后会在本书中讨论平台与产品。）

Enterprise software is usually also very specialized and tailored to serving a specific technical or business need. Think CRM, business analytics, or data management. These are solution areas that become very complicated, very quickly. Our challenge as product managers is not only to make these tools deliver more business value over time with new features, capabilities, integrations, and so forth; it’s also to understand how our users work, what their jobs and industries are like, and how our products fit into their lives. This is especially true after your product breaks out of the “point solution” category (i.e., meeting a very specific, constrained business need) and grows to encompass multiple different use cases, roles, or industries. (We talk about platforms versus products later on in the book.)

客户与用户

The Customer versus the User

让“企业 PM”变得棘手的最后一件大事是我们为谁而建。我们的用户可能将其职业生涯的大部分时间都花在我们产品的用户界面 (UI) 上，但他们几乎从来不是真正为此付费的人。我们的用户直接使用我们的产品来执行某些功能，使他们能够更好、更轻松或更高效地完成工作。相比之下，我们的客户几乎总是那些写支票的用户的老板（或他们的老板，甚至他们老板的老板）。

The last big thing that makes “enterprise PM” tricky is who we’re building for. Our users, who might spend a substantial chunk of their professional lives working in our product’s user interface (UI), are almost never the same people who actually pay us for it. Our users work directly with our product to perform some function that allows them to do their jobs better, more easily, or efficiently. Our customers, by contrast, are nearly always those users’ bosses (or their bosses, or even their bosses’ bosses) who write the check.

当你销售一款标价为五位数、六位数甚至七位数的产品时，往往是一位高管（通常是 C 级高管）拥有足够的预算来扣动扳机。这些类型的客户与他们的直接下属（我们的用户）有一套非常不同的选择标准，他们实际上会日复一日地使用我们的产品。一般来说，他们往往更关心实际的业务成果和投资回报 (ROI)，而不是精心设计的 UI 和功能清单。根据我们的经验，他们可能会接触相关产品，但他们不会日复一日地生活在其中。

When you’re selling a product that has a five-, six-, or even seven-figure price tag, it’s going to be an executive, not infrequently a C-level one, who has the budget juice to pull the trigger. These types of customers have a very different set of selection criteria than their direct reports, our users, who will actually be using our product day in and day out. Broadly speaking, they tend to care more about hard business results and return on investment (ROI) than a high-design UI and feature checklists. In our experience, they might touch the product in question, but they do not live in it day in and day out.

在某些情况下，您的用户可能会对您的执行客户产生强大的影响。管理人员可能会根据其部门的意见选出一组潜在的解决方案供应商，或者通常他们可能以前使用过首选供应商的产品。对于相关产品高度复杂且需要专门培训或经验的场景，这种情况更有可能发生。或者，在很多情况下，高级客户根据基本功能和价格做出选择，很少或根本不考虑用户输入（例如呼叫中心或大型零售销售点软件）。

In some cases, your users might exert a strong influence on your executive customers. Executives might short-list a set of potential solution vendors with their department’s input, or, often, they might have used a preferred vendor’s product before. For scenarios in which the products in question are highly sophisticated and require specialized training or experience, this is more likely the case. Alternatively, there are lots of cases in which executive customers make their choices based on basic functionality and price, with little or no regard for user input (think call center or large retail point-of-sale software).

非常清楚地了解您的用户和客户以及这两者如何相互作用和相互影响对于企业项目管理的成功至关重要。

Very clearly understanding your user and your customer and how those two interact and influence each other is absolutely vital to being successful as an enterprise project management.

您应该关注更强大或更灵活的用户功能吗？超时尚的用户界面？扩展的移动支持和出色的通知？或者您的目标是额外的集成和相邻功能，以提供“足够好”的功能，以允许您的客户终止与竞争对手的合同？您可以花时间处理的项目可能有无数个，但是选择这两个利益相关者中的哪一个进行过度服务以及如何过度服务将取决于您（产品经理）是否了解哪个项目最能推动您的产品成功。

Should you focus on more powerful or flexible user features? An ultra-sleek UI? Expanded mobile support and great notifications? Or do you target additional integrations and adjacent capabilities that can provide “good enough” functionality to allow your customer to end their contract with a competitor? There is probably an infinite list of projects you could spend time on, but choosing which of these two stakeholders to over-serve, and how, will depend on you, the product manager, understanding which is going to best drive your product’s success.

您首先向用户销售还是向客户销售？

Are You Selling to Users First, or Customers?

有些公司故意制定策略来征服其市场的整个用户群社区，作为进入各种规模企业的后门。像这样的“心灵和思想”路线是一种高接触性且通常是高投资的策略，要求产品专注于用户体验（UX）、出色的设计、清晰的功能、充足的文档、简单的入门，以及通常非常好的产品。大量的营销支出。通过向主题专家 (SME) 和爱好者宣传该产品，使其成为大众的最爱，他们实际上是在依靠这些社区来间接向他们工作的大公司施加压力，要求他们“与时俱进”。

There are some companies that make a deliberate strategy of conquering their market’s total user base community as a backdoor into enterprises of all sizes. A “hearts and minds” route like this is a high-touch and often high-investment strategy requiring a product focus on the user experience (UX), great design, clear features, ample documentation, simple onboarding, and, often, a very heavy marketing spend. By evangelizing the product among subject matter experts (SMEs) and enthusiasts to make it a popular favorite, they’re really relying on these communities to indirectly pressure the big companies they work for to “get with the times.”

相比之下，其他公司则以拥有与高管层的直接联系而闻名。他们依靠品牌和解决方案级营销、长期合作关系、以高管为中心的“思想领导力”以及纯粹的销售头脑来获取最高管理层的业务。（这些人的广告遍布每个主要机场。）

By contrast, other companies are renowned for having a direct line to the executive suite. They rely on brand and solution-level marketing, long-term relationships, executive-focused “thought leadership,” and sheer sales savvy to capture business at the C-suite level. (These are the guys whose ads blanket every major airport.)

这些策略很少被明确阐述，但通常很明显您的公司正在采取哪一种策略。它们都是经过验证的、成功的赢得市场的方法。每一个都有一组完全不同的产品含义，企业项目经理应该清楚地理解这些含义。

These strategies are rarely clearly articulated as such, but it’s usually pretty obvious which one your company is taking. They are both proven, successful methods for winning a market. Each one has a quite different set of product implications that enterprise project managers should clearly understand.

明确区分我们的用户和客户，揭示了产品解决的问题的微妙之处，从而揭示了它提供的价值。我们的产品主要解决谁的问题？我们的用户还是客户？实现该价值的适当平衡将取决于您对市场和产品策略的解读。开始该过程的一种方法是优先考虑我们希望产品解决的问题。因此，准备好在下一章中深入讨论您真正要解决的是谁的问题。

Clearly differentiating between our users versus customers reveals a layer of subtlety to the problems the product solves, and therefore the value it offers. Whose problems does our product chiefly address? Our users or customers? Striking the right balance of that value will depend on your reading of your market and product strategy. One way to begin that process is to prioritize the problems we want the product to address. So, get ready for a deep-dive in the next chapter into a discussion of whose problems you’re really solving.

概括

Summary

企业软件的产品管理与消费市场的产品管理截然不同。我们不仅必须区分企业产品的用户和客户以及必须满足各方的需求，而且我们的产品进入市场的路线以及客户​​计划和购买的方式与消费软件完全不同。此外，企业软件通常采用与面向消费者的企业完全不同的商业模式。所有这些差异都会对企业产品的规划、构建、销售、分销和服务方式产生重大的上游影响。

Product management for enterprise software is crucially different than for the consumer market. Not only must we differentiate between our enterprise product’s user and customer and the needs for each party that must be met, but our product’s route to market and the way customers plan for and buy it are completely different from consumer software. Moreover, enterprise software typically operates with a completely different business model than consumer-facing businesses. All of these differences have significant upstream consequences for how enterprise products need to be planned, built, sold, distributed, and serviced.

项目经理简介

姓名：迈克·尼曼

Name: Mike Niemann

职位： DynamicAction 产品管理总监

Title: Director of Product Management, DynamicAction

您是如何开始产品管理的？

How did you get started in product management?

当我的一位教授兼导师离开初创公司 [Trajecta, Inc.] 时，他在德克萨斯大学获得 MBA 学位时向我介绍了这家公司，我认为这对我们刚刚起步的业务来说是一个巨大的打击，但它最终启动了我现在的业务在软件产品管理领域拥有 20 多年的职业生涯。鉴于我是 Trajecta 的第一位带薪员工并为业务的各个方面（销售、营销、客户支持、IT 等）提供支持，我对如何在多种其他产品中利用我们的核心软件有深入的了解。因此，我介入管理已外包给第三方的软件需求定义和开发工作。

When a professor and mentor of mine left the startup [Trajecta, Inc.] he introduced me to while earning my MBA at the University of Texas, I thought it would be a huge blow to our fledgling business, but it wound up launching my now 20-plus-year career in software product management. Given the fact that I was Trajecta’s first paid employee and supported all aspects of the business (sales, marketing, customer support, IT, etc.), I had a strong understanding of how our core software could be leveraged in multiple other offerings. Accordingly, I stepped in to manage the software requirements definition and development efforts that had been contracted out to a third party.

作为一名经理，您工作中最难学习的部分是什么？

As a manager, what have been the most difficult parts of your job to learn?

我坚信，杰出的产品经理，即使是高管级别的产品经理，也必须保留作为个人贡献者的某些方面。当然，产品副总裁必须具有战略远见，但如果您过去曾是一名成功的产品经理，那么对了解市场、最终用户以及阐明您的产品所提供的价值的热爱就永远不会消失。当我从个人贡献者角色晋升为负责专业产品经理团队时，知道何时简单地放手并让团队中的人才执行我们的愿景是一项挑战。从小型创业环境转到 IBM 的大型企业，我在这一领域取得的巨大进步可能更多是出于需要，而不是真正的愿望。然而，我可以肯定地说，这段经历让我成为了更好的员工管理者。

I truly believe that exceptional product managers, even at the executive level, must also retain some aspects of being individual contributors. Of course, the VP of Product must be the strategic visionary, but if you’ve been a successful product manager in the past, that love for understanding your market, your end users, and articulating the value your offering provides never leaves. As I’ve ascended from individual contributor roles to being responsible for a team of professional PMs, knowing when to simply let go and allow the talent on my team to execute our vision was challenging. Moving from the small startup environment to a large enterprise at IBM, I made great strides in this area probably more out of necessity rather than true desire. However, I can definitively say the experience made me a better manager of people.

您认为有哪些特定背景对企业产品经理特别有价值吗？

Are there particular backgrounds you think are especially valuable for enterprise product managers?

经验告诉我，除了任何一门学科的背景之外，成功的产品经理首先必须具备卓越的人际交往能力。产品管理需要能够与具有广泛性格和工作方式的人员进行沟通和领导。产品经理必须领导不同职能领域的许多人，但对这些资源没有任何直接权力。您不必是[计算机科学]专业人士才能有效地与开发人员合作并让他们接受产品愿景，但您确实需要培养足够深度的技术理解才能赢得他们的尊重。此外，产品经理不需要成为成功的终结者，但他们必须拥有销售专业人员所需的自信和镇定。成功的产品经理不需要了解在 10 个不同的 Web 平台上部署 JavaScript 函数的所有技术细节，但她最好了解数据获取如何影响分析产品保真度的基础知识。我聘请了来自公司内部开发、实施工程、营销和其他职位的初级产品经理。我寻找拥有丰富产品知识、了解我们的市场、是吞吐量机器的人，而且最重要的是，受到同行的尊重。通过具备这些品质，我可以确信个人拥有在产品管理职位上取得成功的工具，无论他们在任何特定学科的专业知识如何。但她最好了解数据采集如何影响分析产品保真度的基础知识。我聘请了来自公司内部开发、实施工程、营销和其他职位的初级产品经理。我寻找拥有丰富产品知识、了解我们的市场、是吞吐量机器的人，而且最重要的是，受到同行的尊重。通过具备这些品质，我可以确信个人拥有在产品管理职位上取得成功的工具，无论他们在任何特定学科的专业知识如何。但她最好了解数据采集如何影响分析产品保真度的基础知识。我聘请了来自公司内部开发、实施工程、营销和其他职位的初级产品经理。我寻找拥有丰富产品知识、了解我们的市场、是吞吐量机器的人，而且最重要的是，受到同行的尊重。通过具备这些品质，我可以确信个人拥有在产品管理职位上取得成功的工具，无论他们在任何特定学科的专业知识如何。了解我们的市场，是吞吐量机器，而且最重要的是，受到同行的尊重。通过具备这些品质，我可以确信个人拥有在产品管理职位上取得成功的工具，无论他们在任何特定学科的专业知识如何。了解我们的市场，是吞吐量机器，而且最重要的是，受到同行的尊重。通过具备这些品质，我可以确信个人拥有在产品管理职位上取得成功的工具，无论他们在任何特定学科的专业知识如何。

More than a background in any one discipline, experience has shown me that, first and foremost, successful product managers must have exceptional interpersonal skills. Product management requires the ability to communicate and lead persons with a very wide array of personalities and ways of working. Product managers must lead many people across different functional areas but without any direct authority over those resources. You don’t have to be a [computer science] major to effectively work with developers and get them to buy into the product vision, but you do need to develop a sufficient depth of technical understanding to earn their respect. Furthermore, product managers don’t need to be successful closers, but they must possess the confidence and poise required of sales professionals. A successful product manager doesn’t need to understand all the technical details of deploying JavaScript functions on 10 different web platforms, but she had better know the fundamentals of how data acquisition affects the fidelity of an analytics product. I’ve hired entry-level PMs who’ve come from development, implementation engineering, marketing, and other roles within the company. I look for individuals that possess strong product knowledge, understand our market, are throughput machines, and, most important, are well respected by their peers. By possessing those qualities, I can be confident the individual has the tools to succeed in a product management role irrespective of their expertise in any given discipline.

如果你不从事产品管理，你会在技术领域做什么？

What would you do in tech if you weren’t in product management?

这是一个很好的问题，从我的角度来看，这有点棘手，因为我最喜欢的产品管理方面是“身兼多职”的要求和机会。我今天是一名营销人员，明天是一名技术作家，作为产品专家支持销售，担任产品布道者/梦想家，甚至帮助进行质量检查。当我能为他人的成功做出贡献时，我往往会感到非常满足。从这个角度来看，我可能会倾向于从事营销工作。如果没有营销人才来帮助建立销售渠道、阐明公司的战略愿景、传达战术产品价值主张、计划活动、促进客户成功故事等，开发可以构建世界上最好的产品，但可能不会成功。

That is a great question and from my perspective somewhat of a trick question as the aspect of product management I love the most is the requirement and opportunity to “wear many hats.” I’ve been a marketer one day, a technical writer the next, supporting sales as a product expert, serving as the product evangelist/visionary, and even helping with QA. I tend to get great satisfaction when I can contribute to the success of others. From that perspective, I’d likely gravitate toward a role in marketing. Without marketing talent to help build a sales pipeline, articulate the company’s strategic vision, convey tactical offering value propositions, plan events, facilitate customer success stories, etc., development could build the best product in the world, but it might not succeed.

1《产品管理实践》一书的作者，可从 O'Reilly 获取：http://oreil.ly/2nQi0zI。

1 Author of Product Management in Practice, available from O’Reilly at http://oreil.ly/2nQi0zI.

第 2 章我们为谁而建？

Chapter 2. Who Are We Building For?

产品管理始终是为了解决客户问题。如何在企业软件中选择和解决这些问题可能比在消费软件中复杂得多，需要以新的方式思考客户，以及内部团队之间更好的协调。但这并不需要让你放慢速度。

Product management is always about solving customer problems. How those problems are selected and solved in enterprise software can be significantly more complex than in consumer software, requiring new ways of thinking about the customer, and better alignment between internal teams. But this doesn’t need to slow you down.

吸引许多聪明、创新的人才参与产品管理的众多因素之一就是创造的诱惑。创造、发明中充满乐趣。在我们职业生涯的早期，我们都记得对产品经理充满敬畏，我们认为他们拥有决定企业下一步将创建哪些功能和产品的唯一权力。至少从技术角度来看，他们正在决定如何塑造公司的未来，我们都希望成为其中的一部分。事实上，本章都是关于运输产品的；决定要构建什么以及为什么的过程；由您的开发、产品营销和其他团队“资助”；确保您的设计和开发团队了解它如何与您的产品愿景联系起来，因为这就是您实现创造乐趣的方式。

One of the many things that draws a lot of smart, innovative people to product management is the allure of creation. There is joy in creation, in invention. Earlier in our careers, both of us remember looking in awe at the product managers, who, we assumed, had the sole power to decide what features and products the business would create next. At least from a technology perspective, they were deciding how the future of the company would be shaped, and we both wanted to be a part of that. Indeed, this chapter is all about shipping product; the process of deciding what you are going to build, and why; getting it “funded” by your development, product marketing, and other teams; and making sure that your design and development teams understand how it connects to your vision for the product, because that is how you realize the joy of creation.

一切都始于谁和为什么

It All Begins with Who and Why

我们现在知道，“交付产品”只是企业产品经理职责的一部分，它是产品开发漫长过程的最后阶段，首先要清楚地了解我们的产品是为谁服务的，以及为什么它会增加价值。这些都不是简单的问题，因此，他们的答案也很少是简单的。

We now know that “shipping product” is only a part of an enterprise product manager’s mandate, and it comes toward the end of a long process of product development that starts with a clear understanding of who our product is for and why it adds value. These are not simple questions, and, accordingly, their answers are rarely simple, either.

很少有人，包括我们自己，在进入产品管理领域时，对公司应该如何决定创造什么有现实的认识。年轻的产品经理发现自己被噪音淹没，解析其中的信号需要练习。让我们来计算一下对他们时间的一些要求：

Few people, ourselves included, come into product management with a realistic sense of how the company should decide what to create. Young product managers find themselves inundated with noise, and parsing the signal therein takes practice. Let’s count just a few of the demands on their time:

  • 最终用户的功能请求通常是矛盾的

  • Feature requests from end users, which are often contradictory

  • 销售的要求（“除非你建造这个，否则我们将失去这笔交易！”）

  • Demands from sales (“We’ll lose this deal unless you build this!”)

  • 分析市场趋势和驱动因素

  • Analyzing market trends and drivers

  • 买家/用户角色研究

  • Buyer/user persona research

  • 开发团队的请求或建议，例如清除技术债务、研究新项目或方法、“科学项目”等

  • Requests or advice from the development team, such as clearing technical debt, researching new projects or approaches, “science projects,” and so on

  • 持续的赢/输分析

  • Ongoing win/loss analysis

  • 合作伙伴关系和整合查询

  • Partnerships and integration inquiries

  • 跟上源源不断的行业媒体和分析师对您的市场的报道，其中包括竞争情报

  • Keeping up with the never-ending amount of industry press and analyst coverage of your market, which includes competitive intelligence

这只是部分列表。你应该把注意力集中在哪里？您如何知道每个领域中的哪些主题对您来说最重要？在正常的一天，您的收件箱和日历可能充满机会听到某人认为对您的业务增长至关重要的事情。然而，正如温斯顿·丘吉尔曾经说：“如果你停下来，向每只吠叫的狗扔石头，你永远不会到达目的地。”

This is only a partial list. Where should you focus? How do you know which topics in each of these areas should be most important to you? On a normal day, your inbox and calendar are likely to be full of opportunities to hear something that someone believes is critical to the growth of your business. Yet, as Winston Churchill once said, “You will never reach your destination if you stop and throw stones at every dog that barks.”

应用于产品管理时，这里的指导原则看似简单：弄清楚你正在为谁构建以及为什么。如果您的策略是合理的，那么每次客户或销售代表提出需求时都不要偏离它。这就是你如何发展短期产品视角，这显然不会产生重新定义行业的创新。

Applied to product management, the guiding principle here is deceptively simple: figure out who you’re building for, and why. If your strategy is sound, don’t deviate from it every time a customer or sales rep makes a demand. That’s how you develop a short-term product perspective, which obviously doesn’t produce the kind of innovation that redefines industries.

如果我们必须将产品管理归结为两件事，那就是：通过深入了解客户问题来弄清楚你正在为谁构建产品，并通过推动团队之间的协调来找出如何构建产品。

If we had to boil down product management into two things, it would be these: figure out who you are building for by deeply understanding customer problems, and figure out how to build by driving alignment across teams.

客户问题与用户问题

Customer Problems Versus User Problems

您可能会认为“我们为谁构建”是产品管理领域最简单的问题。我们为那些要求我们构建他们想要购买的软件的人而构建，对吗？您专注于一堆角色- 虚构的结构，充当具有给定角色或职责的所需业务用户的方便代表 - 这些角色描述了与您的产品交互的各种行业角色（或与与您的产品交互的人交互的人员） ），然后为这些角色创建产品和功能。角色可能都有不同的需求，但在任何客户组织中，他们通常拥有公司的总体增长目标。作为企业产品经理，这是一个明智的起点。

You’d think that “who are we building for” would be the easiest question in the field of product management. We build for the people who are asking us to build the software they want to buy, right? You focus on a bunch of personas—fictional constructs that act as convenient representatives for a desired business user with a given role or responsibility—which describe the various industry roles that interact with your product (or who interact with the people who interact with your product), and then you create products and features for those personas. Personas might all have different needs, but within any customer organization, they typically own overarching growth goals for their company. As an enterprise product manager, this is a wise place to start.

那么，我们来谈谈问题吧。

So, let’s talk about problems.

从根本上来说，无论是在消费者软件还是企业软件中，良好的产品管理都需要认识并深入理解问题。购买和使用您的软件的人拥有它们。您越能理解这些问题并将其深入内化，您就越能够向您的管理层、设计团队和开发团队表达这些问题，并能够通过提供相关的解决方案来解决这些问题。在第 7 章中，我们详细讨论了如何了解这些问题是什么。现在，只要您解决正确的问题，您的软件就会变得更有价值，您的业务也会增长。

Fundamentally, whether in consumer or enterprise software, good product management involves recognizing and deeply understanding problems. The people who buy and use your software have them. The better you empathize with those problems and internalize them deeply, the better you’ll be able to express them to your management, your design teams, and your development teams, and be able to solve those problems by delivering relevant solutions. In Chapter 7, we talk a lot more about how to learn what those problems are. For now, suffice it to say that when you solve the right problems, your software becomes much more valuable, and your business grows.

理解这些问题对于了解您正在为谁构建（以及为什么！）至关重要，因为企业软件通常涉及两组不同的问题：用户问题和客户问题。正如我们在第 1 章中讨论的那样，日常使用软件的人通常并不是最有价值解决问题的人（至少从业务角度来看）。

The reason that understanding these problems is central to knowing who you’re building for (and why!) is that enterprise software often involves two different sets of problems: user problems and customer problems. As we talked about in Chapter 1, the people who use your software day to day are often not the people whose problems are the most valuable to solve (at least, from your business perspective).

软件的用户经常会提出功能请求或向您提供与软件本身相关的信号。例如，技术更熟练的用户通常会要求相对较小的改进（例如用户界面 [UI] 调整），以使他们在日常工作中更加有效或高效。意识到这些问题是好事，而且在许多情况下它们值得解决。例如，它们可能会使您的软件更易于使用，这有助于扩大您的用户群。通常，这些请求将与产品设计或用户体验（UX）相关，这也是一些产品经理会说“用户体验设计拥有用户”的几个原因之一。

Users of your software will often make feature requests or give you a signal that relates to the software itself. For example, more technically adept users will often ask for relatively minor improvements (like user interface [UI] tweaks) that allow them to be more effective or efficient in their daily work. These problems are good to be aware of, and in many cases they are worth solving. For instance, they might make your software easier to use, which helps to expand your user base. Often, these requests will relate to product design or user experience (UX), and this is one of several reasons why some product managers will say that “user experience design owns the user.”

但这条格言的另一面同样是重要的是：“产品管理拥有客户。” 借用克莱顿·克里斯滕森 (Clayton Christensen) 的话来说，我们这里所说的“客户”是指那些雇佣您的产品来解决问题的组织。简而言之，客户是您的软件的购买者。这并不是指负责签署合同的采购人员；而是指负责签署合同的采购人员。相反，是具有购买力的高管。它指的是购买您的软件的一群人，因为他们相信这将有助于他们发展业务。

But the flip side of that maxim is equally important: “product management owns the customer.” By “customer,” we mean here the organizations that, to paraphrase Clayton Christensen,1 hire your product to solve a problem. In short, the customer is the buyer of your software. This doesn’t mean the guy in procurement who signs the contract; rather, it’s the executive(s) with purchasing power. It means the group of people who buy your software because they believe it will help them grow their business.

尽管组织内不同角色和不同角色的用户问题会有所不同（假设同一家公司中的两个用户与您的软件的交互可能非常不同），但客户问题对于整个组织来说是常见的，并且反映了客户解决问题的障碍。生长。当我们能够完成这句话时，我们就知道我们已经定义了客户问题：“作为[您的产品]的客户，我们无法像我们希望的那样快速增长，因为我们无法_。” 如果我们遇到一个产品创意无法快速、清晰地与客户的收入增长相关，我们为什么要投资来解决它？（当然，您的客户的问题可能不是增长，而是其他目标。我们在这里使用增长只是因为这是我们最熟悉的客户问题，并且是广泛共享的问题。）

Although user problems will differ from persona to persona and from role to role within an organization (given that two users in the same company might interact with your software very differently), customer problems are common to the entire organization and reflect barriers to your customers’ growth. We know we have defined a customer problem when we can finish the sentence, “As a customer of [your product], we cannot grow as fast as we would like because we can’t _.” If we come across a product idea that can’t be quickly and clearly related to a customer’s revenue growth, why would we invest to solve it? (Of course, your customer’s problem might not be growth, but rather some other goal. We have used growth here simply because it’s our most familiar customer problem, and one that is widely shared.)

以营销分析领域（你们的两位作者都有一定的深度）为例。营销归因是将收入归功于引导消费者购买的各种接触点和体验的做法，在过去十年的大部分时间里一直是热门话题。由于无法准确且有意义地将转化与产生转化的步骤关联起来，导致公司无法有效地分配营销预算并创建精美、优化的客户旅程，因此这些组织的支出效率低下，浪费大量预算。（提示约翰·沃纳梅克的老话，“我花在广告上的钱有一半被浪费了——问题是，我不知道是哪一半。”）

Take the field of marketing analytics (in which both of your authors have some depth), for example. Marketing attribution, the practice of assigning credit for revenue to the various touchpoints and experiences that led a consumer to purchase, has been a hot topic for most of a decade now. The inability to accurately and meaningfully associate a conversion to the steps that produced it leaves companies unable to efficiently allocate marketing budget and create beautiful, optimized customer journeys, and so these organizations spend inefficiently, wasting large swaths of their budget. (Cue the old John Wanamaker line, “Half the money I spend on advertising is wasted—the trouble is, I don’t know which half.”)

这里明显的客户问题是，“我们无法像我们希望的那样快速增长，因为我们没有办法轻松分析和优化我们的营销支出如何实际推动收入，从而导致许多机会错失。” 以下是我们行业中的一些其他客户问题示例，这些问题是您日常不一定会听到的问题产品的用户要求产品级别的改进：

The clear customer problem here is, “we cannot grow as fast as we would like because we don’t have a way to easily analyze and optimize how our marketing spend is actually driving revenue, leading to many missed opportunities.” Here are a few other examples of customer problems from our own industry, the kind you often wouldn’t necessarily hear from day-to-day users of a product asking for product-level improvements:

  • “我们的客户获取预算已经达到了收益递减的地步，但仍需要实现 20% 的同比增长目标。对我们来说，最有希望、最有效的方法就是个性化现场体验。”

  • “We have reached a point of diminishing returns from our customer acquisition budget, but still need to hit a top-line growth target of 20% year-on-year. The most promising and efficient way for us to do this is by personalizing the on-site experience.”

  • “我们面临着来自试图抢占市场份额的较小竞争对手的巨大降价压力，我们正在寻找新的方法来与我们自己的客户互动，以防止客户流失。”

  • “We are facing intense downward pricing pressure from a smaller competitor who is trying to steal market share, and we’re are looking for new ways to engage with our own customers to stem attrition.”

  • “我们知道细分在营销中至关重要，但除了我们多年来一直追求的传统细分市场之外，我们不知道如何找到正确的个人分组，以便我们能够在适当的时候以正确的方式接触到他们。合适的时间。”

  • “We know that segmentation is critical in marketing, but beyond our legacy market segments that we’ve been going after for years, we do not know how to find the right groupings of individuals so that we can reach them in the right way at the right time.”

  • “我们无法整合整个企业的客户数据，因此无法为各个营销团队提供品牌层面的见解。”

  • “We have been unable to consolidate our customer data across the enterprise and, as such, have not been able to empower various marketing teams with insights at the brand level.”

我们相信，扮演产品经理角色的一个好方法是将客户问题视为“货币”，使您能够围绕特定的产品愿景建立一致。作为产品经理，要获得你试图在内部协调的团队的信任和尊重，没有比一致、自信地阐明客户问题以及为什么这些问题对购买你的软件的公司至关重要的更好的方法了。稍后，我们会更多地讨论如何采访您的客户，以了解他们在组织和用户层面的问题，但现在，关键的要点是，您越了解是什么阻碍了客户实现他们的目标，你就能更好地解决让高层管理人员夜不能寐的问题。

We believe that a good way to approach your role as a product manager is to treat customer problems as the “currency” that allows you to build alignment around a specific product vision. As a product manager, there is no better way to gain the trust and respect of the groups you’re trying to align internally than to consistently and confidently articulate customer problems and why they are critical to the companies that buy your software. Later on, we talk a lot more about how to interview your customers to understand their problems at an organizational as well as a user level, but for now, the key takeaway is that the better you understand what is preventing your customers from accomplishing their goals, the better you’ll be equipped to solve the problems that keep their top executives awake at night.

您对市场和所服务的组织（和行业）研究得越多，您就会越多地看到公司之间出现的模式，并且最突出的问题将为您的产品管理团队具体化。一个客户问题，乘以一群客户，就变成了市场问题，解决市场问题就是你最大的市场机会。

The more you study your market and the organizations (and industries) you serve, the more you will see patterns emerge across companies, and the most salient problems will crystalize for your product management team. A customer problem, multiplied by a group of customers, becomes a market problem, and solving market problems is your biggest market opportunity.

值得注意的是，所有这些都不应被视为对“用户问题”的轻视，解决这一问题至关重要，因为用户也是购买（和保留）过程的一部分。然而，这是一个警告，不要以牺牲客户问题为代价来关注用户问题，因为这很容易做到。这是典型的“吱吱作响的车轮”情况。我们经常会听到产品用户讲述他们面临的问题，但通常情况下，用户问题的解决空间有限。它们可能有助于达成一两笔交易，但行业的塑造性增长来自于解决重大的客户问题，而这些问题通常需要数年而不是数月（或冲刺！）的工作。解决用户问题可以让您的用户满意，这非常重要，但他们不一定能为客户更广泛的挑战提供解决方案，从而使您的产品真正不可或缺。成为购买您产品的公司必不可少的最佳方式是帮助他们以独特的方式发展业务（即产生有意义的投资回报率）。这就是解决客户问题的全部内容，并且它是我们所能提供的企业软件和消费者软件之间差异的简洁封装。

It’s important to note that none of this should be taken as dismissive of “user problems,” which are critical to address because users are also part of the buying (and retention) process. It is, however, a warning against focusing on user problems at the expense of customer problems, because this is very easy to do. It’s a classic “squeaky wheel” situation. We will frequently hear from product users about the problems they face, but frequently, user problems have limited upside for you to solve. They might help close a deal or two, but industry-shaping growth comes from solving the big, meaty customer problems that often take years, not months (or sprints!), of work. Fixing user problems can delight your users, which is very important, but they do not necessarily deliver the solutions to your customers’ broader challenges that make your product truly indispensable. The best way to become essential for the companies that buy your products is to help them grow their business (i.e., to produce meaningful ROI) in unique ways. That is what solving customer problems is all about, and it’s as neat an encapsulation of the difference between enterprise and consumer software as we can offer.

最终，所有用户问题都源于客户问题并支持客户问题。以令用户满意的方式解决客户问题，并解决使用户更容易实现其组织的总体业务目标的用户问题。

Ultimately, all user problems flow out of, and support, customer problems. Solve customer problems in a way that pleases your users, and solve user problems that make their organizations’ overarching business goals easier for your users to obtain.

如果这听起来很难做到，那是因为事实确实如此。即使对于最精明的资深产品经理来说，企业软件领域也可能很难驾驭。掌握理解和内化客户问题的实践需要实践和努力，而协调您的组织来解决这些问题可能非常困难。但别担心；在本书的后面部分，我们将更详细地介绍您在第一天可以使用的策略，以帮助您解决市场、客户和用户问题。但首先，我们来谈谈如何有效地解决客户问题。

If this sounds difficult to do, that’s because it is. The enterprise software space can be difficult for even the savviest veteran product manager to navigate. Mastering the practice of understanding and internalizing customer problems takes practice and effort, and aligning your organization to solve them can be, well, really difficult. But don’t worry; later in this book we go into much more detail on strategies that you can use on your first day to help you absorb market, customer, and user problems. But first, let’s talk about how to solve a customer problem effectively.

从客户问题到产品愿景

From Customer Problems to a Product Vision

为了向客户提供解决方案，我们首先必须围绕我们正在解决的问题以及如何解决问题的想法在内部调整资源。推动复杂组织中团队之间的协调是企业产品经理必须培养的三到四项技能之一。

To deliver a solution to our customer, we first must align resources internally around what problem we’re solving and our idea of how to solve it. Driving alignment across teams in complex organizations is among the top three or four skills that an enterprise product manager must develop.

创建这种一致性从根本上来说是围绕理解我们刚刚讨论的客户问题而展开的。“我们为谁而建”是指发现阻碍客户成长的问题的重要性，而“我们如何解决这个问题”则是帮助我们担任不同角色（开发、设计、营销、销售等）的同事概念化客户问题并了解解决该问题的价值。没有“如何”的“谁”只是知识；没有“谁”的“如何”将无法实现一致性，并且肯定不会产生同样有效或有价值的产品。

Creating this alignment is fundamentally centered around understanding the customer problems that we’ve just discussed. Whereas “who we build for” is all about the importance of finding problems that prevent your customers from growing, “how we address this problem” involves then helping our colleagues in various roles (development, design, marketing, sales, etc.) conceptualize the customer problem and understand the value of solving it. “Who” without “how” is just knowledge; “how” without “who” won’t achieve alignment, and it certainly won’t produce as effective or as valuable a product.

我们建议产品经理如何开始围绕解决客户问题的方法达成共识：

Here is how we recommend product managers begin to create consensus around an approach to solving customer problems:

  1. 定义产品愿景

  2. Define a product vision

  3. 建立明确的成功指标

  4. Establish clear metrics of success

  5. 创建一个对产品成功负责的核心团队

  6. Create a core team that is accountable for product success

让我们依次分解这些内容。

Let’s break each of these down in turn.

定义产品愿景

Defining the Product Vision

为了推动一致性，您和您的产品经理团队可以做的最重要的一件事就是建立清晰的产品愿景。这可能是它自己的书的主题，但思考这个问题的最简单方法是，产品愿景是开发人员和设计师每天所做的事情与更大的公司愿景之间的联系。每个产品经理（实际上是每个员工，尤其是每个产品经理）不仅应该能够背诵公司愿景，而且还应该能够生活和呼吸它。例如，Adobe 一段时间以来的愿景是“通过数字体验改变世界”。SAS 的使命是为客户提供“了解的力量”。您可以使用这些声明来开始在 Adob​​e 或 SAS 进行的任何演示或关于 Adob​​e 或 SAS 的演示，然后从那里开始。

The single most important thing that you and your team of product managers can do to drive alignment is to establish a clear product vision. This could be the subject of its own book, but the easiest way to think about this is that the product vision is the connection between what your developers and designers do every day and the larger company vision. Every product manager (and really every employee, but especially every product manager) should be able to not just recite the company vision, but also to live and breathe it. As an example, Adobe’s vision for some time has been, “Changing the world through digital experiences.” SAS’s mission is giving customers “The Power to Know.” You could start any presentation given at or about Adobe or SAS with these statements, and go from there.

作为产品经理，建立产品愿景（如果还没有明确的愿景）的最佳方法是弄清楚您的产品将如何帮助您的公司实现其愿景。

As the product manager, the best way to establish your product vision (if there isn’t already a clear one) is to figure out how your product will help your company achieve its vision.

产品愿景明确后，寻求建立您的产品实现该愿景所需的创新类别。您最终将得到一个类似于图 2-1 的层次结构。

After the product vision is clear, seek to establish the categories of innovation that your product needs to pursue to achieve that vision. You will end up with a hierarchy looking something like Figure 2-1.

我们建议非常清楚这个层次结构，当您向同事展示您的想法时，请浏览类似于图 2-1 的内容，但希望在视觉上比图 2-1更具吸引力。提醒管理层您的产品如何与公司愿景相联系，以及产品策略的相关方面如何帮助实现该愿景。您将准备好解释您正在寻求开展的项目如何实现该产品策略。

We propose being very clear about this hierarchy, and as you present your ideas to colleagues, go through something similar to but hopefully more visually appealing than Figure 2-1. Remind management how your product connects to the company vision and how the relevant aspects of the product strategy help realize that vision. You’ll be all set up to explain how the project you are seeking to undertake brings that product strategy to bear.

建立（或简单地重申）产品愿景和策略对于如何实现至关重要因为如果你的同事无法将项目与更广泛的战略和愿景联系起来，那么你的同事将很难将你要求他们做的事情融入到上下文中。如果您曾经被要求提供一个结果而不知道它为什么重要，那么您可能自己也经历过这种情况。您知道，保持积极性或理解实现预期目标的正确方法可能很困难。另一方面，当你可以清楚地看到你正在从事的项目和总体目标之间的联系时，其他一切就更容易落实到位。开发人员、产品设计师、甚至销售人员也是如此。明确定义目标和旅程中的主要里程碑是产品管理应发挥的关键领导作用，以将产品变为现实。

Establishing (or simply reiterating) the product vision and strategy is critical to the how of shipping product because it will be difficult for your colleagues to put what you’re asking them to do into context without the ability to connect the project to the broader strategy and vision. You may have experienced this yourself if you have ever been asked to produce an outcome without knowing why it is important. You know that it can be difficult to stay motivated or to understand the right way to deliver what’s expected. On the other hand, when you can clearly see the connection between the project you’re working on and big-picture objectives, it’s easier for everything else to fall into place. Developers, product designers, and even salespeople are the same way. Clearly defining the goal and the major milestones along your journey is a critical leadership function that product management should serve to bring a product into reality.

衡量成功

Measuring Success

管理大师彼得·德鲁克有句名言：“如果不衡量，就无法改进。” 对于软件和任何其他学科来说都是如此。技术史册上充斥着这样的公司，它们开始实施他们认为会改变行业的产品战略或一系列功能，但几个月或几年后却发现它实际上并没有影响他们的利润。如果他们早点知道的话，他们就可以纠正路线了！或者，如果他们的努力取得了巨大成功，他们就可以向领导层证明他们的工作和计划​​是多么有效。

Management guru Peter Drucker famously said, “You can’t improve what you don’t measure.” This is as true of software as it is of any other discipline. The annals of technology are littered with companies that embarked on what they thought was an industry-changing product strategy or set of features, only to find months or years later that it did not actually affect their bottom lines. If only they had known earlier, they could have course corrected! Alternatively, if their efforts were wildly successful, they could have demonstrated to leadership how effective their work and planning had been.

因此，作为产品经理，除非您认真考虑了衡量，否则您不能认为您的软件发布是成功的，其中包括定义您希望通过发布改进的关键绩效指标（KPI）并确保适当的数据收集监控这些 KPI（并且希望能够让您准确解释KPI 变化或不变的原因）。

Thus, as a product manager you cannot consider your software release a success unless you have given serious thought to measurement, which includes both defining the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that you expect to improve with a release and ensuring that the appropriate data collection is in place to monitor those KPIs (and, hopefully, to allow you to explain exactly why a KPI is moving or not moving).

如果您的产品愿景和策略具有明确的目标和所需的关键结果，那么您将能够最成功地为功能或版本创建和定义 KPI。我们可以用几个章节来讨论这些目标和关键结果(OKR)，它们最初是由英特尔在 20 世纪 70 年代末开发的，因为它们对于这个过程非常重要。相反，我们将向您推荐一些现有的许多其他资源，以帮助您深入了解该主题。2 OKR 概念简单直观，但经常被企业软件开发团队忽视。本章的其余部分主要是关于推动产品管理团队以及参与开发过程的其他所有人之间的协调，没有比确保目标和关键结果明确更好的方法了。为您的产品定义正确的 KPI 依赖于首先从这些 OKR 开始；否则，您将根据风向来决定要去哪里。

You will have the most success creating and defining KPIs for a feature or a release in the presence of clear objectives and desired key results stemming from your product vision and strategy. We could devote several chapters to these objectives and key results (OKRs), which were originally developed by Intel in the late 1970s, because they are that important to this process. Instead, we will refer you to a couple of the many other sources that exist to help you dive deeply into this topic.2 The OKR concept is simple and intuitive, but too often ignored by enterprise software development teams. The rest of this chapter is largely about driving alignment within product management teams as well as among everyone else involved in the development process, and there is no better way to do that than to ensure that objectives and key results are clear. Defining the right KPIs for your product relies on beginning with these OKRs first; otherwise, you’re deciding where you want to go based on whatever direction the wind happens to be blowing.

OKR 有许多不同的“级别”或“层”，但这里我们将重点关注产品级的 OKR。在这种情况下，“目标”是指您和您的领导层在给定时间段内为您的产品设定的定性战略目标。例如，“推动用户采用”或“准备进入云市场”。在许多企业软件组织中，您的目标将由高级产品领导层设定，并且可能会交给您。在其他情况下，您将有机会与领导层互动，根据您的产品愿景和战略，确定您和您的同事要追求的最紧迫和最关键的目标。

There are many different “levels” or “tiers” of OKRs, but here we will focus on product-level OKRs. An “objective” in this context is a qualitative, strategic goal that you and your leadership have for your product during a given period of time. For example, “drive user adoption” or “prepare to enter the cloud market.” In many enterprise software organizations, your objectives will be set by senior product leadership and might be handed down to you. In others, you will have the opportunity to engage with your leadership to define the most pressing and critical goals for you and your colleagues to pursue, based on your product vision and strategy.

因为 OKR 旨在帮助您专注于要解决的最重要问题，并且因为您几乎肯定没有足够的设计和开发资源来完成您可能想做的所有事情，所以明智的做法是将您的目标列表保持在 3 到 3 之间五。定义和磨练这些目标的过程可能会很辛苦，但它为衡量奠定了基础，同时也确保您的软件版本符合您的产品愿景和战略。

Because OKRs are designed to help you focus on the most important problems to solve, and because you almost definitely do not have enough design and development resources to do everything you might like to do, it’s smart to keep your list of objectives to between three and five. The process of defining and honing these objectives can be grueling, but it sets the foundation for measurement while also ensuring that your software releases are in line with your product vision and strategy.

关键结果源自目标，如果做得好，可以帮助解决为功能或计划定义 KPI 的问题。与目标不同，关键结果应该是定量的，并定义其给定目标的成功。当您寻找最适合您希望在业务中看到的长期变化的事物时，您将选择它们。如果您是一名产品经理，考虑“准备进入云市场”目标，关键结果可能包括让一定数量的参考客户启动并运行产品的测试版，在行业分析师发布的研究中获得排名，和/或与您的产品组合中其他更成熟的产品实现一定比例的交叉销售。您可以使用这些关键结果中的每一个来创建 KPI，以帮助定义您的产品路线图，重点关注您可以做的最能影响这些指标的事情。

Key results flow from objectives and, when done well, can help solve the problem of defining KPIs for a feature or initiative. Unlike objectives, key results should be quantitative, and define success for their given objective. You will select them as you look for the things that best set you up for the long-term changes that you want to see in your business. If you were a product manager thinking about the “prepare to enter the cloud market” objective, key results might involve getting a certain number of reference customers up and running on a beta version of a product, winning placement in an industry analyst’s published research, and/or achieving a certain percentage of cross-sell with other more established products in your portfolio. You can use each of these key results to create a KPI to help define your product roadmap, focusing on the things you can do that will best affect these metrics.

很多时候，这个过程是完全倒着进行的。大多数企业软件产品团队从路线图开始（希望基于产品策略），然后要么完全忽略测量和迭代，要么在将每个功能放入路线图后找出每个功能的 KPI。但是，通过从目标和关键结果出发，然后再决定将哪些内容放在路线图上，您可以确保您正在构建的内容专注于实现最重要的目标。

Way too often, this process is done precisely backward. Most enterprise software product teams begin with a roadmap (hopefully based on a product strategy), and then either ignore measurement and iteration altogether or figure out KPIs for each individual feature after it has already been placed on the roadmap. But by starting from objectives and key results and only then deciding what to place on the roadmap, you can ensure that what you are building is focused on achieving your most important goals.

当我们刚刚花了几页试图说服您作为产品经理始终将客户问题放在首位时，听起来 OKR 似乎优先考虑了您公司的问题（增加收入、扩大用户群、进入新市场等）。事实上，在你达到目标和关键结果之前，客户问题就应该早在你达到目标和关键结果之前就告诉你的产品策略，所以它们已经融入到这个配方中了。此外，在了解 OKR 后，您可以利用对客户问题的关注来找出哪些解决方案最能推动关键结果和 KPI。例如，如果您提出的关键结果之一是“明年推动 20% 的收入增长”，您将以此为目标并找出哪些客户问题最有价值，这样，如果解决了，它们将导致完成该目标业务目标。换句话说，实现您定义的关键结果和 KPI 的最佳方法是首先解决最紧迫的客户问题；如果不是，你要么得到错误的关键结果，要么得到错误的客户问题。

It might sound like OKRs prioritize your company’s problems (growing revenue, expanding the user base, moving into new markets, etc.) when we have just spent several pages trying to convince you to always put customer problems first in your thinking as a product manager. In reality, customer problems should inform your product strategy long before you get to objectives and key results, so they are already baked into this recipe. Furthermore, after you know your OKRs, you can use your focus on customer problems to figure out which solutions will drive key results and KPIs the most. For example, if one of your proposed key results is to “drive 20% revenue growth next year,” you would take that goal and find out which customer problems are most valuable so that, if solved, they would lead to the completion of that business objective. In other words, the best way to achieve the key results and KPIs that you define will be to solve the most pressing customer problems first; if not, you either have the wrong key results or the wrong customer problems.

您可能有一些项目或功能无法清晰地映射到目标或关键结果。在各种企业软件组织中，都必须处理行政命令、客户升级以及技术债务或基础设施项目，无论它们是否实现了您的关键成果之一。在您的产品目标之一之外，您的开发团队可能可以兼职做一些较小的功能。为此，您需要定义自己的 KPI，并定义衡量这些 KPI 的计划。

You might have some projects or features that do not map cleanly to an objective or key result. In all kinds of enterprise software organizations there are executive mandates, customer escalations, and technical debt or infrastructure projects that simply have to be handled, whether they achieve one of your key results or not. There might be smaller features that your development team can do on the side, outside of one of your product objectives. For these you will need to define your own KPIs, and define a plan for measuring those KPIs.
