我们将在第 6 章中进一步讨论该测量过程。现在，请考虑以下两个关键点：

We will discuss that process of measurement a bit more in Chapter 6. For now, consider the following two key points:

  • 除非您定义并衡量了成功，否则产品或功能不可能成功。

  • A product or feature cannot be successful unless you have defined and measured success.

  • 最好的产品路线图是围绕您希望实现的目标和关键结果构建的，而不是相反。

  • The best product roadmaps are built around the objectives and key results you hope to achieve, not the opposite.

产品领导团队

The Product Leadership Team

其他有关产品管理的书籍或博客可能会建议您，围绕一个想法推动一致性就像与您的工程和设计同行合作，一起拜访客户或带每个人出去吃饭一样简单。然而，如果您正在阅读这本书，那么您的公司很可能比标准发行的初创公司要复杂一些，在标准发行的初创公司中，每个人都认识每个人，并且公司范围内的全体会议可以是每周或每天举行的简单会议。

Other books or blogs about product management might have suggested to you that driving alignment around an idea is as simple as teaming up with your engineering and design counterparts to visit a customer together or taking everyone out to dinner. If you’re reading this book, however, there is a good chance that your company is a little more complex than the standard-issue startup in which everyone knows everyone and company-wide all-hands meetings can be a simple weekly or daily occurrence.

作为大型企业软件组织中的产品经理，可能有多个产品线并且不同团队之间存在竞争优先级，您将需要想出一种方法来组织疯狂的事情（或者，正如我们有时所知道的那样，“山羊竞技”）。即使在单个产品团队中，关于哪些项目应该由开发资助的意见也会很多。产品经理可以而且经常确实对相同的市场信号做出截然不同的解释——通常取决于这些信号如何影响每个产品经理自己的产品。

As a product manager in a larger, enterprise software organization, perhaps with several product lines and competing priorities among different teams, you will need to come up with a way to organize the madness (or, as it’s sometimes known in our parts, the “goat rodeo”). Even within a single product team, opinions about what projects should be funded by development will abound. Product managers can and often do interpret the same market signals quite differently from one another—frequently, according to how they affect each PM’s own product.

当您有了清晰的产品愿景和战略，以及针对特定客户问题的拟议解决方案后，如何确保每个人都以同样的方式理解这种联系以及相关的商业机会？如何才能达成真正的共识，让各利益相关者同步走向市场？领导层如何以清晰、一致和负责任的声音说话？

After you have a clear product vision and strategy, as well as a proposed solution to a particular customer problem, how do you make sure everyone understands this connection—and the related business opportunity—the same way? How can you create real consensus so that the various stakeholders can move toward the market in sync with one another? How does leadership speak with a clear, consistent, and accountable voice?

有很多方法可以做到这一点，并且它们取决于多种因素。无论您的组织是 20 人的初创公司还是价值数十亿美元的巨头，这个过程都绝非易事。每家公司都不同，但我们将分享一种在我们所属的几个大型、复杂的软件开发组织中行之有效的方法：产品领导团队(PLT)。

There are many ways to do this, and they depend on a variety of factors. Regardless of whether your organization is a 20-person startup or a multibillion-dollar giant, this process is never easy. Each company is different, but we’ll share one method that has worked in several large, complex software development organizations that we’ve been a part of: the Product Leadership Team (PLT).

如果您的开发组织很成熟，您可能拥有程序或项目管理功能，该功能可以使开发保持在正轨上并帮助组织分布式工作计划。项目管理可能有助于在关键决策者之间建立每周一次的检查，例如参与开发和上市过程的开发经理、产品经理、运营和产品领导。每周（或每隔一周，或每月；您会找到正确的节奏），该 PLT 将听取项目提案并做出裁决，并且因为它代表产品管理、各个工程团队以及参与产品开发过程的其他人员，将能够直接讨论可能的项目并达成共识。将其视为校长会议。

If your development organization is mature, you likely have a program or project management function, which serves to keep development on track and helps organize distributed work plans. Program management might assist in establishing a weekly check-in among key decision-makers, like development managers, product managers, operations, and product leadership involved in the development and go-to-market process, for example. Each week (or every other week, or every month; you will find the right cadence), this PLT will hear and rule on project proposals, and, because it represents product management, various engineering teams, and others involved in the product development process, it will be able to directly discuss possible projects and reach consensus. Think of it as something of a principals’ meeting.

这个群体需要致力于参与，但在项目开始实施后，他们会发现巨大的好处，即减少因优先事项转移或不明确而导致的浪费精力，并为市场上的客户问题提供更多解决方案。理想情况下，在更大、更复杂的软件组织中，如果没有首先获得 PLT 的开发批准，任何重大开发计划都无法启动，更不用说推向市场了。至少，这可以让领导层了解正在发生的事情。当这个过程发挥其魔力时，它确保资源被分配给最好和最有价值的客户问题，而不是一个或另一个产品经理碰巧与一两个开发人员和流氓设计资源在幕后解决的问题。

This group will need to be committed to participating, but after the ball gets rolling, it will find tremendous benefit in the form of less wasted effort due to shifting or unclear priorities and more solutions to customer problems making it to market. Ideally, in a larger, more complex software organization, no major development initiatives can kick off—let alone go to market—without first having been approved for development by the PLT. At the very least, this keeps leadership aware of what is going on. When this process is working its magic, it ensures that resources are allocated to the best and most valuable customer problems rather than to what one product manager or another happened to work out behind the scenes with a developer or two and a rogue design resource.

尽管 PLT 的主要目标是选择要执行的项目，但 PLT 让领导层随时了解情况这一事实不应被忽视，这是其主要优势之一。在许多情况下，即使是与产品或客户体验相关但不涉及开发的项目也应该在 PLT 之前进行，以便产品领导层能够向高级管理层反映和捍卫这些努力。

Although the primary goal of the PLT is to choose which projects to execute on, the fact that the PLT keeps leadership informed should not be ignored as one of its key benefits. In many cases, even projects related to the product or the customer experience that do not involve development should go before the PLT so that product leadership can reflect and defend those efforts to senior management.

根据您产品中产品的数量和复杂性，PLT 会议可能是整个产品组合的每周一次检查，或者您可能希望为您的团队/公司中的每个主要产品部门召开单独的 PLT。我们亲爱的读者，您可能不会每周都参加这次会议，具体取决于您的角色，但至少您希望包括以下人员：

Depending on the number and complexity of products in your offering, the PLT meeting might be a single weekly check-in for the entire product portfolio, or you might want a separate PLT for each major product division in your group/company. You, our dear reader, might not be in this meeting every week, depending upon your role, but at the very least you will want to include the following people:

  • 产品管理领导力

  • Product management leadership

  • 发展领导力

  • Development leadership

  • 项目管理领导力

  • Program management leadership

  • 产品/技术运营领导

  • Product/technical operations leadership

  • 根据您的独特组织需要而定的其他内容

  • Others as needed based on your unique organization

  • 每次会议议程所需的其他内容

  • Others as needed for agenda on a per-meeting basis

作为产品经理，当您对给定的客户问题进行分析并提出解决方案时，您和您的开发同事将被列入 PLT 议程。在第 5 章中，我们讨论您向 PLT 的演示可能是什么样子（尽管没有适用于每个公司的每个软件产品、每个项目/功能的模板）。您将在研究过程中接触 PLT，以获得该小组的批准以继续设计和开发。一旦您确定了拟议项目的一些诚意，您友好的邻里项目经理将能够帮助您抽出时间与 PLT 进行交流。

As a product manager, you and your development counterparts will get on the PLT agenda as you put together an analysis of, and proposed solution to, a given customer problem. In Chapter 5, we discuss what your presentation to the PLT might look like (although there is no template that will work for every software product, for every project/feature, in every company). You will approach the PLT in the middle of your research to get that group’s approval to move forward with design and development. Your friendly neighborhood program manager will be able to help you get time with the PLT as soon as you have established some of the bona fides of your proposed project.

您可能会想，“在我的公司，我们自以为敏捷，但这听起来非常瀑布式。” 所以，我们要坦白说：PLT主要是一种瀑布式开发技术。我们将离开“敏捷在企业软件中有效吗？” 再次辩论，只是说我们认为确实如此，但进行了一些必要的调整。即使是企业软件中最敏捷的开发组织也有主要的、通常是相互关联和相互依赖的计划，这些计划需要进行规划，并且需要多次冲刺才能完成。这就是 PLT 的闪光点。如果您像我们观察到的公司一样，您还可以享受较小的、冲刺规模的项目，这些项目不需要在 PLT 之前进行（稍后会详细介绍）；但对于需要几个人月才能完成的项目，让关键利益相关者批准它们可以让你在开发和设计团队中获得不可伪造的权威。

You might be thinking, “At my company, we fancy ourselves agile, but this sounds very waterfall.” So, we’ll come clean: the PLT is largely a waterfall development technique. We’ll leave the “Does agile work in enterprise software?” debate for another time, except to say that we think it does, but with some necessary adjustments. Even the most agile development organization in enterprise software has major, often interlocking and interdependent initiatives that require planning and take more than a couple of sprints to complete. This is where the PLT shines. If you are like the companies we have observed, you will also have allowances for smaller, sprint-sized projects that do not need to come in front of the PLT (more on this in a moment); but for projects that take more than a few person-months to complete, getting them sanctioned by key stakeholders gives you authority with development and design teams that can’t be faked. Product marketing may also get involved as the projects in question touch upon your communicable value proposition.

本节不是关于如何召开会议，但值得注意的是，尽管 PLT 可以成为推动协调的巨大工具，但这并不意味着每个人都应该参加。当然，借用音乐剧《汉密尔顿》中的一句台词，每个人都希望身处“事情发生的房间”，但 PLT 需要以项目提案的形式处理大量信息，对其进行简要讨论，并提供资金和优先级决定。将会议变成国会会议将使您陷入无休止的辩论中，并妨碍快速决策和协调，而这正是 PLT 的全部目的。这是决策者会议，而不是辩论俱乐部。PLT 会议的时间范围，要求及时做出决定，并遵守Andy Grove 的“不同意并承诺”规则。与此同时，会议中的领导层应该有足够的得力助手，帮助他们提供在评估项目价值和范围时可能缺乏的背景信息。这是您需要针对您的特定情况进行测试和优化的内容。通常，需要一定程度的授权。这几乎总是一件健康的事情。

This section isn’t about how to run meetings, but it is worth noting that even though the PLT can be a tremendous device for driving alignment, that does not mean that everyone should be there. Of course, to borrow a line from the musical Hamilton, everyone wants to be in “the room where it happens,” but the PLT will need to process a lot of information in the form of project proposals, discuss them briefly, and make funding and prioritization decisions. Turning the meeting into a session of Congress will bog you down in never-ending debate and prevent rapid decision-making and alignment, which is the entire purpose of the PLT. This is a decision makers’ meeting, not a debate club. Timebox the PLT meeting, mandate that decisions be made in a timely fashion as a result, and abide by Andy Grove’s rule of “disagree and commit”. At the same time, leadership in the meeting should have enough of their righthand people there to help provide them with context that they might be lacking when it comes to evaluating the value and scope of a project. This is something you’ll need to test and optimize for your particular circumstances. Often, some level of delegation of authority is required. That is almost always a healthy thing.

我们已经看到了这个策略如何发挥作用的几个例子。首先，一家大型企业供应商的产品团队被要求就其平台如何与最近获得的相邻解决方案集成制定几个不同的想法。因此，为了应对这一挑战，该团队与被收购团队的产品经理齐心协力，提出了一些新的跨功能和集成的想法，这些想法对普通用户来说很有价值。然后他们就等着了。这个非常传统的层级组织没有 PLT，产品团队也没有权力自行做出像这样的重大战略决策。相反，他们被要求等待来自多级领导层的绿灯，但从未到来。不仅没有授权，对每种产品的未来做出战略决策也没有时间限制。最终，其他问题出现了，紧迫感也逐渐消失。两种产品之间只提供了非常基本的连接，该团队失去了市场领导地位的重大机会。

We’ve seen a couple of examples of how this strategy plays out. In the first, a product team in a large enterprise vendor was asked to sketch out a couple of different ideas for how its platform could integrate with a recently acquired adjacent solution. So, eager to tackle the challenge, this team put heads together with the acquired team’s product managers and developed a few ideas for novel new cross-features and integrations that their common users would find valuable. And then they waited. This very traditional, hierarchical organization had no PLT, and product teams were not empowered to make big strategic decisions like this one on their own. Instead, they were required to wait for a green light from multiple levels of leadership that never came. Not only was there no delegation of authority, there was also no time limit placed on making strategic decisions about the future of each product. Eventually, other issues arose and the sense of urgency faded. Only very rudimentary connections between the two products were ever delivered, and this team lost a major opportunity for market leadership.

在第二个示例中，另一个企业供应商拥有跨特定解决方案组的 PLT 版本，但它无法确定共同的顶级优先级。多年来，该组织实际上有二十个优先事项——也就是说，它没有。“PLT”没有一套明确的总体目标或实现这些目标的明确战略。当增长停滞且全面进展缓慢意味着什么都没有“完成”时，这种状况最终达到了顶峰。PLT 感受到来自领导层的压力，最终强加了一项任务：产品和工程必须在 Y 日期之前实现 X 目标，否则。每个人头上都悬着一把利剑，最终确定了优先事项，并在规定的时间内完成了 X 项目。尽管这“有效”，但这显然仍然是一个远非理想的优先级强制过程。

In the second example, another enterprise vendor had a version of the PLT across a particular solution group, but it couldn’t settle on common top-level priorities. For years, the group effectively had twenty priorities—which is to say, it had none. The “PLT” did not have a clear set of overarching goals or a definite strategy to achieve them. This state of affairs finally came to a head when growth stalled and the slow pace of progress across the board meant that nothing was getting to “done.” The PLT, feeling pressure from leadership, finally imposed a mandate: product and engineering must deliver X goal by Y date, or else. With a sword hanging over everyone’s head, hard priorities were finally set and X project was met within the mandated timeline. Even though this “worked,” this is still obviously a far-from-ideal priority-forcing process.

由于 PLT 需要做出各种决策，您可能会发现自己需要偶尔与该团队一起退后一步，并确保每个人仍然同意最基本的决策规则：您的产品愿景和 OKR 。最终，PLT 同意做的一切都应该支持这一愿景，或者用新的经验和证据来挑战它。不要害怕在会议上花时间与参与者重新建立产品愿景和战略，以确保在决定特定项目时，每个人都同意您在更广泛的范围内尝试做的事情意义以及你想要成为的产品。

Because of the kinds of decisions that a PLT is tasked with making, you might find yourself needing to occasionally take a step back with this group and make sure that everyone still agrees on the most fundamental rubrics for decision-making: your product vision and OKRs. Ultimately, everything that the PLT agrees to do should support that vision or challenge it with new learnings and evidence. Do not be afraid to take time in that meeting to reestablish the product vision and strategy with participants as a way to ensure that, when it comes time to decide on a particular project, everyone is agreed on what you are trying to do in the broader sense and what you are trying to be as a product.

因此，我们现在定义了 PLT：一小群领导者，他们决定什么、何时以及如何“资助”具有设计和开发资源的项目，并确保您发布的软件支持您的产品策略和愿景。但我们还没有讨论如何使用 PLT 将创新想法转化为正式演示、资助项目和交付软件。如果您急于了解该部分，请跳至第 5 章。不过，在此之前，我们需要了解一些不同的领域，这些领域涉及我们许多人潜伏的一些“未知的未知因素”。

So, we have now defined the PLT: a small group of leaders who make decisions about what, when, and how to “fund” a project with design and development resources, and who can ensure that the software you are releasing supports your product strategy and vision. But we have not yet discussed how to use the PLT to get from innovative ideas to formal presentations, to funded projects, to shipped software. If you’re anxious to get to that part, skip to Chapter 5. Before that, though, we need to cover some different ground that goes over some “unknown unknowns” lurking out there for many of us.

概括

Summary

企业产品经理面临的主要挑战是识别用户问题与客户问题，并清楚地了解您的产品如何解决每一组问题。客户问题是你作为产品经理的“货币”，因为只有解决这些问题，你才能证明你的产品具有释放变革价值的潜力。解决这些问题需要使您的组织围绕产品的共同愿景进行调整，该愿景应源自公司的使命和身份。将愿景转化为运营计划的一个好方法是通过 PLT 框架，您可以将其用作强制及时决策、问责制和共同目标的方法。

The central challenge for enterprise product managers is identifying user problems versus customer problems, and clearly understanding how your product addresses each set. Customer problems are your “currency” as a product manager, because it’s only by solving them that you prove the potential for your product to unlock transformational value. Addressing those problems requires aligning your organization around a shared vision for the product, which should derive from your company’s mission and identity. A great way of translating that vision into an operational plan is via the PLT framework, which you can use as a method to force timely decisions, accountability, and shared goals.

项目经理简介

姓名：尼克·法斯勒

Name: Nick Fassler

职位：产品经理，Asana

Title: Product Manager, Asana

您是如何开始产品管理的？

How did you get started in product management?

早在我从事技术工作之前，我就爱上了优秀的软件。我是我能找到的所有“Web 2.0”工具的早期采用者。虽然我职业生涯的早期从事非营利和可持续发展领域，但我始终说服与我合作的团队采用 Harvest 和 Basecamp 等早期的网络生产力工具。

Way before I ever worked in technology, I fell in love with great software. I was an early adopter of every “web 2.0” tool I could find. While I spent the early part of my career in the nonprofit and sustainability sectors, I always convinced the teams I worked with to adopt early web productivity tools like Harvest and Basecamp.

读研究生期间，我开始追求创办公司的想法。我花了一年多的时间试图找到一个以可持续发展为重点的想法来构建，但最终又回到了团队生产力软件。我创建了 Thrively，这是一个专注于改进公司绩效评估和同行反馈流程的工具。我筹集了天使资金，组建了团队，并推出了产品，但最终却无法继续前进。那次经历让我意识到以制造产品为生是多么的棒。

During grad school, I started pursuing the idea of starting a company. I spent over a year trying to find a sustainability-focused idea to build but ultimately gravitated back to team productivity software. I started Thrively, a tool that focused on improving the performance review and peer feedback process for companies. I raised angel funding, built a team, and launched a product—but ultimately ran out of runway to keep going. That experience made me realize how awesome it would be to build products for a living.

您认为有哪些特定背景对企业产品经理特别有价值吗？

Are there particular backgrounds you think are especially valuable for enterprise product managers?

我认识很多优秀的产品经理，他们的背景截然不同，所以很难说某一特定背景特别有价值。成为企业 PM 的最“标准”途径似乎是拥有技术背景，然后获得 MBA 学位。我确实认为，拥有坚实的业务基础对于在企业中工作尤其重要，因为您要尝试为最终用户和付费客户进行构建。我还曾与一些出色的企业产品经理合作过，他们以前从事销售工程工作，我认为这是一个独特的角色，可以让您了解产品的构建方式和业务需求。

I know so many excellent PMs with radically different backgrounds, so it’s hard to say that one particular background is especially valuable. The most “standard” path to becoming an enterprise PM seems to be coming from a technical background and then getting your MBA. I do think that having solid business fundamentals is especially important for working in enterprise, where you are trying to build for end users and for paying customers. I’ve also worked with a handful of amazing enterprise PMs that were previously in sales engineering—I think it’s a unique role that gives you exposure to both how products are built and the needs of a business.

成为一名优秀的企业产品经理所需的技能也因您的业务模式而异。如果您主要通过大型企业交易销售产品，那么产品经理的角色可能更接近业务职能，以优先考虑个人客户的需求并帮助完成交易。另一方面，在 Asana（以及之前的 Yammer），我们的免费增值模式意味着产品经理通常更接近设计和用户研究——我们需要专注于构建最终用户采用的产品。

The necessary skill set to be a great enterprise PM also differs depending on your business model. If you are primarily selling a product with large enterprise deals, the PM role likely works much closer to business functions to prioritize individual customer needs and help close deals. On the other side of the spectrum, at Asana (and previously Yammer), our freemium model means that PMs are often closer to design and user research—we need to focus on building products that end users adopt.

作为产品经理，你什么时候感到最有成就感？

When have you felt most fulfilled as a product manager?

我从指导新的有抱负的产品经理中获得了很多能量。教授产品管理迫使我反思我作为产品经理所学到的知识，并让我诚实地思考如何才能变得更好。在 Asana，我非常幸运能够指导一些才华横溢且充满热情的实习生。指导具有原始才能和动力的人们，并帮助他们将其转化为能够构建出色的产品，这是一次令人难以置信的经历。去年夏天，我们的实习生开发了一项功能（Asana 模板），该功能成为公司最大的收入来源之一。

I get so much energy from mentoring new and aspiring PMs. Teaching product management forces me to reflect on what I’ve learned as a PM and keeps me honest about how I can get better. At Asana, I have been extremely fortunate to mentor some amazingly talented and passionate interns. It’s an incredible experience to coach folks with raw talent and drive, and help them turn that into being able to build awesome products. Last summer, our intern built a feature (Asana Templates) that turned into one of the company’s largest revenue wins.

如果你不从事产品管理，你会在技术领域做什么？

What would you do in tech if you weren’t in product management?

如果我不是产品经理，我可能会成为一名增长营销人员。我以前有很多营销经验，特别是在用户获取方面，这个角色对人们如何采用技术有很大影响。我正在 Asana 组建移动增长团队，因此直接与我们的营销团队合作对我来说很有趣。我经常想深入研究我们的 Google AdWords 广告活动，但幸运的是，作为产品经理让我很忙。

I’d likely be a growth marketer if I wasn’t a PM. I have lots of previous marketing experience, especially in user acquisition, and it’s a role that has a lot of impact on how people adopt technology. I’m working to build out the mobile growth team at Asana, so it’s fun for me to get to work directly with our marketing teams. I’m often tempted to dive into our Google Adwords ad campaigns, but luckily being a PM keeps me plenty busy.

1卡门·诺布尔，“克莱·克里斯滕森的奶昔营销”，http://hbs.me/2GAQAox。

1 Carmen Noble, “Clay Christensen’s Milkshake Marketing,” http://hbs.me/2GAQAox.

2Google 以实施 OKR 并取得巨大成功而闻名，它在这里介绍了自己的流程：http://bit.ly/2H3VJGw。Christina Wodtke 的《Radical Focus》也是该主题的开创性著作：http://amzn.to/2Ev2zqa。

2 Google, which has famously implemented OKRs to great success, writes about its own process here: http://bit.ly/2H3VJGw. Christina Wodtke’s Radical Focus is also a seminal work on the topic: http://amzn.to/2Ev2zqa.

第 3 章产品经理需要寻求的三种知识

Chapter 3. Three Types of Knowledge for a Product Manager to Seek

无论你走到哪里，成功的产品经理都会不懈地追求知识，尽管重要的知识种类以及如何获取这些知识各不相同。我们建议将您作为企业产品经理的研究和专业知识分为三个不同的类别：组织知识、产品知识和行业知识。

Anywhere you go, successful product managers are relentless in their pursuit of knowledge, although the kinds of knowledge that matter—and how to obtain that knowledge—vary. We recommend thinking about your research and expertise as an enterprise product manager as falling into three distinct categories: organizational knowledge, product knowledge, and industry knowledge.

恭喜您受聘或晋升为产品经理！如果你像大多数人一样作为新产品经理，你们充满活力和热情，准备好通过纯粹的勇气、决心以及为开发人员提供的大量甜食或酒车来征服世界。（布莱尔更喜欢波旁威士忌和软糖蠕虫，而本则喜欢冰淇淋。对于每位 PM，他们自己的。）您将立即赢得您的同事的支持，并凭借您为公司带来的所有热情推出出色的产品功能。正确的？

Congratulations on your hire or promotion into the role of product manager! If you’re like most new product managers, you’re full of energy and zeal, ready to conquer the world through sheer grit, determination, and lots of sugary treats or booze carts for your developers. (Blair prefers bourbon and gummy worms, whereas Ben goes for ice cream. To each PM, their own.) You’re instantly going to win over your colleagues and ship great product features with all of the passion you bring to your company. Right?

嗯，有点像。热情是成功产品管理的一个重要方面。当您传达愿景并争论以支持该愿景的特定方式为您的路线图提供资源时，热情至关重要。这并不是说你应该站在（或扔）椅子上，或者提高你的声音，但相信你自己的信息并清楚地表明你有多么关心它是关键。当你组织中的每个人都能看到你对你正在努力实现的目标有多么坚定的信念时，他们会更容易团结在你周围，而不是你提出一个冷漠但正确的论点。我们最喜欢的一位同事对产品经理的评价之一是：“当我看到（我们的产品经理）对我们的产品和公司充满热情时，我对我们的未来感到兴奋。”

Well, sort of. Zeal is an important aspect of successful product management. When you’re communicating a vision and arguing to resource your roadmap in a particular way that supports that vision, passion is critical. This isn’t to say that you should be standing on (or throwing) chairs, or raising your voice, but believing in your own message and making it clear how much you care about it is key. When everyone in your organization can see how strongly you believe in whatever you’re trying to get built, it’s much easier for them to rally around you than if you make an emotionless but correct argument. One of our favorite quotes about a product manager from one of his colleagues was, “When I see how passionate [our product manager] is about our product and company, it makes me excited for our future.”

但作为新产品经理，你为团队带来的能量还不够。我们见过新的产品经理——对于产品管理职能、公司或行业本身来说是新手——他们仅仅因为热情而过度扩张，或者缺乏真正有效所需的具体知识，更重要的是，他们都未能发展。这种常见情况下的危险在于，产品经理的影响力需要有选择地运用，而缺乏知识的热情可能会给你的公司、你自己，以及（也许最重要的）其他人对你的信任带来灾难。

But the energy that you bring to your team as a new product manager isn’t enough. We have seen new product managers—new to the product management function, a company, or to an industry itself—who have overextended themselves on passion alone or lacked the concrete knowledge required to be truly effective and, more important, failed to develop either. The danger in this common scenario is that a product manager’s influence needs to be wielded selectively, and zeal without knowledge can lead to disaster, for your company, for you, and, perhaps most important, for the trust others place in you.

想象一下，作为一名新产品经理，您被安排开展一个引人注目的项目，并被告知要实施它。您可以用您的热情召集工程师和销售代表，但您如何知道您正在以正确的方式解决正确的问题？人们很容易认为你的客户一定和你一样，或者你能猜到让他们彻夜难眠的事情，或者你将能够依靠自己的精力推动项目取得成功。有时你可能是对的。请记住，作为“关键影响者”，将热情和知识带给受众的能力至关重要。但如果不付出努力来获取实际知识，不必要的失败就会毁掉你的道路。

Imagine that you, as a new product manager, are put on a highly visible project and told to make it go. You can rally the engineers and the sales reps with your passion, but how do you know that you’re solving the right problem in the right way? It is tempting to assume that your customers must be like you, or that you can guess the things that keep them up at night, or that you will be able to drive the project to success on the back of your own energy. You might be right some of the time. Remember that in your role as “key influencer,” the ability to bring both zeal and knowledge to bear on your audience is critical. But without putting in the work to obtain actual knowledge, unnecessary failures will litter your path.

那么，我们谈论的是哪些知识呢？很高兴你问了。

So, what knowledge are we talking about? Glad you asked.

三类知识

Three Categories of Knowledge

您绝对充满热情（我们希望如此！）。那么，我们应该如何考虑获取交付出色产品所需的知识并确保它们解决实际的客户问题呢？

You’ve got zeal in spades (we hope!). So how should we think about acquiring the knowledge necessary to ship fantastic products and ensure that they solve actual customer problems?

我们建议您将这个问题分为三类来解决：

We propose that you approach this question by dividing it into three categories:

组织知识
Organizational knowledge

这是指了解您的公司的实际运作方式。因为我们需要让合适的人来支持我们推动的每一个重大决策，所以我们需要了解这些人是谁以及他们的动机和动机。不要以为您已经知道所有这些。这种机构知识对于企业软件公司来说往往更为重要，因为这些公司往往规模更大、历史更悠久，而且可能更官僚化。

This refers to understanding how your company really works. Because we need to get the right people behind every major decision we’re pushing, we need to learn who those people are and about their motivations and incentives. Don’t assume that you know all of this already. This kind of institutional knowledge tends to be vastly more important for enterprise software companies, which tend to be bigger, older, and perhaps more bureaucratic.

产品知识
Product knowledge

产品知识意味着了解产品的来龙去脉：它的局限性、它的优点、用户喜欢它的什么以及他们讨厌它的什么。技术人员往往迷恋其产品的所有微小技术细节，但这不一定是我们在这里的意思。相反，更重要的是我们有足够的知识能够理解用户，帮助他们找到问题的解决方案。如果我们不了解产品，就很难理解了解产品的最终用户。

Product knowledge means knowing the ins and outs of your product: its limitations, its benefits, what users love about it, and what they hate about it. Techies tend to fetishize all the minute technical details of their products, and that’s not necessarily what we mean here. Rather, it’s more important that we know enough to be able to empathize with users to help create solutions to their problems. If we don’t understand the product, it’s difficult to empathize with end users who do.

行业知识
Industry knowledge

这可以说是这三个知识领域中最重要的一个，因为它代表了对当今市场或相邻/类似市场中尚未解决（或未充分解决）的客户问题的深入而彻底的理解。正是通过这个领域，我们认识到了最大的市场机会。

This is arguably the most important of these three areas of knowledge because it represents a deep and thorough understanding of customer problems that remain unsolved (or inadequately solved) in your market, or adjacent/similar markets, today. It’s through this domain that we recognize the largest market opportunities.

在接下来的几章中，我们将深入探讨每种类型的知识对产品经理的真正意义。现在，我们先简单解释一下各个领域的知识，并讨论如何获得它们。

Over the next several chapters, we dive deep into what each type of knowledge really means for you as a product manager. For now, let’s just briefly explain each area of knowledge and discuss how we can obtain them.

组织知识

Organizational Knowledge

正如我们所讨论的，初创公司通常很难进入企业软件领域，这意味着占主导地位的企业软件供应商往往是大型组织。因此，您可能是成百上千甚至数十万员工中的一员，他们以自己的方式为公司的成功做出了贡献。即使您已经在公司工作多年，它看起来就像一个无法解析的目录列表迷宫，更不用说您是新员工了。个人如何驾驭这一景观？

As we’ve discussed, it is often very difficult for startups to crack the enterprise software space, meaning that the dominant enterprise software vendors tend to be large organizations. As a result, you might be one of hundreds or thousands or even hundreds of thousands of employees who contribute to your company’s success, each in their own way. It can seem like a maze of directory listings impossible to parse, even if you’ve been at the company for years, let alone if you’re a new employee. How does an individual navigate this landscape?

简单的答案是，企业产品经理（几乎）不单独做任何事。

The simple answer is that an enterprise product manager does (almost) nothing alone.

想要发布一个功能吗？伟大的。至少，您需要协调工程、运营、销售、支持、设计和营销（在许多情况下，需求生成和产品营销）；通常，您还可以添加会计和财务，更不用说经常或多或少独立于总部同行运作的国际团队。

Want to ship a feature? Great. At minimum, you’ll need to align engineering, operations, sales, support, design, and marketing (both demand generation and product marketing, in many cases); often, you can add accounting and finance as well, not to mention the international teams that frequently operate more or less independently from their counterparts at headquarters.

您今天是否有需要解决的关键客户升级问题？好的。谁有答案？文档团队？支持？合作伙伴？您去哪里寻求即时帮助？

Do you have a critical customer escalation that you need resolved today? Okay. Who has the answer? The documentation team? Support? A partner? Where do you go to find immediate help?

我们自己的经验中的一个简单例子说明了最后一种情况。在 Adob​​e，销售或客户团队经常向 Ben 询问时间敏感的问题。很多时候，他并不知道问题的答案。没关系！他不会沮丧地举手，冒不必要的延误甚至失去交易或客户的风险，而是对组织的了解使他总是知道合适的人，或者至少是合适的团队来回答问题。通常，Ben 能够在几分钟内将请求转给最佳响应者。这不仅仅意味着知道有支持团队或文档团队。这意味着知道这些团队中的哪些成员拥有我们需要的信息，哪些成员愿意参与该情况，

A simple example from our own experience illustrates this last scenario. At Adobe, Ben frequently is asked time-sensitive questions from sales or account teams. In many cases, he doesn’t know the answer to the question. And that’s okay! Rather than throw up his hands in frustration and risk unnecessary delay or even losing a deal or customer, his knowledge of the organization is such that he invariably knows the right person, or at least the right team, to answer the question. Much more often than not, Ben is able to steer the request to the best possible respondent within a matter of minutes. It means more than merely knowing that there is a support team or a documentation team. It means knowing which member of those teams has the information we need, which members would be willing to get involved in the situation, and which members are good enough at communicating sometimes tricky answers to potentially introduce them to a customer directly.

在另一个例子中，我们认识的一位产品经理着手改善实施特定软件解决方案的客户体验。与她关系最密切的工程团队没有任何可用资源来解决这个问题。但通过采访具有更多组织知识的同事，她了解到两个位于地球另一端的工程团队，他们的激励和动机恰好与她想要做的事情完全一致。这些团队对于没有任何组织知识的人来说是完全看不见的，但事实证明，它们比她自己的开发团队更适合该项目。

In another example, a product manager we know set out to improve the customer experience around implementing a particular software solution. The engineering team with which she was most closely aligned didn’t have any available resources to work on the problem. But by interviewing colleagues who had a bit more organizational knowledge, she learned of two engineering teams halfway around the world whose incentives and motivations happened to be perfectly aligned with what she was trying to do. These teams, which would have been completely invisible to someone without any organizational knowledge, turned out to be a much better fit to work on the project than her own group of developers.

一个人如何获得组织知识？从很多方面来说，这是我们将讨论的三种类型的知识中最困难的，因为它可能需要时间。它不仅需要了解（通常是国际性的且经常缺乏记录的）组织结构，而且还需要一种社交图谱：谁从事哪些项目，谁知道哪些信息等。更微妙的是，它要求您了解动机和激励：每个人（和团队）想要什么，为什么？如果没有经验，这几乎是不可能学习的，简单明了。组织知识通常是任期的函数。但我们会建议一些简单的策略来加快这一过程。

How does one obtain organizational knowledge? In many ways, this is the most difficult of the three types of knowledge that we will discuss, because it can simply take time. Not only does it require an understanding of the (often international and frequently poorly documented) organizational structure, but it also requires a sort of social graph: who works on what projects, who knows what information, etc. More subtly, it requires you to understand motivations and incentives: what does each individual (and team) want, and why? That can be almost impossible to learn without experience, plain and simple. Organizational knowledge is often a function of tenure. But there are some simple strategies for speeding up the process that we will suggest.

产品知识

Product Knowledge

不言而喻，如果不深入了解产品本身，作为一名产品经理很难真正取得成功。

It should go without saying that it’s difficult to be truly successful as a product manager without a deep knowledge of the product itself.

追求产品知识主要有两个不明显的原因。第一个是同理心。

There are primarily two nonobvious reasons to pursue product knowledge. The first of these is empathy.

让我们再看一下我们刚才提供的示例，其中产品经理正在寻求改善特定产品的实施体验。当她自己实际实现了该产品并完成了她试图改进的步骤之后，她的论点和设计影响力会强大多少？对于工程师、销售代表、营销人员和其他人来说，信任一个从个人经验中了解什么对用户有效、什么无效的产品经理会容易得多吗？

Let’s look again at the example we just presented in which a product manager was seeking to improve the implementation experience for a particular product. How much more powerful would her arguments and design influence be after she had actually implemented the product herself, and gone through the steps that she was trying to improve? How much easier would it be for engineers, sales reps, marketers, and others to trust a product manager who understood from personal experience what works and what doesn’t work for users?

同理心可能是产品经理需要培养的最重要的技能，因为它决定了你认为自己解决了客户/用户问题和实际解决了该问题之间的区别。没有它，您会发现自己偏向于解决自己的问题，而不是客户的问题。培养同理心的最好方法之一就是站在客户的立场上评估你的产品，了解其优点和缺点。

Empathy can be the most important skill for a product manager to develop, because it is what makes the difference between thinking you solved a customer/user problem and actually solving that problem. Without it, you will find yourself skewing toward solving your own problem, not your customer’s problem. Among the very best ways to develop empathy is to put yourself in your customer’s shoes and evaluate your product, learning its benefits and shortcomings.

追求产品知识的第二个原因是信任——具体来说，赢得客户的信任以及开发、销售和营销团队（以及其他许多团队）的信任。

The second reason to pursue product knowledge is trust—specifically, earning the trust of customers and the trust of your development, sales, and marketing teams (among many others).

产品知识并不意味着成为包含产品每一个细节的活百科全书。我们一直发现客户和内部团队都了解这样一个事实：特别是在企业软件中，广泛的定制非常普遍，以至于没有两个部署的行为完全相同，产品经理可能无法获得所有答案。我们经常有客户向我们介绍一两件关于我们自己产品的事情！

Product knowledge does not mean being a walking encyclopedia of every minute detail of your product. We have always found customers and internal teams to be understanding of the fact that, especially in enterprise software, where extensive customization is so common that no two deployments behave exactly alike, product managers might not have all of the answers. We frequently have customers teach us a thing or two about our own products!

话虽如此，客户和内部团队都需要您的帮助才能使用和销售您的产品。当客户看到您深入了解您的产品，并且可以将一般信息和使用他们语言的特定用例联系起来时，他们会变得更愿意并且更有可能向您敞开心扉，与您分享他们的问题和担忧，这可能是最重要的作为产品经理您可以收到的意见。

That having been said, both customers and internal teams need your help in order to use and sell your product, respectively. When customers see that you understand your product deeply, and can relate both general information and specific use cases that speak their language, they become much more willing and likely to open up and share with you their problems and concerns, which is perhaps the most important input you can receive as a product manager.

同样，内部团队为您提供可能很难或不可能实现的市场洞察力任何其他方式：他们在正在进行的交易中看到的趋势，或者在您的领域中涌现出具有吸引力的产品的新竞争对手。您将这些数据点置于上下文中的能力对于在这些团队之间建立信任大有帮助，特别是当它涉及到用准确的产品信息来对抗错误信息时。如果没有产品知识，您可能无法回答“我们的产品也能做到这一点吗？”的问题。或“我应该如何质疑我们的竞争对手的说法？” 当您根据您的产品知识准确回答这些问题时，您就开始赢得团体的信任，这些团体可以成为您未来创造获胜产品的最佳盟友。

Similarly, internal teams provide you with market insight that can be difficult or impossible to achieve any other way: trends they are seeing in the deals they are working on, or new competitors sprouting up in your space with compelling offerings. Your ability to contextualize these data points goes a long way toward building trust among those teams, especially as it relates to combating misinformation with accurate product information. Without product knowledge, you might not be able to answer the questions “Can our product do that, too?” or “How should I interrogate what our competitor is claiming?” When you answer these questions accurately, based on your product knowledge, you begin to win the trust of groups that can become your best allies in creating winning products in the future.

幸运的是，产品知识是所讨论的知识类型中最实用的。您可以通过多种方式获得它（取决于产品的复杂程度），通常需要几周或几个月而不是几年。

Fortunately, product knowledge is the most practical of the types of knowledge discussed. You can obtain it in a number of ways, and (depending on the complexity of your product), often in a matter of weeks or months rather than years.

行业知识

Industry Knowledge

尽管组织知识和产品知识非常有价值，但我们必须承认，如果我们必须选择一种知识才能在产品管理方面取得成功，我们会选择行业知识。在这三种类型中，它与交付成功产品以增加公司收入的能力最直接相关。

Although organizational knowledge and product knowledge are tremendously valuable, we have to admit that if we had to pick one type of knowledge to be successful in product management, we’d pick industry knowledge. Of the three types, it is most directly associated with the ability to deliver successful products that will grow your company’s revenue.

行业知识分为几个类别，但一般来说，我们的意思是对推动您竞争的市场中的购买决策的趋势、当前（和未来！）客户问题的新兴解决方案有微妙和多方面的理解，以及这些客户问题如何因客户群中的行业而异。

Industry knowledge breaks down into a few categories, but generally we mean having a subtle and multifaceted understanding of the trends that drive buying decisions in the marketplace where you compete, the up-and-coming solutions to current (and future!) customer problems, and how those customer problems vary by industry in your customer base.

简而言之：了解客户面临的问题，并了解为什么这些问题是需要解决的有价值的问题。客户问题是产品管理的“货币”。你越了解它们，你就越富有。

In short: know the problems your customers are facing, and know why they are valuable problems to solve. Customer problems are the “currency” of product management. The better you understand them, the richer you are.

为了说明市场知识的重要性，您只需查看产品待办事项即可。如果您已经拥有一个，我们敢打赌，它的功能远远超出您可以利用的时间、工程资源、营销资源等所能解决的问题。如果您还没有，想象一下包含 200 个产品功能或流程改进的列表，所有这些都是有价值的。现在想象一下，有人问公司应该关注其中哪五个功能。

To illustrate the importance of market knowledge, you need look only as far as a product backlog. If you have one already, we’ll bet that it has far more on it than you can possibly solve with the time, engineering resources, marketing resources, and so on available to you. If you do not have one yet, imagine a list of 200 product features or process improvements, all of which are valuable. Now imagine being asked on which five of those features the company should focus.

如果您了解推动购买决策的因素以及让客户的高管彻夜难眠的问题，那么优先处理积压的订单就不会像挑选您最喜欢的婴儿那样重要；您可以选择最喜欢的产品。你需要做出一些削减，并且可能有一些大致相同的选择，以及一些需要考虑的下行权衡，但这是可以做到的。没有市场知识，你还不如在飞镖靶上扔飞镖。（请记住在会议结束后保留​​波本威士忌。）

If you understand what is driving purchase decisions and what problems keep your customers’ C-suites up at night, prioritizing that backlog won’t be as much like picking which baby you love the most; you’ll need to make some cuts, and there might be some choices that are roughly equivalent, as well as some downrange trade-offs to consider, but it can be done. Without market knowledge, you may as well throw darts at a dartboard. (Just remember to keep the bourbon for after that meeting, please.)

作为产品经理，行业知识使您能够编写市场需求文档（MRD），其中规定产品愿景，阐述产品战略的核心原则，并从根本上回答“我们经营的市场对我们有何要求才能发展业务？”的问题。

Industry knowledge is what allows you, as a product manager, to write a Market Requirements Document (MRD), which sets the vision for your product, lays out the core tenets of the product strategy, and essentially answers the question “What is the market in which we operate going to require of us in order for us to grow our business?”

也许因为它是本章讨论的三种类型的知识中最具战略意义的，所以对于那些刚进入特定市场的人来说，获得它也可能是最困难和最耗时的。（如果您从同一行业内晋升到产品管理职位，您可能会发现这比之前在非常不同的领域担任过产品经理的人更容易。）在涵盖行业知识的第 7 章中，我们讨论了您应该如何开始使用它，以及我们希望一开始就知道的一些事情。

Perhaps because it is the most strategic of the three types of knowledge discussed in this chapter, it can also be the most difficult and time-consuming to obtain for those who are new to the given market. (If you are moving into a product management role from within the same industry, you might find this easier than someone who has been a product manager previously but in a very different space.) In Chapter 7, which covers industry knowledge, we talk about how you should get started on it, as well as several things that we wish we’d have known at the beginning.

您可能听说过，产品管理主要是一个“软技能”职位。在所需的众多软技能中，热情和知识是最基本的两项。如果没有这两者，产品经理将很难影响他独特的地位来实施的变革。从某种程度上来说，激情是无法教授的东西。如果您对所指导的业务不感兴趣，您可能想寻找新业务。但是，您可以获得知识。

You might have heard it said that product management is mostly a “soft skills” position. Among the many soft skills required, passion and knowledge are two of the most fundamental. Without both, a product manager will be hard pressed to influence the kind of change that he is uniquely positioned to enact. To some extent, passion is something that is impossible to teach. If you’re not excited about the business you are guiding, you might want to find a new business. You can, however, obtain knowledge.

从沟通开始

It Starts with Communication

产品经理最终负责将不同的团队聚集在一起，让他们接受她的产品愿景，并在产品或功能发布之前和之后保持团队（通常还有客户）保持一致。确保这个过程尽可能顺利进行，通常在大型和复杂的组织中，需要良好的（不仅仅是良好的）沟通。尽管作为产品经理你需要培养很多技能，但与沟通想法相关的技能将是你最有价值的技能之一；事实上，沟通可能是企业产品管理成功的最重要因素。由于在此类软件公司中良好的沟通可能更具挑战性，因此在本节中，我们将为您提供一些指导来帮助您入门。

The product manager is ultimately responsible for bringing disparate teams together, getting them bought into her product vision, and keeping teams (and often customers) aligned both before and after the release of a product or feature. Ensuring that this process goes as smoothly as possible, often in large and complex organizations, requires great (not just good) communication. Although there are many skills you will want to develop as a product manager, those related to communicating ideas will be among your most valuable; in fact, communication might be the most important factor leading to success in enterprise product management. And because great communication can be a bit more challenging in this type of software company, in this section, we give you some guidance to help you to get started.

“沟通”一词可以指各种不同的事物。我们并不是在狭隘地谈论沟通，例如编写连贯的电子邮件或向客户执行像样的路线图演示的能力，尽管这些都是沟通的一部分。更广泛地说，我们指的是通过不同的媒介，以不同的方式向不同职能受众（开发团队、销售团队、营销团队、客户、行业分析师等）清晰地传达困难概念的能力。

The term “communication” can mean all kinds of different things. We are not talking about communication narrowly, such as the ability to write a coherent email or to execute a decent roadmap presentation to a customer, although those are both part of it. More broadly, we mean the ability to communicate difficult concepts clearly in different ways to different functional audiences (development teams, sales teams, marketing teams, customers, industry analysts, etc.) via different mediums.

产品管理位于十几个不同的内部团队以及客户、合作伙伴和其他外部实体之间的十字路口。没有人比您更适合将这些团队聚集在一起以实现伟大目标。但每个群体（包括产品管理本身！）都有自己的激励、目标、希望、恐惧、习惯、传统和流程。这意味着并非每个群体都会以相同的方式对相同的刺激做出反应。

Product management sits at the crossroads between a dozen different internal teams as well as customers, partners, and other external entities. Nobody is better positioned than you are to bring these teams together to achieve something great. But each of these groups (including product management itself!) has its own incentives, goals, hopes, fears, habits, traditions, and processes. This means that not every group responds to the same stimulus in the same way.

假设您想让销售和开发团队接受您为产品设定的愿景。大多数企业销售人员的薪酬方式通常专注于短期预订目标，按季或按年生活。（顺便说一句，这实际上是一件好事。）您的产品愿景对他们来说很重要，主要是因为它让潜在客户对他们与您公司的未来关系感到兴奋；但只要你有一些东西，实现这一使命有多困难就不那么重要了在他们可以谈论的路线图上。伟大的工程师（那些你真正需要支持你的愿景的人）必然是更务实的思想家，他们会立即想知道如何在合理的时间内从 A 点到达 Z 点。您的愿景对他们很重要，因为它决定了他们在实现该愿景的过程中如何解决问题，并且当他们相信该愿景是现实的时，他们会将对其的理解应用于他们解决的每个问题。

Suppose that you want to get your sales and development teams to buy into the vision that you’re setting for your product. The way most enterprise salespeople are compensated, they are typically focused on short-term bookings objectives, living quarter to quarter or year to year. (And, by the way, this is actually a good thing.) Your product vision matters to them primarily because it’s what gets prospects excited about their future relationship with your company; but how difficult it will be to achieve that mission matters much less, provided you have something on the roadmap that they can talk about. Great engineers (the ones you really need to buy in to your vision) are, by necessity, more pragmatic thinkers who will immediately wonder how to get from point A to point Z in a reasonable timeframe. Your vision matters to them because it frames how they will solve problems along the way toward achieving that vision, and when they believe the vision is realistic, they will apply their understanding of it to every problem that they solve.

如果您向销售团队传达这一愿景，您通常会用最广泛的术语和简洁的陈述来谈论它，这些术语听起来令人惊叹，但为他们敞开了大门，让他们可以随心所欲地解释它。您可能会谈论这一愿景是多么独特，以及您的公司如何是唯一有能力实现这一愿景的公司。你甚至可以点出特定的竞争对手，并解释为什么你的愿景会将他们送入坟墓。

If you are communicating this vision to your sales team, you will often do it by talking about it in the broadest possible terms and pithy statements that sound amazing but leave the door open for them to explain it however they want. You will likely talk about how unique this vision is and how your company is the only one capable of achieving it. You might even call out specific competitors and explain why your vision will put them in their graves.

如果您向开发团队传达相同的愿景，您可能会将其归结为具体细节：我们将如何实现愿景，以及我们希望何时到达沿途的检查点。您的开发团队可能不太关心竞争格局（他们也不应该；这对他们来说几乎没有什么好处），或者为什么您的公司具有独特的优势来实现这一愿景。他们关心这是正确的事情，它解决了一个有趣的问题，并且它有意义。

If you’re communicating that same vision to the development team, you will likely boil it down to specifics: how we are going to achieve the vision, and when we are hoping to reach checkpoints along the path. Your development team probably doesn’t care that much about the competitive landscape (nor should they; it can benefit them very little), or why your company is uniquely positioned to make this vision reality. They care that it is the right thing to do, that it solves an interesting problem, and that it makes sense.

您进行这些对话（以及其他类似对话）的方式通常会完全不同，而与您的销售代表产生共鸣的内容对于您的工程师来说可能是梵文（反之亦然）。您从每个小组得到的问题也将反映该小组的经验、知识、目标、偏见、偏好等。

The way you have these conversations (and others like these) will often be completely different, and what resonates with your sales reps can be Sanskrit to your engineers (and vice versa). The questions you get from each group will also reflect that group’s experience, knowledge, goals, biases, preferences, and so on.

请注意，这两种情况下的核心信息相同，但不同受众传达信息的方式可能截然不同。但是，当然，如果没有这些（和其他）群体的协调和支持，你就不可能成功。这主要取决于产品管理（在其他群体的帮助下，如产品营销）来创建这种协调。因此，您需要善于根据受众定制信息。

Note that it’s the same core message in both cases, but the way you convey the message might be wildly different from one audience to the next. But, of course, you cannot succeed without these (and other) groups being aligned and bought in. And it’s primarily up to product management (with the help of other groups, like product marketing) to create that alignment. Thus, you need to become great at tailoring the message to the audience.

在本书中，我们将回顾与整个组织中的不同团队进行沟通的最佳实践：开发、营销、销售、领导力等等，因为沟通对于任何成功的产品经理来说都是一项至关重要的技能。但让我们首先为最重要的群体：客户提供一些快速提示。

Throughout this book, we return to best practices for communicating with different teams throughout your organization: development, marketing, sales, leadership, and more, because communication is such a vital skill to any successful product manager. But let’s begin with some quick tips for the group that matters most: customers.

沟通不仅仅适用于内部团队！作为产品经理，您应该花费大量时间直接与客户交谈（当我们说“客户”时，我们也将潜在客户和以前的客户包括在该组中）。与他们的沟通有所不同，原因很明显：他们不属于您的公司，并且有自己截然不同的激励、动机和观点。事实上，您的客户沟通范围非常广泛，我们无法涵盖您可能在客户“面前”需要找出正确的说话和倾听方式的所有可能情况。但这里有一些一般准则来指导您如何处理这些交互：

Communication isn’t just for internal teams! As a product manager, you should be spending a considerable amount of time speaking directly with customers (and when we say “customer,” we include prospects and former customers in this group, as well). Communicating with them is different for obvious reasons: they aren’t part of your company and have their own very different incentives, motivations, and perspectives. In fact, the scope of your customer communications is so broad that we cannot cover all of the possible situations in which you might be “in front of” customers needing to figure out the right way to speak and listen. But here are some general guidelines to frame how you approach these interactions:

适应不同的行业
Become comfortable with different industries

与客户交谈时，您可以做的最好的事情之一就是至少传达对他们在行业中面临的挑战有基本的了解。您的软件可能针对特定行业，例如金融服务，这使得这变得更容易一些（尽管每个行业都有子行业），但如果您制作通用软件，请熟悉每个行业的市场驱动因素、挑战和关键用例将帮助客户相信您在设计和交付软件时考虑到了他们的需求。它还可以帮助他们了解您可能与他们分享的内容的价值。让出版商考虑如何应用您讲述的关于电子商务品牌的故事只会给价值认可造成障碍。您不需要成为任何一个行业的真正思想领袖，但会说这种语言将大大有助于建立信任。

One of the best things you can do when speaking with a customer is convey at least a basic understanding of the challenges facing them in their industry. Your software might be targeted at a specific industry such as financial services, which makes this a bit easier (although every industry has subindustries within it), but if you make general-purpose software, familiarizing yourself with each industry’s market drivers, challenges, and key use cases will help customers trust that you have their needs in mind as you are designing and shipping software. It also helps them grasp the value of what you might be sharing with them. Making a publisher think about how to apply a story you tell about an ecommerce brand only creates a barrier to value recognition. You don’t need to be a true thought leader in any one industry, but speaking the language will go a long way toward building trust.

你会高估你的客户对你公司的了解程度
You will overestimate how much your customer understands your company

请记住，大多数软件公司从外部看起来都很健康。他们讲述客户正在做的令人惊奇的事情的故事，并在软件发布时发布新闻稿。从你坐的地方，你可能只能看到功能失调和腐烂，但你的顾客无法看到“香肠是如何制作的”，除非你告诉他们。即使您感到沮丧和绝望，也要在与客户的沟通中表达乐观和信心。

Remember that most software companies look healthy from the outside. They tell stories of amazing things that their customers are doing, and publish press releases when software ships. From where you sit, you might see nothing but dysfunction and decay, but your customers cannot see “how the sausage gets made” unless you tell them. Even when you are feeling discouraged and desperate, convey optimism and confidence in your communications with customers.

永远不要责怪其他内部团队
Never blame another internal team

同样，有时可能会出现问题（产品错误、错过发货日期、意外限制等），并且您很想按照您所看到的方式向客户展示它。透明度是件好事——事实上，它可能是你在与客户互动时能做的最好的事情之一——但如果把让客户感到沮丧的事情归咎于另一个内部团队则不然。它向客户表明，您的公司并不团结，并且互相攻击，而不是齐心协力为您的客户做最好的事情。即使另一个人或团队确实有过错，向客户展示统一战线也意味着要么拒绝归咎于他人，要么创造性地为可能不是你的错的事情“囤积责任”。

Along those same lines, there might be times when something goes wrong (a product bug, a missed ship date, an unexpected limitation, etc.) and you are tempted to lay it out for the customer the way you see it. Transparency is good—in fact, it can be one of the best things you can do in your interactions with customers—but blaming another internal team for whatever is frustrating the customer is not. It suggests to the customer that your company is not united and snipes at one another rather than coming together to do what is best for your clients. Even when another person or team really is at fault, presenting a united front to the customer means either refusing to assign blame or creatively “hoarding blame” for something that might not have been your fault.

诚实并坦率地了解您产品的局限性
Be honest and forthright about your product’s limitations

这听起来可能违反直觉。我们希望客户购买我们的产品，不是吗？那我们为什么要谈论限制呢？企业客户希望有一个值得信赖的合作伙伴。销售人员有一个明显的议程，那就是销售软件。您有机会将自己展现为开放的、不投币的、关注客户长期最佳利益的人。这里要记住的是，无论如何，您的客户很可能会发现您产品的局限性；一种不成熟（但常见）的销售方法是，销售代表会说他早在销售发生之前就已经预订了销售。如果没有其他人愿意这样做，您就需要对长期关系负责。

This one might sound counterintuitive; we want the customer to buy the product, don’t we? Then why would we talk about limitations? Enterprise customers want a partner in whom they can trust. Salespeople have an obvious agenda, which is to sell software. You have an opportunity to represent yourself as someone who is open, who isn’t coin-operated, and who is looking out for the customer’s long-term best interest. The thing to remember here is that your customer is likely to find out your product’s limitations anyway; an immature (but common) approach to sales would be for the rep to say that he will have booked the sale long before that happens. If nobody else is going to do it, you need to be responsible for the long-term relationship. Being clear and straightforward about what you produce adds to your credibility and sets the stage for your customers to be successful with your product.

概括

Summary

所有优秀的产品经理都会对自己的角色充满热情，但最成功的产品经理是那些能够快速发展三个知识领域的人：组织、产品和行业。这三个领域涵盖了对我们工作的公司、我们制造和销售的产品以及我们销售的行业的广泛理解。其中一些比其他更容易开发，对成功也更关键，但真正的产品成功在于这三者的融合。接下来的几章将分别探讨每个领域。

All good product managers bring enthusiasm into their roles, but the most successful ones are those who manage to quickly develop three domains of knowledge: organizational, product, and industry. These three domains encompass a wide range of understanding about the companies we work in, the products we build and sell, and the industries into which we sell. Some of these are easier to develop and more critical to success than others, but it is at the confluence of all three that true product success lies. The next several chapters explore each area individually.

项目经理简介

姓名：奥布里·鲁普

Name: Aubrey Rupp

职位： IBM 高级产品经理

Title: Senior Offering Manager, IBM

您是如何开始产品管理的？

How did you get started in product management?

我的背景是商业和技术分析咨询。经过多年实施产品并帮助客户克服产品和业务挑战后，我想成为解决方案方面的一部分。通过进入产品管理，我决定应用我的现场经验和客户用例为客户制定解决方案，改进我们的产品并推动我们组织内的业务影响。小时候，我一直喜欢数学问题，尤其是困难的问题，因为a）只要有适当的注意力和理解力就可以解决这些问题，b）正确解决问题所带来的欣快感。产品管理没有太大不同。更少的二次方程，但仍然找到解决问题的正确方法，并且如果你做对了，就会有成功的感觉。

My background was in business and technical analytics consulting. After years of implementing products and helping customers overcome product and business challenges, I wanted to become part of the solution side. By getting into product management, I decided I could apply my field experience and customer use cases to craft solutions for customers, to improve our products and drive business impact within our organization. As a kid, I always loved math problems, especially the hard ones, because a) they were solvable with the right level of focus and understanding, and b) the euphoric feeling that comes with getting it right. Product management isn’t much different. Fewer quadratic equations, but still finding the right approach to solving the problem and the feeling of success if you get it right.

您工作中最难学习的部分是什么？

What have been the most difficult parts of your job to learn?

让合适的用户参与进来，并收集适当的用户对某个想法的反馈。人们很容易认为大多数用户都像我一样工作和思考。当提出问题的解决方案时，根据我认为我所知道的来实施是很容易的。困难的部分是确保功能和解决方案尽早（早在代码编写之前）就吸引用户的注意，以便我们可以确保我们正在解决正确的问题并正确地解决它。平衡用户和市场的需求。了解两者并充分了解它们很重要。在理想的世界中，这两个人想要同样的东西，但事情并不总是这样。努力推动市场发展，同时与客户的需求保持同步是一场持久战。过于重视某一领域可能会阻碍市场增长，而其他方面太多可能会让客户感到沮丧。这是关于寻找平衡。

Getting the right users involved and collecting the appropriate user feedback on an idea. It’s very easy to think that most users work and think like I do. When coming up with a solution to a problem, it’s easy to just implement based on what I think I know. The hard part is making sure that features and solutions get users’ eyes on them early—long before the code is written—so that we can be sure we are solving the right problem and solving it correctly. Balancing the needs of the users and the market. It’s important to know both, and know them well. In an ideal world, these two want the same thing, but it doesn’t always work out that way. Trying to advance the market while staying in sync with the needs of the customers is a constant battle. Too much emphasis in one area can stall market growth, and too much in the other can create frustrated customers. It’s about finding balance.

您认为有哪些特定背景对企业 PM 特别有价值吗？

Are there particular backgrounds you think are especially valuable for enterprise PMs?

作为企业PM，深入了解产品、客户、行业至关重要。来自实施和业务咨询的背景，我相信深厚的产品知识可以成为产品管理成功的基石。一旦担任产品经理角色，一个人就可以学习如何编写用户故事、敏捷或如何运行 Scrum。您从使用产品或帮助客户解决产品问题中获得的深入知识可以真正推动您的职业生涯。凭借客户关系和丰富的用例知识进入产品管理可以加快您将产品提升到新水平的能力。需要注意的是，过多关注客户可能会导致您忽视整体战略计划，因此，理解这种平衡以及平衡战略和战术的需要至关重要。无论背景如何，对行业的热情是任何产品经理的重要特质。

As an enterprise PM, it’s crucial to have deep knowledge of the product, of the customer, and of the industry. Coming from a background of implementation and business consulting, I believe that deep product knowledge can be a cornerstone of success in product management. Once in the product manager role, a person can learn how to write a user story, Agile, or how to run a scrum. The in-depth knowledge that you get from using a product or helping a customer solve a problem with your product can really jumpstart your career. Coming into product management with customer relationships and strong knowledge of use cases can accelerate your ability to take your product to the next level. One word of caution—too much customer focus can cause you to take your eye off of the big picture strategic initiatives, so understanding this balance and need to balance strategic and tactical is crucial. Regardless of background, passion for the industry is an important characteristic of any product manager.

如果你不做 PM，你会在科技行业做什么？

What would you do in tech if you weren’t in PM?

如果我不是企业产品经理，我会考虑进入用户体验设计。不是因为我是一名出色的设计师，而是因为确定用户体验是任何产品成功的关键部分。

If I weren’t an enterprise product manager, I’d consider going into user experience design. Not because I’m a strong designer, but because nailing the user experience is a key part of making any product successful.

如果我采取完全不同的方法，我会从公司软件开发转向代理机构的客户战略。这将使我有机会与各种形状和规模的许多不同客户互动，并直接与他们合作以实现业务成果。我希望有机会为个别问题制定解决方案，而不是试图解决如此大规模的问题。

If I were to take a completely different approach, I’d move away from corporate software development and into customer strategy at an agency. This would give me the opportunity to engage with many different customers of all shapes and sizes and work with them directly to achieve business results. I’d like the opportunity to craft solutions to individual problems instead of trying to solve at such a massive level.

第 4 章组织知识

Chapter 4. Organizational Knowledge

企业产品经理与一系列令人眼花缭乱的团队和角色一起工作，从工程和设计到销售和营销（等等！）。了解如何在企业软件环境中让每个团队发挥最佳工作效果需要实践，但这是产品管理成功之路上的一项关键技能。

Enterprise product managers work with a dizzying array of teams and roles, from engineering and design to sales and marketing (and more!). Knowing how to get the best work out of each group in an enterprise software context takes practice, but is a key skill on the path to product management success.

如果您演奏任何类型的乐器，您就会知道独奏与与其他人演奏完全不同。尽管一些令人惊叹的音乐只能在无伴奏的情况下演奏，但弦乐三重奏或四重奏的作品确实具有魔力。在三、四人的小型室内乐团中，演奏者的个人差异非常重要。每个成员都需要确切地知道其他音乐家在做什么以及他们演奏方式上的微小变化，以便根据最细微的提示调整自己的音调、音量或节奏。

If you play any sort of musical instrument, you already know that playing solo is an entirely different ball game than playing with other people. Although some amazing music was only ever meant to be played unaccompanied, pieces for a string trio or quartet can be positively magical. In a small chamber ensemble of three or four, personal player differences matter tremendously. Each member needs to know exactly what the other musicians are doing and the minute variations in how they tend to play in order to adjust their own tone, volume, or tempo at the slightest cue.

尽管四重奏可能很珍贵，但没有一个四重奏可以像一个完整的管弦乐队那样传达伟大交响曲的威严。在管弦乐环境中，个人犯错的余地更大（除非你是第一任主席，在这种情况下，去练习）。然而，代价是优秀的管弦乐演奏者也需要跟踪更多的部分。这些演奏者需要知道第一小提琴、中提琴、打击乐或管乐在接下来的几个小节中正在做什么，以便他们可以准备自己的部分或入口。他们必须调整音量以适应大提琴的声音（当然，大提琴是任何管弦乐队的支柱1）。如果你在定音鼓的强音之前加入四分音符，那么……那将是一个尴尬的夜晚。

Yet precious as it might be, no quartet can ever do what a full orchestra can to convey the majesty of a great symphony. In an orchestral setting, individuals have a bit more margin for error (unless you’re first chair—in which case, go practice). Yet the trade-off is that a good orchestral player needs to keep track of many more parts, too. These players need to know what the first violins, violas, percussion, or winds are doing in the next few measures so that they can prepare their part or entrance. They must adjust their volume to account for the cellos (who are, of course, the backbone of any orchestra1). If you come in a quarter note before the timpani at a forte, well…that’s going to be an embarrassing night.

这与成熟软件公司的产品管理有很多相似之处。在最好的情况下，一个全速运转并完美执行的软件组织就像一个世界级的乐团，如柏林爱乐乐团或芝加哥交响乐团，其许多不同的部分相互协调和支持。产品管理（就像大提琴部分一样）是确保整个组织保持一致的关键职能——如果不是朝着共同的目标，那么至少是朝着相互关联和支持的目标迈进。

There are many parallels here to product management in a mature software company. At its best, a software organization that is firing on all cylinders and executing perfectly closely resembles a world-class ensemble like the Berlin Philharmonic or Chicago Symphony Orchestra, whose many different parts harmonize and support one another. Product management (just like the cello section) is a critical function in making sure this entire organization is aligned—if not toward a common goal, then at least toward mutually interlocking and supportive ends.

与五个利益相关者的日常协作尤其构成了企业产品管理的必要条件：开发、设计、管理、营销和销售。简而言之，与这五类人建立有效且增值的工作关系将决定你作为产品经理的成功或失败。在接下来的几个部分中，我们将深入研究您与每个团队合作以使您的产品取得成功所需的组织知识。在每个部分中，我们还分享了一些技巧，以帮助您更有效地与这些群体进行沟通。

Day-to-day collaboration with five stakeholders in particular make up a sina qua non of enterprise product management: development, design, executives, marketing, and sales. Simply put, developing effective and value-adding working relationships with these five groups of people will make or break your success as a product manager. Over the next several sections, we delve into the organizational knowledge you need to work with each of these teams to make your product successful. In each section, we also share some tips to help you communicate more effectively with these groups.

开发/工程

Development/Engineering

可以说，组织中没有比产品管理之间更重要的工作关系了。和开发/工程。（注：为了简洁起见，从现在开始，我们将这个组简单地称为“开发”。）开发的工作是构建事物；构建事物是开发的工作。产品管理的工作就是向开发人员解释要构建什么。两者缺一则要么无用，要么盲目。

There is arguably no working relationship more important in the organization than between product management and development/engineering. (Note: in the interest of brevity, we refer to this group simply as “development” from here on out.) It is development’s job to build the thing; it is product management’s job to explain to development what to build. One without the other is either useless or flying blind.

开发团队的独立性往往会根据组织的规模和成熟度而有很大差异。例如，一家小型初创公司可能根本没有产品管理功能，只有一个或少数开发人员。在这种情况下，首席执行官、首席技术官或首席开发人员实际上是产品经理。然而，随着公司的发展，软件产品的复杂性往往会非线性增加，要求开发人员更加关注解决方案的设计和维护，而不是产品管理介入解决的庞大业务、市场和客户需求。 。

The independence of development teams tends to vary greatly depending on the size and maturity of the organization. A small startup, for example, might have no product management function at all, and just one or a handful of developers. The CEO or CTO or head developer is effectively the product manager in this case. As the company grows, however, the sophistication of the software product tends to increase nonlinearly, requiring developers to be much more focused on engineering and maintaining the solution and less on the sprawling business, market, and customer demands that product management steps in to address.

因此，在从初创类别进入成长阶段的成长型公司中，定义产品管理和开发之间的角色和职责应该有助于使后者的工作更轻松、更专注，并更好地与保持高水平的生产力保持一致。这种转变需要两个团队之间高度信任——任何人最不希望发生的就是地盘和责任方面的冲突。在这种情况下，一种优秀且常见的解决方案是从公司内部晋升到产品管理。

Thus, in growing companies that have emerged from the startup category and graduated into a growth stage, defining roles and responsibilities between product management and development should help make the latter’s job easier, more focused, and better aligned with maintaining a high level of productivity. This transition requires a lot of trust between both teams—the last thing anyone wants is conflicts over turf and responsibilities. One excellent and frequent solution in this case is to promote to product management from within the company.

更成熟的公司通常已经为产品管理和开发如何协同工作建立了明确的标准操作程序。这些通常依赖于软件开发的通用范例，例如敏捷/Scrum 或瀑布模型。我们不打算在这里深入探讨这些框架的优缺点——不仅在其他地方已经有大量的文章讨论它们，而且不同模型的适用性高度依赖于该领域团队更了解的上下文细节比我们多。可以说，我们相信开发和产品管理已经针对其特定情况明智地选择了最佳的软件开发流程。尽管如此，强烈建议不熟悉这些框架的新产品经理至少熟悉它们。

More mature companies have typically established a clear standard operating procedure for how product management and development work together. These will often rely on a common paradigm for software development like Agile/Scrum or a Waterfall model. We’re not going to delve into the pros and cons of these frameworks here—not only have oceans of ink already been spilled debating them elsewhere, but the applicability of different models is highly dependent on contextual specifics that teams in the field know much better than we do. Suffice to say, we trust that development and product management have already wisely chosen the best software development process for their particular situation. Nevertheless, new product managers who aren’t familiar with these frameworks already are strongly advised to become acquainted with them, at least.

无论您使用哪种框架，您都需要从一个基本概念开始，了解您想要构建什么以及您想要达到的目标。在第五章中，我们讨论如何利用市场和客户的意见来构建产品愿景和战略；现在，我们将进入将该战略付诸行动的实质部分。橡胶，遇见道路。

No matter which framework you use, you’ll need to begin with a basic idea of what you want to build and where you want to get to. In Chapter 5, we discuss how to use market and customer input to build a product vision and strategy; for now, we get into the nitty-gritty part of putting that strategy into action. Rubber, meet road.

与您的开发经理一起构建工作

Structuring Work with Your Development Manager

为了清晰地确定工作范围和计划，我们使用史诗、故事和需求等敏捷概念，这些概念在企业软件即服务 (SaaS) 领域中相当标准。史诗是故事的一个大集合，应该以某种有意义的方式代表实现更广泛的产品愿景的封装的实质性进展，而故事通常构成完成史诗的渐进步骤。在冲刺计划开始时，您应该与您的开发团队坐下来仔细研究相关的史诗，并确保团队的每个成员都了解它对您的客户所代表的价值（并且，如果适用的话，您的用户也是如此）。只有这样，您才能开始将史诗分解为单独的故事以及构成每个故事的要求。

To scope and plan work clearly, we use the Agile concepts of epics, stories, and requirements, which are fairly standard in the enterprise Software as a Service (SaaS) world. An epic is one large collection of stories which should, in some meaningful way, represent encapsulated, material progress toward your broader product vision, whereas stories often constitute incremental steps toward completion of an epic. At the beginning of sprint planning, you should sit down with your development team(s) to go over the epic(s) in question and make sure each member of the team understands the value it represents to your customers (and, if applicable, your users, too). Only then can you begin the process of decomposing that epic into individual stories, and the requirements that might make up each one.

在我们开始分配这些需求之前，让我们先谈谈实际执行此操作的人：您的开发经理。

Before we get to divvying up those requirements, let’s talk for a moment about the person who actually does that: your development manager.

开发经理可以是指定的高级开发人员，或者在更成熟的团队中，可以是具有特定能力并专注于工程项目管理的人员。一个强大的开发经理对于您的开发团队和整个公司来说是多么重要的资产，这一点我们再怎么强调也不为过。我们合作过的最优秀的开发经理拥有一些高度专业化的技能：

The development manager can either be a designated senior developer or, in more mature teams, a person with a specific competence and sole focus on engineering project management. We cannot stress strongly enough how great an asset a strong development manager can be for your development team and your company as a whole. The best development managers we’ve worked with provide a few highly specialized skills:

  • 他们深入了解团队中每个开发人员的技术优势和劣势，这使他们能够更有效地分配和组织要完成的工作。

  • They intimately understand the technical strengths and weaknesses of each individual developer on their team, which allows them to more effectively assign and structure work to be done.

  • 经验使他们能够准确估计完成积压工作所需的工作量（即“故事点”）。

  • Experience allows them to accurately estimate the level of effort (i.e., “story points”) required to complete work on the backlog.

  • 他们可以尽早就预期或遇到的问题提出警告或危险信号，并帮助集思广益解决方案。

  • They can raise caution or red flags early about problems anticipated or encountered, and help brainstorm workarounds.

作为团队特定知识的渠道，您的开发经理可以在许多冲刺过程中进行有效的规划。通过准确的故事点估计和工作记录，您可以得出更好的速度估计（基本上是在给定时间范围内可以完成多少工作的衡量标准），从而随着时间的推移实现流程改进。

As a conduit of team-specific knowledge, your development manager makes effective planning possible over the course of many sprints. With accurate story point estimates and work logging, you can derive better velocity estimates—basically, a measure of how much work can be completed within a given timeframe—which enable process improvements as time goes on.

在分配需求时，请遵循开发经理的判断。产品经理通常更愿意回答开发人员针对特定需求提出的一次性问题（例如，“此列表应该显示完整的描述还是摘录？”），而不是深入了解有关技术细节的细节。对于前开发人员产品经理来说，保持这种距离可能很困难，但最终可以使开发工作更加高效。

When it comes to assigning requirements, defer to your development manager’s judgment. Product managers are typically more helpful in answering developers’ one-off questions that arise about specific requirements (e.g., “Should this list show full descriptions, or excerpts?”) than in getting deeply involved in details about the technical specifics. This distance can be difficult for ex-developer product managers to keep, but ultimately allows development to be more efficient at its job.

产品经理应该具备怎样的技术能力？

这触及了产品管理界的一个常见争论：产品经理到底应该具备怎样的技术水平？正如我们之前提到的，我们的观点是，企业软件中的产品管理是一个可操作的、跨职能的角色，技术知识只是其中的一部分，而不是最重要的。即使是产品经理对于经验丰富的开发人员来说，大多数企业软件都涉及庞大、复杂的代码库，通常带有参差不齐或不完整的内部文档，很少有人（如果有的话）能够完全理解其全部内容。为了在这个世界中进行探索，开发人员需要小心翼翼地行事，并通过日复一日地生活在该代码库中来了解他正在做的事情。这并不能描述大多数产品经理，这就是为什么我们建议大多数产品经理不应该接触代码。当然，某些类型的产品经理角色可能适合直接贡献代码库，但根据我们的经验，这种情况很少见。

This touches on a common debate in product management circles: just how technical should product managers be? As we’ve mentioned before, our view is that product management in enterprise software is an operational, cross-functional role, of which technical know-how is only one part, and not the most vital. Even if the product manager is an experienced developer, most enterprise software involves sprawling, intricate code bases, often with spotty or incomplete internal documentation that few, if any, individuals fully understand in its entirety. To go mucking around in that world, a developer needs to tread gingerly and possess the understanding of what he’s doing that comes from living in that code base day in and day out. That does not describe most product managers, which is why our recommendation is that most product managers should not be touching code. Of course, there can be certain types of product manager roles for which direct code base contributions are appropriate, but in our experience, those are few and far between.

当事情没有按计划进行时该怎么办

What to Do When Things Don’t Go According to Plan

当您听到“工程”这个词时，有些人可能会想到蒙哥马利·斯科特（“斯科蒂”）或乔迪·拉福吉，他们都是来自《星际迷航》宇宙的工程师。在虚构的企业号航空母舰上，工程人员的工作通常是评估风险，采取保守态度，并在柯克船长和皮卡德船长（分别）向他们提出不可能的要求时说不，就像产品管理人员经常做的那样。似乎在每一集或每部电影中，船长都会深思熟虑地反驳工程人员的担忧，而工程人员则会创造奇迹。工程师和船长通力合作，挽救了局面。

When you hear the word “engineering,” some of you might think of Montgomery Scott (“Scotty”) or Geordi LaForge, both engineers from the Star Trek universe. On the fictional USS Enterprise, Engineering’s job was often to assess risks, play it conservative, and say no when Captains Kirk and Picard (respectively)—much like product management often does—asked them for the impossible. Seemingly in every episode or film, the captain would thoughtfully push back on engineering’s concerns, and engineering would pull a miracle out of its hat. Working cooperatively, engineering and the captain save the day.

就像Enterprise上的 Scotty 或 Geordi 一样，你自己的工程团队有一种天然的保守倾向。开发人员总是（并且可以理解）宁愿花更多时间而不是更少时间来进行原型设计、测试、质量检查等。这就是产品经理有时必须在冲刺期间发挥调查作用的地方，并询问为什么某些故事花费的时间比预期更长，为什么速度下降，有时会即时重新确定优先级，以便关键工作先于不太重要的工作完成。就像以前一样，开发经理是这里的重要合作伙伴，他可以解释出现了哪些新问题，从而减缓了进度。一些延迟和不可预见的障碍是不可避免的，尽早沟通有助于设定对该冲刺输出的期望。其他时候，

Just like Scotty or Geordi on the Enterprise, your own engineering team has a natural tendency toward conservatism. Developers would always (and understandably) rather take more time rather than less for prototyping, testing, QA, and so on. This is where product managers sometimes must step into an investigative role during a sprint and ask why certain stories are taking longer than expected, why velocity is down, and sometimes reprioritize on the fly so that critical work is finished before less-critical stuff. Just like before, the development manager is a vital partner here who can explain what new issues arose that slowed down progress. Some delays and unforeseen obstacles are just inevitable, and communicating them early helps to set expectations for that sprint’s outputs. Other times, understanding why certain stories or requirements took longer than expected can lead to avoiding similar delays in the future, which is a good use of a post-sprint review.

然而，不可避免的是，有一天，您将在冲刺即将结束时看到一两个高价值的故事看起来有从发布中溜走的风险。你会去和你的开发经理谈谈，她会解释原因，但总而言之，这个故事存在风险。你做什么工作？

Yet, inevitably, one day you’ll be nearing the end of a sprint when you see that a high-value story or two look to be at risk of slipping out of the release. You’ll go talk to your development manager, and she’ll explain the reasons why, but the long and short of it is that the story is at risk. What do you do?

当然，答案取决于您的具体情况。但这里有两个相互竞争的考虑因素可能会帮助您思考这个困境。一方面：

The answer will, of course, just depend on your situation. But here are two competing considerations that might help you think through this dilemma. On the one hand:

技术债务可以成为一种工具
Technical debt can be a tool

很像消费者债务、技术债务——即推迟重要的工程工作可能不会立即产生明显的客户价值，例如重构效率低下的代码，应尽可能避免，因为从长远来看，它总是会困扰您，并且通常需要花费更多的成本来解决。但与消费者债务一样，技术债务也可以成为解决短期问题的有效工具。在企业软件中，我们经常提前向客户告知某些功能或升级，如果我们不交付它们，就会产生恶意并损害我们未来的信誉。作为基本规则，如果要在保留我们对客户的信誉和承担一些技术债务之间做出选择，我们将每周 7 天承担技术债务，周日提供双倍服务。通常，与重建客户信任相比，解决技术债务可以更快、更便宜。

A lot like consumer debt, technical debt—i.e., putting off important engineering work that might not have immediately obvious customer value, such as refactoring inefficient code—should be avoided wherever possible, because it will always catch up with you and usually cost more to resolve in the long run. Yet also like consumer debt, technical debt can be an effective tool for solving short-term problems. In enterprise software, we often telegraph certain features or upgrades to customers in advance, and when we don’t deliver them, it creates bad will and hurts our credibility in the future. As a general rule, if given the choice between saving our credibility with the customer and taking on some technical debt, we will take the technical debt seven days a week, with a double serving on Sunday. Typically, technical debt can be resolved a lot quicker and more cheaply than building back a customer’s trust.

另一方面：

And on the other hand:

匆忙推出前沿功能是有风险的
Rushing out bleeding-edge features is risky

“快速行动，打破常规”是企业软件灾难的根源。除了早期采用者或测试版用户场景的明显例外之外，在没有足够的质量保证和功能强化的情况下推出经过轻微测试的“前沿”功能，很可能会给用户带来糟糕的体验，他们会想知道为什么他们会这样做。付给你这么多钱买一个不完整的产品，他们无法信任他们的业务。企业买家不想要半生不熟的解决方案；他们期望并且坦率地说应该得到精心设计的产品。

“Move fast and break things” is a recipe for disaster in enterprise software. With the obvious exception of early-adopter or beta user scenarios, rolling out lightly tested, “bleeding-edge” features without adequate QA and feature hardening runs a high risk of delivering a bad experience for your users, who will wonder why they’re paying you so much money for an incomplete product that they can’t trust with their business. Enterprise buyers don’t want half-baked solutions; they expect, and frankly deserve, a well-engineered product.

不，我们并不可爱。这两点都是正确的，并且像任何有趣的问题一样，它们需要在您自己的特定上下文中应用。您应该考虑的一些问题是：这些高价值故事有多重要？顾客在等他们吗？您能否有合理的信心将它们推出，并相信它们会按预期工作？销售需要他们建立管道吗？哪些工作必须从冲刺中删除，或者因为您选择完成这些故事而不是其他项目，您将承担哪些技术债务？只有在与您的开发经理讨论完这些问题后，产品管理层才能决定明智的行动方案。

No, we aren’t being cute. Both points are true, and like any interesting problem, they will require application within your own specific context. Some questions you should consider are: How important are those high-value stories? Are customers waiting on them? Can you roll them out with reasonable confidence that they’ll work as intended? Does sales need them to build pipeline? What work will have to drop out of the sprint, or what technical debt will you incur because you chose to finish those stories instead of other items? Only after talking through these questions with your development manager can product management decide on an informed course of action.

沟通发展

Communicating with Development

帮助开发人员深入了解客户问题，以便他们能够创新解决这些问题，所花费的每一分钟都是值得的。以下是一些提示，可帮助您思考我们如何与开发同行沟通：

Helping development understand customer problems deeply enough that they can innovate to solve them is worth every minute that it takes. Here are some tips to help you think about how we communicate with our development counterparts:

帮助他们抓住问题，然后让他们弄清楚如何解决它
Help them grasp the problem and then let them figure out how to solve it

这可能意味着将他们直接放在客户面前，以便他们可以用自己的眼睛和耳朵看到或听到客户的痛苦。如果这是不可能的，那就意味着要传达你从客户、潜在客户和市场那里听到的信息。但要注意不要过于规范地描述问题的解决方案；您可能会与善于利用技术解决问题的工程师一起工作，他们了解手头的问题和用例。在大多数情况下，如果工程师能够自由地进行创新，而不必被告知数据库中应该有多少列或按钮应该有多少像素高，那么他们的解决方案将会更好、更完整。如果您在与工程师的沟通中表现得很专横，那么如果您得到的正是您所要求的而不是更多，请不要感到惊讶。

This might mean putting them in front of customers directly, so that they can see or hear customers’ pains with their own eyes and ears. Where that isn’t possible, it means communicating back what you’re hearing from customers, prospects, and the market. But beware of being over-prescriptive of describing solutions to problems; you likely work with engineers who are great at solving problems with technology after they understand the problems and use cases at hand. Engineers’ solutions, in most cases, will be better and more complete if they are allowed the freedom to innovate without being told exactly how many columns should be in the database or how many pixels high the button should be. If you are overbearing in your communications with engineers, do not be surprised if you get exactly what you ask for instead of much more.

让他们遵守时间表和承诺
Hold them to timelines and commitments

工程师通常倾向于全面地解决问题，并且他们对问题了解得越多，他们就越能看到应该添加到解决方案中的东西。这是可怕的范围蔓延，可能会威胁到时间表，而时间表（至少在企业软件中）通常是由产品管理或执行领导基于各种对开发可能不明显的市场因素驱动的。即使在拥有成熟项目管理功能的组织中，产品管理也有责任将承诺的时间表放在首位，并帮助您的工程师继续专注于问题的最重要部分，以便功能按时交付，而不是继续拖延。直到它们“完美”为止。

Engineers often tend to want to solve the problem comprehensively, and the more they learn about the problem, the more they see things that should be added to the solution. This is the dreaded scope creep that can threaten timelines, which (at least in enterprise software) are usually driven by product management or executive leadership based on a variety of market factors that might not be apparent to development. Even in organizations that have a mature project management function, it is incumbent upon product management to keep committed timelines front and center and to help your engineers remain focused on the most important parts of the problem such that features ship on time and do not continue in perpetuity until they are “perfect.”

随时为您的团队提供支持
Have your team’s back at all times

当你与你的开发同行交谈时，确保他们知道你作为一个团队的输赢，并且如果有必要，如果出现问题，你会接受责备。伟大的开发实践通常会涉及承担重大风险——例如，押注于未经证实但有前途的 DBMS 或实现他们认为可以扩展的 JavaScript 框架——而这通常是最好的创新发生的地方。永远不要责怪开发部门认真地尝试做你所要求的事情，即使他们失败了。仅此一点就将为您在开发同事中赢得许多追随者。当你可以使用“我们”一词时，切勿使用“他们”一词。

As you talk to your development counterparts, make sure they know that you win and lose as a team and that, if necessary, you will accept blame if something goes wrong. Great development practices can often involve taking significant risks—betting on an unproven but promising DBMS or implementing a JavaScript framework that they think will scale, for example—and this is often where the best innovation happens. Never blame development for earnestly trying to do what you’ve asked, even if they failed. This alone will win you many acolytes among your developer colleagues. Never use the word “they” when you can use the word “we,” instead.

延期信贷
Defer credit

同样，当你可以使用“我们”这个词时，永远不要使用“我”这个词。大多数时候，尽管工程师们花了数周甚至数月的时间来设计和完善解决方案，但工程师并不是在会议上登台演讲或在全公司会议上展示他们所做的事情的人：你是。人们很容易忘记是谁让这些机会成为可能的。在许多情况下，开发就像艺术：解决方案的创建者天生就为此感到自豪，而感到被认可和欣赏比你能做的任何其他事情都重要。当您与您的工程师以及其他人沟通您的工程师时，请务必随时随地认可他们的努力。

Similarly, never use the word “I” when you can use the word “we,” instead. Most of the time, despite being the ones who spend long days for weeks and months designing and perfecting a solution, engineers aren’t the ones on stage at conferences or presenting in company-wide meetings on the things they’ve done: you are. It can be easy to forget who made those opportunities possible. In many cases, development is like art: the creator of the solution is inherently proud of it, and feeling acknowledged and appreciated means more than just about anything else you can do. When you communicate with your engineers, and with others about your engineers, make sure to acknowledge their efforts whenever and wherever you can.

不要用升级和消耗的故事来过度惊吓他们，但也不要撒谎
Don’t unduly alarm them with tales of escalation and attrition—but don’t lie, either

作为与客户群的联系，您对产品未来的态度和展望对产品的开发具有巨大的影响力。一个忧郁的产品经理无意中向开发团队传达了一种恐惧或沮丧的感觉。当客户不满意时要诚实，但要乐观——这个团队可以开始扭转局面。每当你听到首席执行官报告盈利不佳，但传达出事情进展顺利的信心时，请想想如何以同样的方式向工程师传达坏消息。但如果不需要传达坏消息，请跳过它。

只要有可能，帮助他们了解他们正在做的事情将如何解决真正的客户问题并使您的公司赚很多钱。每个人都喜欢觉得自己对公司的贡献很重要。分享因您的开发团队所做的事情而赢得交易的故事。详细讨论您用来证明要求他们为您做一个项目的客户反馈。告诉他们您将如何向销售团队传达他们正在做的事情，以及您期望它如何使销售流程受益。

As their connection to the customer base, your attitude and outlook on your product’s future carries a tremendous amount of weight with development. A product manager who is all doom and gloom inadvertently conveys a sense of fear or discouragement to the development team. Be honest when customers are unhappy, but be optimistic—this is the team that can start to turn things around. Whenever you hear a CEO report missed earnings but convey confidence that things are going great, think of how you can similarly communicate bad news in a positive light to your engineers. But if bad news doesn’t need to be communicated, skip it.
