  4. Review PLT’s feedback with development to ensure requested changes are within scope. If not, surface immediately. Reshuffle the Candidate as necessary.

  5. 纳入反馈后，PLT 暂时接受候选路线图。

  6. With its feedback incorporated, the PLT provisionally accepts the Candidate Roadmap.

路线图到期前四个星期：

Four weeks before the roadmap is due:

  1. 在内部与销售和营销人员（以及不在 PLT 上的任何其他关键利益相关者）“社交”候选人路线图并收集反馈。这些团队是否发现任何明显的遗漏或有调整建议？在此阶段，除非确实有必要，否则应避免对史诗般的包含或日程安排进行重大更改。

  2. “Socialize” the Candidate Roadmap internally with sales and marketing (and any other critical stakeholders who are not on the PLT) and gather feedback. Do these teams see any glaring omissions or have suggestions for tweaks? At this stage, major changes in epic inclusion or scheduling should be avoided unless deemed truly necessary.

  3. 产品管理充当了销售、营销、开发、PLT 和产品管理本身之间不可避免的候选路线图来回调整的路由器。

  4. Product management acts as a router for the inevitable back-and-forth of tweaks to the Candidate Roadmap between sales, marketing, development, the PLT, and product management itself.

  5. 产品管理和营销开始概述路线图演示材料（如果尚未发生）。

  6. Product management and marketing begin outlining roadmap presentation material, if this hasn’t happened already.

路线图到期前两周：

Two weeks before the roadmap is due:

  1. 由 PLT 进行最终审查和认可。所有成员都有责任。如果仍未达成共识，请尽快解决。如有必要，不同意，但承诺。

  2. Final review and endorsement by the PLT. All members are accountable. If there still isn’t consensus, resolve ASAP. Disagree if necessary, but commit.

  3. 产品管理和营销开发了面向客户和面向内部的最终路线图版本。安排会议在内部提出最终路线图。

  4. Product management and marketing develop customer-facing and internal-facing versions of the Final Roadmap. Meetings are scheduled to present the Final Roadmap internally.

到期日：

Due date:

  1. 最终路线图分享给相关内部团队。

  2. The Final Roadmap is shared with relevant internal teams.

  3. 产品管理层准备向销售团队展示最终路线图，并开发出面向客户的版本并得到营销部门的支持。

  4. Product management is prepared to present on the Final Roadmap to sales teams, with customer-facing versions developed and blessed by marketing.

  5. 产品管理和开发为最终路线图的第一个冲刺/季度的执行创建故事和要求。

  6. Product management and development create stories and requirements for executing on the first sprint/quarter of the Final Roadmap.

恭喜！你有一个路线图！

Congratulations! You have a roadmap!

现在，此时，您可能正在考虑以下事情之一：

Now, at this point, you’re probably thinking one of the following things:

这是荒唐的！我从未见过如此干净的路线图规划过程！

This is ridiculous! I’ve never seen a roadmap planning process this clean!

或者，

Or,

这是荒唐的！我从未见过如此官僚化的路线图规划流程！

This is ridiculous! I’ve never seen a roadmap planning process this bureaucratized!

事实上，这两种反应都是完全公平的。这是一个理想化的模板——现实世界中的大多数路线图规划都比表面上显示的要混乱得多。在某些组织中，“路线图规划”通常相当于每个产品经理实质上出现在一个房间中并向列表中添加一个项目。相比之下，坚持这样的流程的优点，特别是在较大的组织中，是它避免了路线图规划的“花生酱”方法（分散以满足每个人的愿望清单）。通过使用公司的业务目标作为起点，并通过 PLT 尽早审查实现这些目标的方法，您可以更好地避免次要问题和宠物项目的干扰。它确保产品路线图满足组织的业务需求，同时保持客户驱动。

Both are, in truth, completely fair reactions. This is an idealized template—most roadmap planning in the real world involves a great deal more chaos than this lets on. In some organizations, “roadmap planning” often amounts to each product manager essentially showing up in a room and adding an item to a list. By contrast, the advantage of sticking to a process like this one, particularly in a larger organization, is that it avoids a “peanut buttering” approach to roadmap planning (spreading around to fit everyone’s wish list). By using the company’s business goals as a starting point and vetting the approach to accomplishing them early with the PLT, you can better avoid the distractions of side issues and pet projects. It ensures that the product roadmap meets the organization’s business needs while also staying customer-driven.

衡量成功

Measuring Success

让我们暂时缩小范围，考虑一个更广泛的问题：如何确定产品的表现如何？什么构成成功或失败？你的仪表板上有什么？让我们谈谈如何衡量产品指标来确定并定义“成功”。

Zooming out for a moment, let’s consider a broader question: How do you determine how the product is doing? What constitutes success or failure? What’s on your dashboard? Let’s talk about how to measure product metrics to determine—and define—“success.”

假设您的产品达到了当年收入目标的 110%（无论是新预订量、新 ACV 还是您使用的任何指标）。大多数人都会认为今年是成功的一年，也许确实如此。当然，这是许多高层在继续行动之前会考虑的数字。但这里的故事还有更多值得我们关注的地方。这与你的成功指标有关。

Suppose that your product hit 110% of its revenue target for the year (whether in terms of new bookings, new ACV, or whatever metric you use). Most people would consider this a successful year, and perhaps it is. Certainly, this is the number that many higher-ups will look at before moving on. But there’s much more to the story here that’s worth our attention. This has to do with the metrics of your success.

衡量的内容得到管理，对吧？由于企业软件的种类如此繁多，因此很难提供一刀切的建议来衡量您的产品。也就是说，我们将提出三个相关的指标领域，这将有助于讲述一个更全面、更细致的故事，说明您的产品的优势和可以改进的地方。这些是销售额、用户（例如，用户增长）和参与度（例如，实际用户采用和使用）。对于 SaaS 供应商来说，后面这些领域（用户和参与度）通常比本地软件更容易衡量和跟踪。

What gets measured gets managed, right? It’s tricky to offer one-size-fits-all suggestions for measuring your product, because the varieties of enterprise software are so vast. That said, we would propose three relevant metric areas that will help tell a much more holistic and nuanced story about where your product is strong and where it could improve. These are sales, users (e.g., user growth), and engagement (e.g., actual user adoption and usage). Those latter areas, users and engagement, are typically much easier for a SaaS vendor to measure and track than for on-premises software.

总的来说，这三个领域同时增长通常是个好消息。（如果您这样做了，恭喜您！）不过，您很可能会看到其中一个或多个的改进空间。然而，鉴于企业软件的行业和高度特定于角色的性质，我们看到的是，这些指标的不同组合放入上下文中可以提供有关产品健康状况的许多不同的叙述。我们的意思是什么？让我们来看看：

On balance, it’s usually good news to see growth in all three of these areas simultaneously. (And if you do, congratulations!) It’s more than likely, though, that you see room for improvement with one or more of them. Given the industry and highly role-specific nature of enterprise software, however, what we see is that different combinations of these metrics put into context can provide lots of varied narratives around the health of a product. What do we mean? Let’s take a look:

  • 考虑一种销售增长较高但用户和参与度得分较低的产品。这是怎么回事？那么，您的产品的价值主张在购买该解决方案的高管中引起了共鸣，并且您的销售人员在传递描述该价值的消息方面表现得非常有效。问题在于，这些高管的直接下属并不清楚价值主张。该产品无法解决用户遇到的问题，因此，它也不太可能最终解决更大的业务问题。产品管理的问题是产品是否真的可以解决这些用户的问题，只是在入门或可用性方面存在差距；或者，更不祥的是，如果客户公司的执行领导者试图解决的问题与组织其他部门的问题之间存在更根本的脱节。无论哪种方式，这对作为供应商的您来说都是一个危险的地方。

  • Consider a product with high sales growth, but low scores for users and engagement. What’s going on? Well, your product’s value proposition is resonating among the executives who buy the solution, and your sellers are demonstrably effective in delivering the messaging describing that value. The problem is that value proposition isn’t as clear to those executives’ direct reports. The product isn’t solving the problems those users have, and as such, it’s unlikely to ultimately solve the larger business problems, either. The question for product management is whether the product really can solve those users’ problems, and there’s just a gap in onboarding or usability; or, more ominously, if there is a more fundamental disconnect for the client company between the problems its executive leaders are trying to solve versus those of the rest of the organization. Either way, this is a dangerous place for you, as a vendor, to be.

  • 接下来，考虑销售增长较低但用户和参与度得分较高的产品。这再次可能表明您的客户内部存在脱节。你的产品为用户解决的问题很可能并不一定由那些掌握资金的高管共同承担。传播和品牌营销可以通过建立内部冠军来稍微缩小这一距离，但从根本上来说，产品管理需要找到一种方法，将用户发现的效用与高管认可的商业价值联系起来。

  • Next, consider a product with low sales growth, but high scores for users and engagement. This, again, could point to an internal disconnect for your clients. It’s more than likely that the problems your product solves for users are not necessarily shared among those executives who hold the purse strings. Evangelism and brand marketing can narrow this distance a little by building internal champions, but fundamentally, product management needs to find a way to connect the utility that users have discovered to business value that executives recognize.

  • 如果销售增长基本达到预期，但您发现用户增长较低且参与度较高，情况又如何呢？这是利基解决方案的经典模式：少数用户发现您的产品非常有用，而大多数用户则不然。仔细观察，您很可能会发现其中许多用户都具有特定的角色、责任或关注领域。这是一个强烈的吸引力信号，您可以使用它来更仔细地研究这些用例，以便更好地向客户强调它们并帮助您传达信息。

  • How about if sales growth is basically meeting expectations, but you’re seeing low user growth paired with high engagement? This is a classic pattern for a niche solution: a few users find your product extremely useful, whereas most don’t. With a closer look, you’re quite likely to discover that many of those users share a certain role, responsibility, or focus area. This is a strong signal of traction that you can use to research those use cases more closely to better highlight them with customers and help inform your messaging.

  • 最后，如果销售增长基本达到预期，但您看到用户增长高而参与度低怎么办？很多人看到“参与度低”，立即变得紧张，我们理解，但放慢脚步。许多企业产品实际上并不需要高水平的用户参与就能获得成功。也许用户只觉得他们需要你的产品中的一项特定功能来解决他们面临的问题，然后就可以继续他们的一天。这也是一个强烈的信号，可以帮助您在该用例的基础上扩展产品的实用性。

  • Finally, what if sales growth is basically meeting expectations, but you’re seeing high user growth and low engagement? A lot of people see “low engagement” and immediately become nervous, and we understand, but slow down. Many enterprise products really don’t require high levels of user engagement to be successful. Perhaps users only feel they need one specific thing from your product to solve the problem they face, and can then go on with their day. This, too, is a strong signal that can help you build on that use case to broaden the usefulness of the product.

当然，并非所有这些框架都“适合”您的产品环境，您应该主要将它们作为示例。然而，通过跟踪和询问一小部分这样的核心指标，产品经理可以开始揭示其产品的优势和劣势背后的叙述，这对于集思广益的前进道路非常有用。

Not all of these frames will “fit” for your product’s context, of course, and you should take them mostly as examples. Yet by tracking and interrogating a small group of core metrics like these, product managers can begin to reveal a narrative behind their product’s strengths and weaknesses that can be extremely useful in brainstorming paths forward.

规划产品寿命终止

Planning the Product End-of-Life

导致产品报废（或“废止”）的原因可能有很多。希望有一个更新、更好的对应版本已启动并运行，并且您已准备好强制客户迁移。也许您的业务遇到了麻烦，或者该产品只是您决定停止支持的外围产品。无论情况如何，产品报废对于许多企业产品经理来说都是现实，因此仔细规划非常重要。良好的产品报废流程会让客户感受到组织良好的业务合作伙伴的支持，他们很可能会再次与之合作。糟糕的报废流程会毁掉桥梁，让客户陷入困境，他们只想向任何倾听的人宣传他们的糟糕经历。将良好的生命周期终止计划视为对客户保留的良好投资。

There could be many reasons why you end-of-life (or “sunset”) a product. Hopefully, a newer, better counterpart is up and running, and you’re ready to force customers to migrate. Perhaps your business has run into trouble, or the product is simply a peripheral one that you’ve made a decision to stop supporting. Whatever the case is, product end-of-lifes are a reality for many enterprise product managers and are important to plan for closely. A good product end-of-life process leaves customers feeling supported by a well-organized business partner who they are very likely to work with again. A poor end-of-life process will burn bridges and leave a customer hanging who wants nothing more than to advertise their bad experience to anyone listening. Consider a good end-of-life plan a sound investment in customer retention.

当您因产品被淘汰或被新版本取代而停用产品时，应在产品管理和销售团队之间开始内部规划。以下是针对产品生命周期的一项可能的计划，该计划处于相当高的水平，以便考虑到公司环境因素。当然，这是假设您的产品寿命终止的原因不是因为公司的业务活动（例如，退出……）。

When you sunset a product because it’s being phased out or replaced by a new version, planning should begin internally between product management and the sales team. What follows is one possible plan for the product end-of-life that is reasonably high-level so as to allow for company-contextual factors. This assumes, of course, that the reason for your product end-of-life is not because of a business event at the company (like, say, going out of it…).

您的第一步是选择一个明确的生命终止日期并坚持下去。可能会有法律或合同要求，这些要求会在您何时、为谁以及何时可以终止产品而发挥作用，因此显然一定要与您的法律团队取得联系。确保您了解客户在合同中合法享有的权利以及期限 - 您最不希望看到的是愤怒的客户想知道为什么您要逐步终止他们实际上仍然有权使用的产品结束日期后的几个月内。但假设你在法律上没有任何问题，那就坚持你的日期，不要改变它。没有例外。设置此日期后，请立即通知您的销售团队。确保不会针对相关产品启动新交易，并尝试找出修改或终止管道中已有交易的方法。可能有向客户销售即将正式停产的产品是有意义的例外情况；例如，如果客户的需求是即时且短期的（而且，嗯……他们仍然想购买），但这种需求很少见。

Your first step is to pick a drop-dead end-of-life date and stick to it. There are likely legal or contractual requirements that will come into play around when exactly you can sunset a product, and for whom and when, so obviously be sure to get with your legal team. Be sure you understand what customers are legally entitled to in their contracts and for how long—the last thing you want is to be surprised by an angry customer wanting to know why you’re winding down a product they’re actually still entitled to use for months after your end date. But assuming you’re in the clear legally, stick to your date and don’t move it. No exceptions. After you set this date, immediately inform your sales teams. Ensure that no new deals are initiated for the product in question, and try to figure out a way to modify or terminate any already in the pipeline. There may be exceptions for which it makes sense to sell a customer a product that is on the verge of being officially sunset; for example, if the customer’s needs are immediate and short-term (and, well…they still want to buy it)—but they are rare.

在确定了生命周期终止日期并得到管理层的祝福后，是时候深入探讨为客户制定完善的迁移计划的细节了。例如，如果您有较新版本的软件或完全替代的产品，迁移可能不仅仅涉及切换；还涉及到迁移。它可能涉及移动或修改大量数据、下游应用程序、流程和集成。在复杂的场景下，根据产品的不同，甚至可能涉及到专业的服务需求。许多处于这种地位的公司选择提供折扣甚至免费服务来留住客户。（另一方面，有些人选择不这样做，以便对这些客户施加一些微妙的压力，迫使他们离开。“解雇”麻烦的客户，例如那些订阅价值低但客户服务要求极高的客户，有时是个好主意。 ) 对于您不这样做的情况销售替代产品来向客户定位，合作是一个好主意。与其让你的忠实客户悬而未决，不如与你尊敬的昔日竞争对手建立合作伙伴关系，并可以轻松地将客户从一种产品转移到另一种产品。通过与开发和服务团队的协作，应该由产品管理来推动主要客户迁移计划，然后将其提交以供批准。

After you’ve finalized your end-of-life date and it’s been blessed by management, it’s time to get down into the nitty-gritty of developing a sound migration plan for customers. For example, if you have a newer version of the software or an alternative product entirely, migration probably involves more than just throwing a switch; it could involve moving or modifying a large amount of data, downstream applications, processes, and integrations. In complex scenarios and depending on the product, this might even involve professional services requirements. Many firms in this position choose to offer services at a discount, or even free, to keep customers. (On the other hand, some choose not to do so in order to put some subtle pressure on those customers to leave. “Firing” troublesome customers, like those with low subscription value but exceptionally high customer service demands, is sometimes a good idea.) For cases in which you do not sell an alternative product to position to customers, partnering is an excellent idea. Rather than leave your loyal customers hanging, it’s a great idea to strike up a partnership with an erstwhile competitor that you respect and can work with to move customers easily from one product to the next. Through collaboration with the development and services teams, it should be product management that drives the primary customer migration plan and then presents it for approval.

确定迁移计划后，就该宣传它了。与相关客户团队召开会议，解释停产决定和迁移路径。在此情况下，制定清晰、记录齐全的计划的前期投资将为您省去很多麻烦。大多数问题都可以通过基本的迁移文档和方便的常见问题解答轻松回答。

After you have finalized a migration plan, it’s time to evangelize it. Call a meeting with the relevant account teams and explain both the end-of-life decision and the migration path. This is where the upfront investment in creating a clear, well-documented plan will save you a lot of headaches. Most questions can be easily answered by a basic migration document and handy FAQ.

下一步是回到我们营销方面的朋友那里。营销将至少在两个方面再次成为关键合作伙伴。首先，营销可以为制定临终公告计划提供宝贵的帮助。在某些情况下，营销实际上可以推动公告，特别是当它用于定位增强型或下一代产品时。其次，营销至少需要清除任何现有的对日落产品的引用（或宣传！）。

The next step is to go back to our friends in marketing. Marketing will again be a key partner in at least two ways. First, marketing can lend valuable assistance in developing an announcement plan for the end-of-life. In some cases, marketing can actually drive the announcement, particularly when it’s used to position an enhanced or next-generation product. Secondly, and at a minimum, marketing will need to purge any existing collateral of references to (or pitches for!) the sunset product.

完成这些工作后，您就可以开始向客户通报这一消息了。如何做到这一点显然完全取决于您的客户关系，但通常情况下，客户团队，尤其是购买昂贵软件套件的大客户，会要求产品管理人员解释生命周期结束的决定，并引导客户完成迁移计划。（如果您的飞行常客里程不足，请做好准备。）这些客户拜访并不总是很有趣，但我们个人发现，很少有客户会对这样的公告感到惊讶，并且在明确的迁移时通常会做出良好的反应道路已经经过深思熟虑并真诚地提出。直截了当地说明为什么要取消产品以及打算如何帮助客户完成项目。根据我们的经验，成年人总是欣赏直率和诚实的乐于助人的意愿。在淘汰主要企业产品时，我们对这种解释很少有负面反应。（分享负面故事需要先请本或布莱尔喝一杯。）

With these pieces in place, you’re ready to begin breaking the news to customers. How this is done obviously depends entirely on your customer relations, but often, account teams, especially for big clients buying expensive suites of software, will call in product management to explain the end-of-life decision and walk clients through the migration plan. (If you’re low on frequent flier miles, get ready.) These customer visits aren’t always fun, but we’ve personally found that few customers are taken by surprise by announcements like this, and often react well when a clear migration path has already been well thought out and presented in good faith. Be straight about why you’re sunsetting a product and how you intend to assist the client in wrapping up the project. In our experience, adults always appreciate forthrightness and an honest willingness to help. In sunsetting major enterprise products, we’ve had remarkably few negative reactions to this kind of explanation. (Sharing stories about the negative ones will require buying Ben or Blair a drink first.)

如果您正在定位替代产品或下一代产品，最好准备好精彩的推介和演示。如果失去久经考验的旧产品的顾客能够看到、触摸并询问有关新替代品的问题，那么您已经有一个留住忠实顾客的好机会，这几乎总是比寻找网络更便宜、更好-新的一个。事实上，标准做法是为有兴趣转向下一代产品的客户提供甜味剂——同样，专业服务是这方面的最爱，但有吸引力的折扣也很有效。

If you’re positioning an alternative or next-generation product, it’s a good idea to have a great pitch and demo ready to roll. If customers who are losing a tried-and-tested old favorite product can see, touch, and ask questions about a new alternative, you already have a warm opportunity to retain a loyal customer, which is almost always cheaper and better than finding a net-new one. In fact, it’s standard practice to offer customers interested in moving to your next-generation product a sweetener—again, professional services is a favorite for this, but attractive discounting works, too.

产品报废是软件行业的一个事实，没有什么可以回避的。它们不像发布那么有趣，但如果你长期从事这个行业，你会不止一次地经历它们。做好准备吧。

Product end-of-lifes are a fact of the software business and nothing to shy away from. They’re not as much fun as launches, but if you’re in this for the long term, you’ll go through them more than once. Just be ready.

概括

Summary

产品知识不仅仅是熟悉产品的工作原理。当然，这很重要，但不要担心成为世界上最伟大的产品 X 专家。相反，在达到熟练的熟悉程度后，扩展以了解产品的规划、发布、维护以及有时的所有要素。 ，退出市场。编写明确的需求以及构建和传播产品路线图是产品知识的关键组成部分。确保您了解内部路线图和面向外部路线图的双重用途，因为这些路线图对每个路线图的外观都有很大的影响。当您执行路线图时，请在多个维度上衡量您的结果，以确保您不会错过有关产品性能的关键叙述。

Product knowledge is about much more than simply being familiar with how your product works. That’s important, of course, but don’t worry about being the world’s greatest expert on Product X. Rather, after achieving a skilled level of familiarity, expand to understand all elements of how your product is planned, launched, maintained, and, sometimes, withdrawn from the market. Writing clear requirements and building and evangelizing the roadmap for your product are key components of product knowledge. Be sure you understand the dual uses of internal versus external-facing roadmaps because these have big consequences for what each should look like. As you execute on the roadmap, measure your outcomes on more than one dimension to make sure you’re not missing critical narratives about your product’s performance.

表 5-2。产品路线图概述幻灯片示例

Q1 (v1.4)

Q1 (v1.4)

Q2 (v1.5)

Q2 (v1.5)

营销分析

Marketing Analytics

  • 实时报告

  • Real-time reporting

  • 改进的导航

  • Improved navigation

  • 高级指标生成器

  • Advanced metric builder

  • 改进团队之间的数据共享

  • Improved sharing of data between teams

  • 分析师的表格构建和管理

  • Table builder and curation for analysts

  • 营销人员的消费体验

  • Consumption experience for marketers

  • 更新了许可

  • Updated permissioning

广告

Advertising

  • 高级出价优化

  • Advanced bid optimization

  • 与 AdWords 和 Bing 集成

  • Integration with AdWords and Bing

机器学习

Machine Learning

  • 异常检测

  • Anomaly detection

  • 统计公式/函数

  • Statistical formulas/functions

  • 统计相关性

  • Statistical correlations

  • 得分增益/提升图表

  • Gains/lift charts for scoring

  • 异常检测警报

  • Anomaly detection alerting

  • 基于规则的归因建模

  • Rules-based attribution modeling

  • 决策树和其他可视化

  • Decision trees and other visualizations

  • 贡献分析

  • Contribution analysis

开发商/合作伙伴

Developers/Partners

  • 消防水带（测试版）

  • Firehose (beta)

  • 报告 API 增强功能

  • Report API enhancements

  • 标准认证

  • Standard authentication

  • 报告API支持

  • Report API support

一体化

Integration

  • 分析 – 目标数据集成

  • Analytics – Target data integration

  • 共享个人资料 (Raven)

  • Shared profile (Raven)

  • 附加卡类型

  • Additional card types

  • 无缝角色切换

  • Seamless persona switching

移动的

Mobile

  • 以应用程序为中心的用户界面

  • App-centric user interface

  • 兴趣点报告和定位

  • Points of interest reporting and targeting

  • 移动操作系统和浏览器检测

  • Mobile OS and browser detection

  • 推送活动管理

  • Push campaign management

  • 应用内消息传递

  • In-app messaging

  • 应用下载转化跟踪

  • App download conversion tracking

  • 动态标签管理集成

  • Dynamic tag management integration

  • 完整的地理围栏分析

  • Full geo-fencing analytics

  • 屏幕/视觉覆盖

  • Screen/Visual overlays

  • 增强消息传递（短信、富媒体）

  • Enhanced messaging (SMS, rich media)

  • 移动广告网络集成

  • Mobile ad network integrations

视频

Video

  • 心跳视频报告

  • Heartbeat video reporting

  • 集成视频和广告报告

  • Integrated video and ad reporting

  • 同时观看的实时报告

  • Live reporting of concurrent viewers

  • 支持在线线性电视内容

  • Support for linear TV content online

1“最高薪人士的意见”

1 “Highest Paid Person’s Opinion”

第 6 章使用数据构建更好的产品

Chapter 6. Building Better Products with Data

无论您使用的是企业软件还是消费软件，分析数据以了解人们如何实际购买、实施、使用和保留您的产品是您快速构建正确产品的最佳机会。

Whether you’re in enterprise or consumer software, analyzing data to understand how people actually buy, implement, use, and retain your product is your best chance to build the right thing quickly.

在第七章中，我们研究了客户为何并不总是完全按照他们所说的去做。您可能会询问客户有关他们使用您的产品的问题，或者他们在各自行业中面临的挑战，有时他们可能会（有意或无意）给出不知情、有偏见或完全不准确的答案。

In Chapter 7, we examine how customers do not always do exactly what they say they do. You might ask customers questions about their usage of your product, or the challenges they face in their respective industries, and at times they are likely to give answers which are (either intentionally or unintentionally) uninformed, biased, or just plain inaccurate.

我们已经讨论了观察是如何确保您关注人们实际所做的事情而不是简单地了解他们对自己所做的事情的印象或假设的好方法。观察的问题在于它不能很好地扩展。即使在企业软件中，您的用户群可能比非常成功的消费产品小得多，您也可能有数十万或数百万您想要观察的用户。观察一小群用户执行日常任务可以为您提供有关产品优缺点的有力、直观的证据，但除非您观察至少几十个用户尝试完成类似的结果，否则很难从中得出广泛的结论单独观察。

We’ve discussed how observation is a good way to ensure that you are focused on what people actually do rather than simply their impressions or assumptions about what they do. The trouble with observation is that it does not scale very well. Even in enterprise software, where your user base is likely substantially smaller than highly successful consumer products, you might have hundreds of thousands or millions of users that you would like to observe. Watching a small group of users perform daily tasks can provide you with powerful, visual evidence of the strengths and weaknesses of your product, but unless you are watching at least several dozen users try to accomplish similar results, it is difficult to draw widespread conclusions from observation alone.

帮助您了解用户中更广泛趋势的缺失环节是数据，它使您能够大规模而不是单独地发现用户群（和客户群）的趋势，有助于确保您就产品设计、路线图等。最好的企业产品经理是有能力的分析师，他们可以提出好的问题（并提出假设），然后使用数据回答这些问题（并尝试推翻这些假设）。

The missing link to help you understand broader trends among your users is data, which allows you to spot trends in your user base (and customer base) at scale rather than individually, helping to ensure that you are making informed decisions about product design, the roadmap, and more. The best enterprise product managers are capable analysts who can ask good questions (and pose hypotheses) and then answer those questions (and attempt to invalidate those hypotheses) using data.

坦率地说，使用数据来帮助告知产品设计和路线图，到目前为止，消费类软件在某种程度上已经超过了企业软件。这有几个原因。最值得注意的是，消费类软件用户群的庞大规模使得消费类软件产品经理更难以从直接客户访谈中收集见解，而不是分析程序化使用数据；而企业产品经理通常有几十到几千个客户可供选择，这使得定性客户访谈变得更容易，而程序化使用数据在某种程度上不太能代表市场。企业产品团队还可以利用与这些客户的直销关系来寻找互动的机会。然而，最好的企业软件产品团队正在通过数据和分析取得巨大进步并做出更好的决策。这是我们不应该让消费软件人员享受所有乐趣的另一种情况。

The use of data to help inform product design and the roadmap is, frankly, an area where consumer software has somewhat outpaced enterprise software to this point. There are a few reasons for this. Most notably, the sheer scale of consumer software user bases makes gleaning insights from direct customer interviews more difficult for consumer software product managers, in lieu of analyzing programmatic usage data; whereas enterprise product managers typically have anywhere from a few dozen to a few thousand customers to choose from, making qualitative customer interviews easier, and programmatic usage data somewhat less representative of the market. An enterprise product team can also use the direct-sales relationships with those customers to find opportunities to interact. However, the best enterprise software product teams are making great strides and much better decisions with data and analysis. This is another case in which we should not let the consumer software people have all the fun.

幸运的是，在过去 15 年里，组织捕获、分发和分析各种数据的能力迅速扩展。在本章中，我们将简要介绍三大类型的数据，这些数据对于您作为产品经理的分析至关重要。如果您作为产品经理曾在无数可能的路径或设计决策中感到迷失，那么本章适合您。如果您想知道从一位客户那里听到的内容是否更广泛地适用于您的客户群（或潜在客户群），那么本章适合您。我们的目的不是教您如何进行数据分析或规定分析方法（群组分析与延迟分析等）；其他书籍和博客将填补这些空白。

Fortunately, the past 15 years have seen a rapid expansion of organizations’ ability to capture, distribute, and analyze data of various kinds. In this chapter, we briefly cover three broad types of data that will be essential in your own analysis as a product manager. If you have ever felt lost amid countless possible paths or design decisions as a product manager, this chapter is for you. If you have ever wondered whether what you are hearing from one customer is applicable more broadly to your customer base (or potential customer base), this chapter is for you. Our aim is not to teach you how to do data analysis or prescribe methods for analysis (cohort analysis versus latency analysis, etc.); other books and blogs will fill in those gaps.

产品使用数据

Product Usage Data

您的产品中的哪些功能可以产生持久的使用效果？最常使用的用户与偶尔使用的用户有何不同？哪些功能与续订或追加销售相关？我们应该如何考虑将产品的不同组件包装在一起？哪些很少使用的功能可以退役以恢复开发和测试资源？您可以通过检查有关产品使用情况的数据来回答这些问题和许多其他问题。

Which features in your product produce lasting usage? How do your most habitual users differ from occasional users? Which features correlate with renewal or upsell? How should we think about packaging disparate components of our product together? What little-used features can be retired to recover development and testing resources? You can answer these questions and many others by examining data around product usage.

产品使用数据的关键词是粒度。很高兴知道有多少人安装或登录了您的产品，但这仅适用于跟踪采用和流失的最高级别趋势。获取更精细、更具体的数据，了解哪些功能最常使用、哪些设置真正产生影响，以及用户如何在与您一起的旅程中分成离散的组或集群，这使得使用数据如此强大。

The key word with product usage data is granularity. It is nice to know how many people have installed or logged in to your product, but this is useful only for tracking the highest-level trends in adoption and churn. Getting more granular, specific data on which features are used most, which settings really make a difference, and how users break out into discrete groups or clusters along their journey with you is what makes usage data so powerful.

诚然，某些产品的产品使用数据比其他产品更容易获得。软件即服务 (SaaS) 的出现为软件提供了与网站数十年来相同的数据收集方法。因此，对于 SaaS 产品，收集有关产品和功能使用情况的数据就像在整个产品中插入 JavaScript 标签或 API 事件调用一样简单。对于传统的本地或安装的软件，由于连接、防火墙或安全问题，一开始收集精细的、功能级的产品使用数据可能会更加困难，甚至不可能。本书并不是要讨论在已安装的软件中实施用户测量的各种策略；而是要讨论在已安装的软件中实施用户测量的各种策略。相当，

Admittedly, product usage data is easier to come by for some products than for others. The emergence of Software as a Service (SaaS) has opened up software to the same methods of data collection that websites have enjoyed for decades. Thus, for SaaS products, collecting data on product and feature usage can be as simple as inserting JavaScript tags or API event calls throughout your product. For traditional on-premises or installed software, collecting granular, feature-level product usage data can be more difficult or even impossible at first, due to connectivity, firewall, or security concerns. This book is not the place to go into various strategies for implementing user measurement within installed software; rather, we simply aim to recognize that an enterprise software product manager who is leading an installed product might need to become a bit more creative to obtain this data.

净推荐值 (NPS) 旨在为您提供一种随时间推移跟踪客户对您产品的满意度的方法，也属于此类。再次强调，在可能的情况下，尝试对 NPS 和客户之声工作进行一般化和细化，以便您不仅了解用户是否喜欢您的产品，还了解产品的哪些方面让他们回访更多，并且（不少于重要）哪些特征会让他们愤怒。

Net Promoter Score (NPS), which purports to give you a way to track customer satisfaction with your product over time, also falls into this category. Again, where possible try to be both general and granular with your NPS and voice-of-customer efforts so that you know not just whether users love your product, but which aspects of the product keep them coming back for more, and (no less important) which features drive them to rage.

在最基本的应用中，产品使用数据也可以成为寻找客户合作伙伴以进行发现和反馈的好方法（如第6 章所述）。假设您正在考虑迭代产品的一部分，或者您想更详细地了解用户从某个功能中获得的价值。产品使用数据可以向您指出产品某一部分最重（或最轻）的消费者。正如我们刚才提到的，您可以利用客户团队和客户之间已经存在的关系来联系相关用户并向他们学习。

At its most basic application, product usage data can also be a great way to find customers to partner with for discovery and feedback (as discussed in Chapter 6). Let’s say you are considering iterating on a part of your product or that you want to understand in more detail the value users get from a feature. Product usage data can point you to the heaviest (or lightest) consumers of a part of your product. As we just mentioned, you can then take advantage of relationships that already exist between account teams and customers to reach out to the relevant users and spend time learning from them.

销售和财务数据

Sales and Finance Data

作为产品经理，出于多种原因，熟悉通常由销售和财务拥有的数据至关重要。您负责与您的产品相关的业务。最终，尽管这可能不是您在任何特定时刻选择表达产品目标的方式，但在几乎所有企业软件情况下最重要的关键绩效指标 (KPI) 都是预订、收入和保留/流失。从某种意义上说，您对这些指标中的每一个都负有责任。确保您步入正轨以确保增长并在未步入正轨时适当参与的最佳方法是使用基本的销售和财务数据。

As a product manager, there are a number of reasons why it is crucial to be intimately familiar with the data typically owned by sales and finance. You are responsible for the business that surrounds your product. Ultimately, although it might not be how you choose to express your product goals at any given moment, the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that matter most in nearly every case for enterprise software are bookings, revenue, and retention/attrition. In one way or another, you are responsible for each of these metrics. The best way to ensure that you are on track to secure growth and to become involved appropriately when you are not on track, is by working with basic sales and finance data.

从销售中（可能通过您的客户关系管理 [CRM] 工具），确保您可以按产品和权利访问和过滤客户数据拥有的、年度经常性收入 (ARR)、位置、客户团队成员以及您的销售运营团队可能已经捕获（或可能开始捕获）的各种其他字段。这些数据将帮助您完成一些工作，例如按收入对客户群进行建模、跟踪关键销售交易和续订的进度以及帮助进行赢/输分析等。有权查询组织 CRM 数据的产品经理可以回答各种问题，并更多地参与保护其业务的未来。例如，我们知道一位企业软件产品经理从其公司的 Salesforce 实例获取数据转储，其中包含其产品的整个业务记录的快照。由此，他可以查出任何特定客户在他的产品上花费了多少钱，任何特定客户拥有的其他产品等等。这些数据有助于找出最有利可图的交叉销售机会，这有助于他规划路线图工作，为客户抓住这些机会。

From sales (likely via your customer relationship management [CRM] tool), make sure you can access and filter customer data by products and entitlements owned, annual recurring revenue (ARR), location, account team members, and a variety of other fields that your sales operations team is likely already capturing (or could begin capturing). This data will help you do things like model out your customer base by revenue, track the progress of key sales deals and renewals as they happen, and aid in win/loss analysis, among other things. Product managers who have access to query their organization’s CRM data can answer all sorts of questions and be much more involved in securing the future of their business. As an example, we are aware of an enterprise software product manager who gets a data dump from his company’s Salesforce instance containing a snapshot of his product’s entire book of business. From this, he can look up how much any given customer is spending on his product, other products owned by any given customer, and more. This data has been instrumental in figuring out what the most lucrative cross-sell opportunities are, which helps him plan roadmap work to address those opportunities for customers.

随着每个季度的进展，您的财务团队将需要频繁读取您的预订、收入和保留/流失情况。当然，在每个季度之后了解您是否达到了各种目标至关重要，但是在整个季度定期更新这些指标可以让您选择将客户团队的支持重点放在哪里，以及使用哪些营销杠杆努力实现您的季度目标。在许多情况下，产品经理参与关键销售交易可能是错过产品编号还是成功获得产品编号的关键。

From your finance team, you will want a frequent readout of your bookings, revenue, and retention/attrition as each quarter progresses. Of course, it is crucial to understand after each quarter whether you hit your various targets, but having a regularly updated view into these metrics throughout the quarter allows you to choose where to focus your support of account teams, as well as which marketing levers to pull to achieve your quarterly goals. In many cases, involvement from a product manager in a key sales deal can be the difference between missing your product’s number and hitting it.

与负责跟踪您的产品的销售和财务同事建立关系，他们可以帮助您进行分析，从而帮助您以强有力的方式发展业务。

Develop a relationship with your colleagues in both sales and finance who are responsible for tracking your product, and they can help you with analysis that will enable you to help grow your business in powerful ways.

行业数据

Industry Data

这包括任何非特定于您自己的业务的数据，这些数据可以帮助您深入了解您所在行业的竞争方向。我们在第 6 章中讨论了其中几个来源。它包括您的总潜在市场 (TAM)、行业研究和分析、竞争情报等。当试图支持你的论点，即某个客户问题值得解决时，获得优秀的 TAM 或对最高管理层领导者的调查表明，78% 的人认为你所倡导的问题对业务至关重要，可以使所有问题都得到解决。区别。

This includes any data not specific to your own business that provides insight into the direction of the industry in which you compete. We discussed several of these sources in Chapter 6. It includes your Total Addressable Market (TAM), industry studies and analysis, competitive intelligence, and more. When seeking to bolster your argument that a certain customer problem is worth solving, having access to a good TAM or a survey of C-suite leaders suggesting that 78% of them feel like the problem you are advocating for is business critical, can make all the difference.

测试

Testing

企业软件之外的几乎所有产品管理思想领袖以及企业软件内部的许多产品管理思想领袖都主张进行大量数据驱动的测试。测试可以采取多种形式，其中一些在任何产品管理环境中都是非常可取的。在这里，我们将重点关注企业软件与消费软件朋友的一些不同之处。

Nearly every product management thought leader outside of enterprise software, and many within enterprise software, advocate for heavy data-driven testing. Testing can take many forms, and some of them are highly advisable in any product management context. Here we will focus on a few ways in which enterprise software is different from our consumer software friends.

让我们变得异端。通常，我们是 A/B（或“分割”）测试的忠实粉丝。这个理论是合理的，即通过在统计上有效的测试中尝试一个想法（新的 UI 设计、新功能等），您可以自信地（大规模）了解用户更喜欢哪个选项，然后滚动将这种偏好传达给所有客户。如果您不确定如何改善客户体验（谁能真正确定？），请进行测试并让结果说明一切。在消费类软件中，以及在企业软件中的有限方式中，A/B 测试是一种强大（而且通常很便宜）的方法，可以确保您发布的内容能够推动您想要推动的 KPI。

Let’s get heretical. Usually, we are huge fans of A/B (or “split”) testing. The theory, which is sound, is that by trying out an idea (a new UI design, a new feature, etc.) in a statistically valid test, you can learn with confidence (at scale) which option users prefer, and then roll that preference out to all customers. If you’re not sure how to improve your customer experience (and who is ever really sure?), run a test and let the results speak for themselves. And in consumer software, and in limited ways in enterprise software, A/B testing is a powerful (and often cheap) way to ensure that what you ship drives the KPI you intended it to drive.

然而，问题是：当大公司向你支付数百万美元购买软件时，他们最不想要的就是对产品进行重大的、未经宣布的和意想不到的改变。对于业务关键型应用程序（例如您可能使用的应用程序）来说更是如此。如果其中之一出现故障，或者以意想不到的方式发生变化，这不仅令人烦恼，还会让您的客户失去业务。失败的风险可能是巨大的，不仅仅是因为客户希望他们付费的产品始终可用。

Here is the rub, though: when big companies pay you millions of dollars for software, the last thing they want is major, unannounced, and unexpected changes to the product. This is even more true for business-critical applications like the ones you probably work on. If one of these goes down, or changes in unexpected ways, it’s not just annoying — it’s lost business for your customer. The stakes of failure are potentially huge, and not just because customers expect the product they paid for to always be available.

A/B 测试对于大多数网站和消费者应用程序来说非常有用，但有时在企业软件产品中存在风险，原因是企业用户（即那些“为软件支付数百万美元”的人）不喜欢在这涉及到他们的用户体验（UX）。没有人喜欢事情突然发生变化，但当你的客户是大型组织而不是个人客户时，这种关系就完全不同了。您可能会在企业软件中发现，当用户体验发生变化时，您销售给的公司（可能有成百上千的用户使用您的产品）坚持提前几个月通知。然后，您的高级用户会培训他们的（通常非常大）组织如何使用您的工具。当您以测试的名义对他们进行更改时，他们通常无法导航到提供价值的关键工作流程。

The reason A/B testing is great for most websites and consumer applications but sometimes risky within enterprise software products is that enterprise users (i.e., those “pay[ing] you millions of dollars for software”) do not like to be jerked around when it comes to their user experience (UX). Nobody likes it when things suddenly change on them, but the relationship is quite different when your customers are massive organizations rather than individual customers. You will likely find in enterprise software that the companies you sell to—which might have hundreds or thousands of users consuming your product—insist on months of advance notice when there are changes to the UX. Your power users then train their (often very large) organizations on how to use your tool. When you change it on them in the name of testing, they are often left hampered in their ability to navigate to the key workflows that provide value.

从测试的角度来看，这不起作用的原因是测试参与者不应该知道他们正在测试中。让我们考虑一下您的工具的新用户。我们称他为 Charles，他刚刚获得了您的产品的访问权限。您希望 Charles 获得积极的体验，因为他所在的公司为您的软件支付了大量资金，并且他使用您的产品完成的任务很可能有助于客户对您公司的投资回报的看法。为了熟悉，Charles 观看了您的教育团队录制的一些培训视频。他还阅读了一些文档。

From a testing perspective, the reason this doesn’t work is that test participants aren’t supposed to know that they are in a test. Let’s consider a new user of your tool. We’ll call him Charles, and he’s just gotten access to your product. You want Charles to have a positive experience because he is part of a company paying a lot of money for your software, and the tasks he completes with your product may well contribute to the customer’s view of their return on investment with your company. To become familiar, Charles watches a few training videos recorded by your education team. He reads a bit of documentation, as well.

现在 Charles 登录了。但是等等！这看起来不太像视频。他在文档中读到的功能在哪里？这看起来不对劲！查尔斯感到困惑和沮丧。更奇怪的是，查尔斯问另一家公司的朋友阿曼达，为什么该产品与文档或视频不匹配。但阿曼达向查尔斯发送了一张屏幕截图：对她来说，该产品看起来与记录的一模一样。

Now Charles logs in. But wait! This doesn’t look quite like the videos. Where is the feature he read about in the documentation? This doesn’t look right! Charles is confused and frustrated. To make matters weirder, Charles asks a friend, Amanda, at a different company why the product doesn’t match the documentation or videos. But Amanda sends Charles a screenshot: to her, the product looks exactly like what is documented.

这里发生了什么？Charles 最终加入了某个测试组，因此获得了与其他用户不同的用户体验变体。阿曼达属于对照组，采用的是传统的用户体验。可能有多个测试组，每个测试组都有不同的经验。其中一些体验可能确实比控件更好，并且用户可能能够轻松找到自己的方式。但他们中的许多人不会，并且挫败感将会增加。实际上没有人会因为他们的 News Feed 看起来与其他人的 News Feed 不同而放弃 Facebook（即使有少数人这样做，也不会影响 Facebook 的整体增长），但他们通常会放弃您的软件，从而将收入投入对你来说有风险。

What happened here? Charles ended up in a certain test group, and thus received a different variant of the UX than other users. Amanda was in the control group, which got the traditional UX. There could be multiple test groups, each with a different experience. Some of these experiences might indeed be better than the control, and users might be able to find their way painlessly. But many of them won’t be, and frustration will mount. Nobody is actually going to quit Facebook because their News Feed looks different than someone else’s News Feed (and even if a few people did, it wouldn’t put a dent in Facebook’s overall growth), but they often will abandon your software, putting revenue at risk for you.

为什么不简单地为每个测试变体创建单独的培训、文档等？这当然会有帮助，但请向我展示拥有足够资源和协调能力来支持创建所有支持材料的多个版本的软件公司，然后我将向您展示失落的亚特兰蒂斯之城。

Why not simply create separate training, documentation, and so on for each test variant? This certainly would help, but show me the software company that has enough resources and coordination to support creating multiple versions of all supporting materials and I’ll show you the Lost City of Atlantis.

（这里的另一个潜在问题是销售。在向潜在客户进行演示时，您最不希望看到的就是您的销售团队不知道如何应对的陌生体验。您可以通过从测试中排除演示帐户或演示环境来缓解这种情况，但这充其量仍然是有风险的；当客户购买时，他们看到的可能与展示的不符。）

(Another potential issue here is sales. The last thing you want during a demonstration to a prospect is an unfamiliar experience that your sales team doesn’t know how to navigate. You can mitigate this by excluding demonstration accounts or demonstration environments from tests, but this is still risky at best; when the customer buys, what they see might not match what was demonstrated.)

我们暂时停止异端邪说，并提供一些额外的澄清：企业软件中肯定有一席之地。但是，如果您来自消费类软件背景，并且习惯于每月运行多个对用户工作流程有重大影响的测试，您可能会发现在企业界开发类似的程序很困难。我们建议从小规模开始，对统计上显着但较小的用户组进行测试，并专注于对产品进行微小的更改，这样当事情突然看起来与以前不同时，不会让用户或销售代表深入查看文档。

We will stop being heretical for a moment and offer some additional clarity: there is certainly a place for testing in enterprise software. However, if you come from a consumer software background and were used to running multiple tests with major user workflow implications each month, you might find it difficult to develop a similar program in the enterprise world. We recommend starting small, testing with statistically significant but small groups of users, and focusing on minor changes to your product that won’t send a user or a sales rep diving for the documentation when things suddenly look different than they used to.

在企业软件中进行“大规模测试”的另一个好方法是让用户“选择”通过“公共测试版”或其他“实验室”机制进行测试，以便那些能够轻松找到可能不熟悉的功能或工作流程的人知道他们正在做什么。这并不是严格意义上的 A/B 测试，而是在产品上线之前收集有关产品变更的反馈的好方法，这样您就可以确保您的改进达到预期效果并为客户解决问题。

Another good approach to “testing at scale” in enterprise software is to let users “opt in” to testing via a “public beta” or other “labs” mechanism, so that those who feel comfortable finding their way around potentially unfamiliar features or workflows know what they are getting into. This is not strictly A/B testing, but is a good way to gather feedback on changes to your product before they go live so that you can ensure your improvements will have their intended effect and solve problems for your customers.

如果测试理论是合理的，但产品管理中经常传播的实践在企业软件中的工作方式与在消费软件中的工作方式不同，那么产品经理该怎么办？对于重大产品变更，我们建议重点关注广泛的用户测试：使用快速构建的原型，让用户像探索产品的任何其他部分一样探索您的概念，然后快速迭代这些原型，然后进行更多测试 - 起泡、冲洗， 重复。

If the theory of testing is sound, but the practice as often evangelized in product management does not work the same way in enterprise software as it does in consumer software, what is a product manager to do? For major product changes, we recommend focusing on extensive user testing: using quickly built prototypes to allow users to explore your concept as they would any other part of your product, and then iterating quickly on those prototypes, followed by more testing—lather, rinse, repeat.

原型设计涉及用户体验设计师和/或开发人员创建拟议变更的轻型版本。这可以在开发或测试环境中，甚至可以（在网络上的 UI 更新的情况下）是一个 JavaScript 书签，它似乎可以为用户更改产品中的布局和 CSS，而无需实际进行任何底层代码更改。

Prototyping involves UX designers and/or developers creating a light version of the proposed change. This can be in a development or beta environment, or can even (in the case of UI updates on the web) be a JavaScript bookmarklet that appears to change the layout and CSS in your product for a user, without actually making any underlying code changes.

用户测试涉及与一小群用户（通常具有不同的经验水平并且可能来自不同的行业）合作，以了解他们对原型的理解程度。这些测试可能应该由您的用户体验设计团队运行，并提供产品管理和开发支持。考虑到所提议的新体验，测试管理员应该给受试者布置一系列任务来完成。他们在与您讨论他们的思维过程时适应和凭直觉适应新体验的能力（或无能力）将产生有价值的见解。

User testing involves working with a small group of users, typically of varying experience levels and possibly in different industries, to see how well they understand the prototype. These tests should likely be run by your UX design team, with product management and development supporting. The test administrator should give the subjects a series of tasks to complete given the proposed new experience. Their ability (or inability) to adapt and intuit their way through the new experience while talking you through their thought processes will yield valuable insights.

在某些情况下，您甚至可以通过明确邀请用户加入测试来“对生产中的体验进行 A/B 测试”。这将使他们陷入正常体验的变体，并且他们可以通过表格提供反馈。最热情的高级用户通常会急于帮忙。

In some cases, you might even be able to “A/B test an experience in production” by explicitly inviting users to join a test. This would drop them into a variant on their normal experience, and they can provide feedback via a form. Your most enthusiastic power-users will often be eager to oblige.

在软件开发过程的早期进行原型设计和用户测试不仅可以确保您正在构建的体验易于理解，而且还可以围绕完善的最终产品创建所有支持材料（文档、培训等） ，以便用户掌握您的产品的所有“渠道”之间保持和谐。

Prototyping and user testing early in the software development process will not only ensure that the experience you’re building is easily understood, but it will allow all of the supporting materials (documentation, training, etc.) to be created around a polished final product, so that there is harmony across all of the “channels” through which users master your product.

总之：我们的建议是进行测试，但要以适合您的企业用户的方式进行。在产品开发之前（和期间）让您的客户参与测试，但不要冒疏远用户的风险，他们的体验将为您未来的收入铺平道路。不要为他们的业务所依赖的体验提供意想不到的产品变体。

In sum: our advice is to test away, but do it in a way that’s right for your enterprise users. Involve your customers in testing prior to (and during) product development, but don’t risk alienating your users, whose experiences pave the road to your future earnings. Don’t give them unexpected product variants on an experience on which their business relies.

概括

Summary

企业产品经理通常有很多机会使用数据来更好地了解他们的客户，并且这些数据可以为您将与客户进行的其他研究提供定量依据。我们建议尽可能将分析作为产品管理流程的一部分。我们还建议谨慎对待 A/B 测试，但您将有很多机会进行拆分测试以及涉及原型的用户测试。所有这些方法都将帮助您确保以正确的方式解决正确的问题。

Enterprise product managers often have copious opportunities to use data to better understand their customers, and this data sheds quantitative light on other research you will do with customers. We recommend making analysis part of your product management process wherever possible. We also advise a bit of caution around A/B testing, but you will have plenty of opportunities to do both split testing as well as user testing involving prototypes. All of these methods will help you to ensure that you are solving the right problems in the right ways.

项目经理简介

姓名：基门·华纳

Name: Kimen Warner

职位： Adob​​e 集团产品经理

Title: Group Product Manager, Adobe

您是如何开始产品管理的？

How did you get started in product management?

我在大学主修产品设计，本质上是产品管理与机械工程的结合，所以我学会了如何实际构建物理产品。我知道我想做软件产品管理，这样我就可以快速迭代（老实说，我不会在工厂里花时间！），但从大学毕业后直接找到产品管理职位几乎是不可能的。相反，我进入了咨询行业，然后加入了一家初创公司，担任面向客户的技术顾问，在那里我学习了产品。然后，我利用这些产品知识进入了产品管理团队。那家初创公司被收购了两次，而我仍在为它做产品管理！

I majored in product design in college, which was essentially product management combined with mechanical engineering, so I learned how to actually build physical products. I knew I wanted to do software product management so I could iterate quickly (and honestly not spend time in factories!), but it’s almost impossible to find a product management role directly out of college. Instead, I went into consulting and then joined a startup as a client-facing technical consultant where I learned the product. I then leveraged that product knowledge to move into the product management team. That startup got bought twice, and I’m still doing product management for it!

您认为有哪些特定背景对企业产品经理特别有价值吗？

Are there particular backgrounds you think are especially valuable for enterprise product managers?

我认为掌握一些技术知识至关重要。没有人期望您编码，但是了解什么是困难的、什么是容易的，以及如何实现设计可以使整个过程更快，并在您和开发团队之间建立信任。另一部分是客户关系体验。企业产品管理意味着大量的客户参与——从售前到管理遇到产品问题后不满意的客户。这些对话中的外交和信心对于成功至关重要。

I think having some technical knowledge is crucial. Nobody expects you to code, but knowing what’s hard and what’s easy, and how a design might get implemented makes the entire process faster and builds trust between you and your development team. The other piece is customer relationship experience. Enterprise product management means heavy customer engagement—from pre-sales to managing unhappy customers after they’ve experienced a product issue. Diplomacy and confidence in those conversations are essential for success.

您工作中最难学习的部分是什么？

What have been the most difficult parts of your job to learn?

功能优先级很难确定。我们想要构建的东西总是比我们能够构建的东西多得多，而每一项的论点都可能非常引人注目。我尝试过的每一个标准都有其缺点，而且当高管和其他人在销售周期中做出承诺时，它只会变得更加困难。我们需要不断努力，以确保我们所做的事情符合我们的客户、我们的利润以及我们对创新的渴望。

Feature prioritization is tough. There are always many more things we want to build than we can, and the argument for each one can be extremely compelling. Every rubric I’ve tried has its faults, and it only gets harder when promises have been made in sales cycles, by executives, and others. It’s a constant struggle to ensure we’re doing what’s right by our customers, our bottom line, and our thirst for innovation.

如果你不从事产品管理，你会在技术领域做什么？

What would you do in tech if you weren’t in product management?

这个很难啊！我花更多的时间思考如何在产品管理方面变得更高级的同时，继续关注产品的构建。我可能对“解决方案架构师”风格的角色最感兴趣，在这个角色中，我将与客户一起使用公司的技术尝试新的、复杂的想法。它会让我“疯狂”一点，并尝试新的想法来解决问题。但说实话，我的心真正放在产品管理上。

This one’s tough! I spend more time thinking about how I can stay close to building products while becoming more senior in product management. I’d probably be most interested in a “solutions architect” style role, where I’d work with customers to try out new and complicated ideas using a company’s technology. It would let me “geek out” a bit and kick the tires on new ideas to solve problems. But honestly, my heart is really in product management.

第 7 章行业知识

Chapter 7. Industry Knowledge

如果不了解行业当前的状况以及未来的发展方向，产品经理就无法帮助设计产品的未来。幸运的是，您将拥有许多工具来获取这些知识：最重要的是，通过多种方式直接与客户合作收集的见解。

Product managers cannot help design the future of the product without knowing where their industry is currently, as well as where it is headed. Fortunately, you will have many tools at your disposal to gain this knowledge: most important, insights gleaned from working directly with your customers in a number of ways.

尽管到目前为止我们在本书中还没有过多讨论它们，但我们承认产品可以通过某些方式企业软件的管理可能比消费技术更容易。我们将在本章中讨论一个这样的例子：了解您的目标市场。在本章讨论的三种类型的知识中，行业/市场知识是行业中的新产品经理和经验丰富的产品经理都需要不断努力获得的知识，特别是考虑到大多数行业的技术变革步伐。

Although we have not talked much about them so far in this book, we will admit that there are some ways in which product management for enterprise software might arguably be easier than in consumer technology. We’re going to discuss one such example in this chapter: gaining an understanding of your target market. Of the three types of knowledge discussed in this chapter, industry/market knowledge is the one that both new and experienced product managers in an industry will need to continually strive to obtain, especially given the pace of technological change in most industries.

当然，消费技术有其可寻址的细分市场。但即便如此，从大规模来看，普通技术消费者拥有的用例种类仍然存在巨大差异。在企业软件中这仍然是一个问题，但更容易克服。同一行业的企业往往有许多共同特征：销售方式；他们销售什么类型的产品；他们如何采购、生产和分销这些商品；等等。深入了解一个行业的运作方式可以让企业产品经理了解该行业的人们所面临的问题类型，这是非常有价值的。

Consumer technology has its addressable segments, of course. But even so, at large scale there is a tremendous diversity in the kinds of use cases normal technology consumers have. In enterprise software this is still a problem, but is somewhat easier to overcome. Businesses in the same industry tend to share many characteristics in common: how they sell; what types of products they sell; how they source, produce, and distribute those goods; and so forth. Knowing a lot about how an industry works gives an enterprise product manager very valuable insight into what types of problems people in that industry face.

在成熟的行业中，可能存在大量噪声，使您想要捕获的信号变得模糊。有时，自以为无所不知的行业老手们对未来的预测完全是错误的。或者，也许贸易媒体在制度上所投入的叙述与行业真正面临的问题不同步。（只是，你知道，一些疯狂的猜测！）对于新兴的行业和市场，你将无法获得有关正在发生的事情的明确数据，尤其是在公共范围内，这使得直接客户输入变得更加难以模仿。

In mature industries, there can be a lot of noise blurring the signal you want to capture. Sometimes, the industry old-timers who think they know everything are plain wrong about what’s coming ahead. Or, perhaps the trade press is institutionally invested in a narrative that’s out of sync with what problems really face the industry. (Just, you know, some wild guesses!) With nascent industries and markets, you will have much less definitive data about what’s going on, especially in the public purview, making direct customer input all the more inimitable.

但也许发展行业知识的最佳理由是——你知道我们会再说一遍——更好地培养与客户的同理心。现实情况是，即使是最好的产品经理也只会遇到一小部分最终用户或客户，特别是当您的产品是一个大型、成熟的产品时。当然，你可以从该样本中推断出许多有价值的教训，但很难确定你已经最大限度地减少了从中产生的所有偏见。培养对您所销售的行业的敏锐感觉是我们了解如何深入了解您所关心的人的角色和角色的最佳方式。你对他们的行业了解得越多，你就越能理解为什么你的客户会做他们所做的事情，并开始认识到你作为局外人的盲点。只有当你对这些有了很好的认识之后，你才能真正开始想象如何构建工具来在该行业中进行创新。

But perhaps the best reason to develop your industry knowledge is—you knew we’d say it again—to better develop empathy with your customers. The reality is that even the best product managers will only ever likely meet a small sample of their end users or customers, particularly if your product is a large, mature one. You can extrapolate a lot of valuable lessons from that sample, to be sure, but it’s difficult to be sure you have minimized all the bias you can from it. Developing a keen sense of the industry you sell into is the best way we know how to deeply understand the personas and roles of the folks you care about. The more you understand about their industry, the better you can grasp why your customers do the things they do and begin to recognize your own blind spots as an outsider. Only after you have a good sense of those can you truly begin to imagine how to build tools to innovate forward in that industry.

让我们从四个具体主题开始，无论行业成熟度如何，这些主题都应该适用。还有很多其他的，但这些将成为您建立市场知识的坚实基础。

Let’s begin with four specific topics that should be applicable regardless of industry maturity. There are many others, but these will serve as a strong foundation for building your market knowledge.

您的市场的基础知识

The Basics of Your Market

您的总潜在市场 (TAM)。您的产品具有 TAM，但即使是特定功能也可能使您能够通过单独的 TAM 在新的或广阔的市场中竞争。如果您的公司相当成熟，它将拥有成熟的企业战略职能，可以研究和更新您已经参与竞争的任何市场的 TAM 计算，并且应该渴望帮助开发新的 TAM，以支持成功进入新市场带来的增长。如果您的公司没有做到这一点，您可以从估算开始。请注意，您通常可以从 IDC 或其他行业分析师等公司获得 TAM，但根据我们的经验，软件公司自己的估计往往要优越得多，部分原因是它们让您有机会用自己的术语而不是其他人的术语来定义市场。通常过于笼统的术语。（事实上​​，我们经常发现这些市场中“运营商”的估计通常比银行家或分析师的估计现实得多。）查看竞争对手的财务报表或资金情况，并向后推算收入。将所有主要竞争对手的数据加起来，您就已经上路了。虽然最好有一个“批准的”TAM 计算，但事情的本质是最重要的：认真了解您的市场份额和总机会。

Your Total Addressable Market (TAM). Your product has a TAM, but even a specific feature might enable you to compete in a new or broadened market, with a separate TAM. If your company is reasonably mature, it will have a developed corporate strategy function which researches and updates TAM calculations for any market where you already compete, and it should be eager to help develop new TAMs to support the growth that comes with entering new markets successfully. If none of this is in place at your company, you can begin by estimating. Note that you can often get TAMs from firms like IDC or other industry analysts, but in our experience software companies’ own estimates are often far superior, in part because they give you the opportunity to define a market in your own terms rather than someone else’s often too-generic terms. (In fact, we often find that estimates from “operators” in these markets are usually far more realistic than those of bankers or analysts.) Look at your competitors’ financial statements or funding, and work backward to a guess at revenue. Add that up across all major competitors, and you are on your way. Although it is best to have an “approved” TAM calculation, the essence of the thing is most important: be deliberate about understanding your market share and your total opportunity.

TAM 估算的伟大之处在于，它为客户解决问题的价值和解决该问题对您自己的公司的价值。假设您拥有 5 亿美元的 TAM，并且您认为通过开展某个项目，您实际上可以在未来两年内获得其中的 10%。5 亿美元的数字让您可以将客户问题的规模与您可以解决的其他问题进行比较；换句话说，知道市场可以支持 5 亿美元的支出来解决一个问题（或一组问题），您就可以衡量哪些问题最值得解决。如果你可以合理地追求 5 亿美元市场的 10% 或 20 亿美元市场的 10%，你当然知道你会选择哪个。但除此之外，如果您认为自己可以占领 5 亿美元市场的 10%，那么您的公司的机会就价值 5,000 万美元。

The great thing about a TAM estimate is that it provides context to both the value to your customers of solving a problem and the value to your own company of solving that problem. Suppose that you have a $500 million TAM and you think you can realistically capture 10% of it within the next two years by taking on a certain project. The $500 million number gives you a way to compare the size of the customer problem with other problems you could solve; in other words, knowing that the market can support $500 million of spend to solve a problem (or set of problems) gives you a way to gauge which problems are most worth solving. If you could reasonably pursue 10% of a $500 million market or 10% of a $2 billion market, of course you know which you would choose. Beyond that, though, the estimate that you think you can capture 10% of a $500 million market tells you that the opportunity for your company is worth $50 million.

与 TAM 密切相关（通常包含在公司战略团队可能向您提供的任何 TAM 数据中）的是复合年增长率 (CAGR)，它表示市场的增长率。我们不会深入阐述 CAGR（您可以轻松地用 Google 搜索），但简单地说，它可以帮助您了解 TAM 包含的一组客户问题对您的潜在客户的重要性和价值增长的速度有多快。考虑表 7-1中提出的两个机会。

Closely related to TAM (and usually included in any TAM data that your corporate strategy team might offer you) is Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR), which conveys the rate of growth for a market. We will not do an in-depth exposition of CAGR (you can easily Google it), but simply put, it helps you to understand how fast the set of customer problems encompassed by a TAM is growing in importance and value to your potential customers. Consider the two opportunities presented in Table 7-1.

表 7-1。TAM 和 CAGR 示例图
五年内市场占有率 塔姆 复合年增长率（未来五年）

市场1

Market 1

30%

30%

5亿美元

$500 million

24.5%

24.5%

市场2

Market 2

25%

25%

7.5亿美元

$750 million

7.5%

7.5%

乍一看，5 亿美元的 30% 是 1.5 亿美元，而 7.5 亿美元的 25% 是 1.88 亿美元，所以也许您宁愿解决市场 2 所代表的问题集。但 CAGR 又增加了一层。实际上，通过推出新产品和功能来真正获得额外的市场份额需要时间。在采用直销模式的企业软件中更是如此，您受到销售和续订周期的约束；在我们的世界中，大多数客户并不是简单地打开电子商务表单并输入信用卡来购买您的软件。五年后，市场 1 的 30%（复合年增长率为 24.5%）将成为价值 3.6 亿美元的机会，而市场 2 的 25%（复合年增长率为 7.5%）将成为价值 2.5 亿美元的机会。请记住，不要只看 TAM 的表面价值，而应将 CAGR 纳入您选择投资的考虑因素中，

At first glance, 30% of $500 million is $150 million, whereas 25% of $750 million is $188 million, so perhaps you would rather attack the problem set represented by Market 2. But CAGR adds another layer. Realistically, actually capturing additional market share by shipping new products and features takes time. This is even more true in enterprise software with direct sales models, where you are bound by sales and renewal cycles; in our world, most customers are not simply rolling up to an ecommerce form and entering a credit card to buy your software. Five years from now, 30% of Market 1, with its 24.5% CAGR, becomes a $360 million opportunity, whereas 25% of Market 2 at 7.5% compound annual growth is a $250 million opportunity. Remember not to take TAM at face value, but rather factor CAGR into how you think about selecting your investments, because you are not competing in static markets.

您的市场驱动力。影响人们对您的产品和行业的看法的市场主要趋势是什么？移动连接的爆炸性增长是否正在改变消费者与您所服务的品牌的互动方式？CRM 技术的进步是否意味着更多品牌正在向客户提供个性化优惠？更好的内存数据库的开发是否会改变客户的成本状况？您的客户行业中是否存在其他所有竞争对手都被迫与之竞争的大型竞争对手？了解这些趋势是什么，并明智地猜测它们对您产品的未来意味着什么。

Your market drivers. What are the major trends in the market that are affecting how people think about your product and your industry? Is the explosive growth of mobile connectivity changing how consumers interact with the brands you serve? Do advancements in CRM technology mean that more brands are presenting personalized offers to customers? Is the development of better in-memory databases changing cost profiles for your customers? Are there mega-competitors in your customers’ industry that all others are forced to compete against? Learn what these trends are and have an informed guess at what they mean for the future of your product.

这些知识从哪里来？在某种程度上，它只需要成为技术的学生，而不仅仅是在自己的行业中。市场驱动因素通常似乎与您的产品关系不大或毫无关系。就像“你看不到的飞机会把你击落”的比喻一样，看似与你的产品完全无关的技术趋势最终可能会颠覆你的整个行业。因此，您需要了解周围的世界，并观察技术如何改变商业和消费者世界中的其他市场和生活。

Where does this knowledge come from? To some extent, it simply requires being a student of technology, and not just in your own industry. Market drivers often seem to have little or nothing to do with your product. Like the analogy that “it is the airplane you don’t see that will shoot you down,” technology trends that seem totally unrelated to your product can end up turning your entire industry on its head. So, you need to be aware of the world around you and observe how technology is changing other markets and lives in both the business and consumer world.

我们俩都曾在网络分析行业担任产品经理。2009 年，网络分析蓬勃发展并席卷了整个世界，因为整个企业才刚刚开始认识到了解消费者网络行为的价值。对于这个领域的任何人来说，在网络上目光短浅和加倍努力都是很容易的。但这个行业精明的产品经理会看到 iPhone，特别是 App Store（因此选择 2009 年作为例子）的巨大成功，并立即意识到市场即将由彻底重新定位品牌和消费者的互动方式，以及消费者如何从根本上思考技术。从表面上看，App Store（和 Google Play）的推出与网络分析没有直接关系，但同时，它也与网络分析有关的一切。网络分析市场即将被“数字分析”市场完全取代，该市场将网络和移动应用程序视为同一客户旅程的一部分。意识到移动的增长及其作为市场驱动因素对网络分析行业的潜在影响，需要产品经理关注自己世界之外的技术。

Both of us have worked as product managers in the web analytics industry. In 2009, web analytics was humming along and taking over the world as the enterprise at large was really just beginning to grasp the value of understanding their consumers’ web behaviors. It would have been easy for anyone in this field to have tunnel vision and double down on the web. But an astute product manager in this industry would have seen the wild success of the iPhone and, in particular (hence the choice of the year 2009 for this example), the App Store and immediately realized that the market was about to be driven by a complete reorientation of how brands and consumers interact, and indeed how consumers think about technology at a very fundamental level. The introduction of the App Store (and Google Play) did not directly, on the face of it, have anything to do with web analytics, but at the same time, it had everything to do with web analytics. The web analytics market was about to be entirely superseded by a “digital analytics” market that treated web and mobile app as parts of the same customer journey. Awareness of both the growth of mobile and its potential impact on the web analytics industry as market drivers would have required a product manager to be paying attention to technology outside of her own world.

如果您成功地识别出最相关的市场驱动因素，您通常可以在现有市场中找到新兴市场或新兴人物（例如 2009 年之后不久的“移动产品经理”），这两者都可以代表您作为产品经理的机会。

If you are successful in recognizing the most relevant market drivers, you can often find emerging markets or emerging personae in existing markets (such as the “mobile product manager” shortly after 2009), both of which can represent opportunity for you as a product manager.

您的客户和潜在客户面临的最常见问题。是什么阻碍了您的客户按照他们希望的速度增长？您的公司可以如何提供帮助？如果您花足够的时间与客户交谈，您就会发现模式开始出现。他们可能不会都使用相同的词语，但您会意识到他们实际上在问相同的事情。（也许是一个极端的例子，我们有过这样的经历，行业会议上连续五次会议都围绕同一个普遍问题。）尽管有多种方法可以了解您的客户和潜在客户面临的问题，但我们不这样做相信有一种值得的替代品可以代替花时间与客户实际谈论他们的想法。让客户向你敞开心扉说出他们真正担心的事情是一项艰巨的任务。

The most common problems your customers and prospects face. What is preventing your customers from growing as fast as they would like, and how can your company help? If you spend enough time talking to customers, you will see patterns begin to emerge. They might not all use the same words, but you will recognize that they are really asking about the same things. (As perhaps an extreme example, we have had experiences in which five consecutive meetings at industry conferences all centered around the same general problem.) Even though there are a number of ways to learn about the problems your customers and prospects face, we do not believe that there is a worthy substitute for spending time actually talking to your customers about what is on their mind. Getting customers to open up to you about what really worries them is a difficult task.

您的竞争格局。首先，警告一下：太多的产品经理对竞争着迷，通常是无意的，而不知道竞争正在发生。在竞争过程中，他们最终依赖市场领导者的产品战略来定义自己的产品战略，或者相信对竞争对手的全面了解将使他们能够抵御威胁。从长远来看，这两种方法都行不通。也就是说，了解你与谁竞争、为什么他们有时会获胜以及你的相对优势是什么是很有价值的。这正是老式“SWOT 分析” 1的价值所在。从市场知识的角度来看，这很重要，因为您的销售团队将需要它，并且因为您经常可以发现竞争产品中存在无人解决的问题的漏洞。

Your competitive landscape. First, a word of warning: too many product managers become obsessed with the competition, usually unintentionally, without knowing that it is happening. Through the process of competition, they end up relying on the market leader’s product strategy to define their own, or believing that knowing their competitor inside and out will allow them to fend off threats. Neither of these approaches works in the long term. That said, it is valuable to know who you compete with, why they sometimes win, and what your relative strengths are. This is where a good ol’ fashioned “SWOT analysis”1 is worthwhile. From a market knowledge perspective, this is important because your sales team will need it, and because you can often spot gaping holes in your competitive set offerings where there is a problem that no one is solving.

请记住，市场知识的目的是让您能够设定和管理产品或功能的愿景。任何能够帮助你走进一个满是高管的房间并解释为什么客户需要你所提议的东西的东西都是好的。我们将在本书后面讨论如何引导对话。

Remember that the purpose of market knowledge is to allow you to set and manage the vision for a product or feature. Anything that helps you walk into a room full of executives and explain why customers need whatever you’re proposing is good. We’ll get into how you should lead that conversation later in the book.

了解您的市场

Learning Your Market

获取市场知识的过程虽然对于行业新手来说通常很困难，但也相当简单。与所有类型的知识一样，这需要时间来掌握，但以下资源可以帮助您提高专业知识。

The process to obtain market knowledge, although often difficult for newcomers to an industry, is also fairly straightforward. As with all types of knowledge, this takes time to master, but the following resources can help accelerate your expertise.

客户会议

Customer Meetings

正如上一节所述，没有什么可以替代这一点。大多数人喜欢谈论他们做了什么以及为什么这样做，特别是如果你赢得了他们的信任。我们通常发现客户愿意接受采访，而且往往愿意分享他们对自己公司和面临的挑战的看法。在我们观察的一个团队中，产品经理被要求每个季度至少召开六次现场客户会议，这迫使原本忙碌的产品负责人离开办公室，以便他们能够了解市场和客户问题。即使您无法广泛旅行，电话交谈也是一个很好的开始。在这些对话之前制定基本的相互保密协议可能会有所帮助，以增强客户对您的信任，也可以让您比在公开场合更坦诚地介绍自己的产品策略。请记住：您正在努力了解让客户彻夜难眠的本质。

As mentioned in the previous section, nothing can replace this. Most people like to talk about what they do and why they do it, especially if you’ve earned their trust. We have usually found customers willing to be interviewed and, more often than not, willing to share their views of their own companies and the challenges they are facing. On one team that we observed, product managers were required to conduct at least six in-person customer meetings each quarter, which forced otherwise busy product leaders out of the office so they could learn about market and customer problems. Even if you cannot travel extensively, phone conversations are a great start. It can be helpful to work up a basic mutual Non-Disclosure Agreement prior to these conversations to enhance your customer’s trust in you and also to allow you to be a bit more forthcoming with your own product strategy than you would be in public. Remember: you’re trying to get to the essence of what keeps your customer up at night. That is where you will find willingness to pay for software.

笔记

此建议也适用于与非客户的会议。尽管您的大部分时间可能会花在与客户在一起，因为他们了解您当前的产品，可以作为讨论其业务目标和问题时的背景，但潜在客户、前客户以及选择您的竞争对手而不是您的公司都提供了有价值的学习经验这也将使您更深入地了解值得解决的客户问题。

This advice is also applicable to meetings with noncustomers. Although much of your time will likely be spent with customers because they have knowledge of your current product offering to serve as context when discussing their business objectives and problems, prospects, former customers, and companies who chose your competitor over you all provide worthwhile learning experiences that will also give you deeper insight into customer problems worth solving.

只要有可能，请一两名工程师和一名用户体验设计师加入您参加这些会议。工程师非常擅长解决问题。它们是您最好的创新的大部分来源。将他们直接与客户联系起来，给了他们一个（不幸的是，非常罕见的）机会来直接培养同理心。与其让你向他们发送一堆你做的笔记（这些笔记可能读起来枯燥且没有人情味），他们有机会结识一个真正的人，有真正的动机和真正的挑战。这将彻底解决客户问题中固有的挫败感，并且通常会在开发过程结束时产生更好的软件解决方案。让工程师和设计师参与这些客户会议的价值如何强调都不为过。

Whenever possible, have an engineer or two and a UX designer join you for these meetings. Engineers are great at solving problems. They are where much of your best innovation will come from. Connecting them directly to the customer gives them an (all-too-rare, unfortunately) opportunity to develop empathy on a first-hand basis. Rather than having you send them a bunch of notes that you took, which can read as dry and impersonal, they have an opportunity to meet a real human being, with real motivations and real challenges. This will hammer home the frustration inherent in the customer problem and generally produce better software solutions at the end of the development process. We cannot stress enough how valuable it is to involve engineers and designers in these customer meetings.

客户访谈有多种类型，并且都以不同的方式具有指导意义；您何时采用每种类型将取决于多种因素，例如您在给定项目的开发过程中所处的阶段、客户的成熟度等等。让我们简要关注一些对于理解客户问题特别有帮助的内容。

There are a variety of types of customer interviews, and all of them are instructive in different ways; when you employ each kind will depend on a variety of factors such as where you are in the development process for a given project, your customer’s maturity, and more. Let’s focus briefly on a few that are particularly helpful for understanding customer problems.

发现采访

Discovery interviews

发现访谈可能是由产品团队驱动的最常见的客户访谈类型。它涉及与一个或多个人坐在客户办公室现场并进行某种形式的公开对话。工程和用户体验都可以参与（亲自或远程），或者至少有另一个产品经理参与，这样你就能有多个耳朵参与讨论。发现访谈的目的是更好地了解客户面临的阻碍他们成长的挑战。当您与许多客户会面时，模式就会出现。您将把一家公司无法确定营销支出的投资回报率与另一家公司有关消费者旅程的问题联系起来，这将在您的脑海中具体化您的产品或功能的方向。

A discovery interview is probably the most common type of customer interview driven by the product team. It involves sitting with one or multiple individuals on site at a customer’s office and having some form of open dialog. Both/either engineering and UX can be involved, too (in-person or remotely), or at least another product manager so that you have multiple ears on a discussion. The goal of a discovery interview is to better understand the challenges facing your customer that are preventing them from growing. As you meet with many customers, patterns will emerge. You will make connections between one company’s inability to determine ROI on marketing spend and another company’s questions about the consumer journey that will crystallize in your mind a direction for your product or feature.

发现访谈的目的不是让客户告诉您他们希望在您的产品中看到哪些功能或您应该收购哪些公司。客户喜欢尝试为您进行创新，当然迎合他们是可以的。你时不时会遇到一个真正伟大的想法，鼓励你的客户像技术专家一样思考是件好事，但他们没有你的观点。他们并不是那些与其他数十家公司谈论他们的问题并识别指向真正机会的模式的人。个别客户有一系列独特的问题，并希望这些问题今天得到解决。你的工作是弄清楚他们明天会遇到什么问题，并解决这些问题。

The purpose of discovery interviews is not to have the customer tell you what features they want to see in your product or which companies you should acquire. Customers love to try to innovate for you, and of course it is fine to humor them. Every now and then you come across a truly great idea, and it’s good to encourage your customers to think as technologists, but they do not have the perspective that you have. They are not the ones talking to dozens of other companies about their problems and identifying patterns that point to real opportunities. An individual customer has a unique set of problems, and wants those problems solved today. Your job is to figure out what problems they are going to have tomorrow, and solve those.

《创智赢家》（ Shark Tank）成名的马克·库班（Mark Cuban ）（以及其他著名企业）描述了一家软件公司，该公司曾经拥有一流的产品：

Mark Cuban of Shark Tank fame (among other notable ventures) described a software company that once had a best-in-class product:

然后就犯了一个致命的错误。它询问客户希望在产品中看到哪些功能，然后他们提供了这些功能。需要提醒企业家[还有产品经理！]，知道他们不知道什么不是他们的客户的工作。换句话说，您的客户在完成工作时已经够艰难的了。他们不会花时间尝试重塑他们的行业或他们的工作方式。当然，你时不时会遇到例外。但你不能让公司相信你会在你的客户中找到那个人。您的客户可以告诉您哪些事情被破坏了以及他们希望如何让他们开心。听他们说。让他们开心。但不要依赖它们来为您的产品或服务制定未来路线图。那是你的工作。

Then it made a fatal mistake. It asked its customers what features they wanted to see in the product, and they delivered on those features. Entrepreneurs [and also product managers!] need to be reminded that it’s not the job of their customers to know what they don’t. In other words, your customers have a tough enough time doing their jobs. They don’t spend time trying to reinvent their industries or how their jobs are performed. Sure, every now and then you come across an exception. But you can’t bet the company on your finding that person among your customers. Your customers can tell you the things that are broken and how they want to be made happy. Listen to them. Make them happy. But don’t rely on them to create the future roadmap for your product or service. That’s your job.

因为您正在尝试创造未来，而不仅仅是满足客户今天想要的东西，询问他们想要什么，或者他们是否会购买功能 X，通常不是特别有效。但是，带着对做事方式、为什么这样做以及阻碍增长的差距的真正好奇心，深入挖掘他们的业务需求，是非常有效的。有时，产品本身几乎不会出现在这些讨论中，这可能违反直觉，意味着您走在正确的轨道上。

Because you are trying to invent the future, not just deliver on what customers want today, asking them what they want, or whether they would buy Feature X, is usually not particularly effective. But digging into their business needs with genuine curiosity about the way things are done, why they are done that way, and where there are gaps preventing growth, is tremendously effective. Sometimes, the product itself hardly comes up in these discussions, which may counterintuitively mean that you’re on the right track.

当你担任产品经理时，你将成为一名专家面试官。你可能很快就会发现自己在批评职业篮球比赛结束后向球员提问的节奏作家，或者你最喜欢的新闻媒体上的谈话者。进行一次良好的客户访谈也没有什么不同。您想要提出与当前主题相关的好的、发人深省的问题，并能够真正倾听并根据个人的回答深入探讨后续问题。以下是进行良好的发现访谈的其他一些关键：

In your time as a product manager, you will become an expert interviewer. You might soon find yourself critiquing the beat writer asking questions of players after a professional basketball game, or the talking heads on your favorite news outlet. Conducting a good customer interview is not all that different; you want to ask good, thought-provoking questions that are relevant to the topic at hand and be able to truly listen and dig into follow-up questions based on the individual’s response. Here are a few other keys to conducting a good discovery interview:

  • 与各种角色交谈，包括买家、您的主要/二级/三级用户等。请记住，您正在尝试了解一家公司如何成长或不成长，并且许多角色都会影响该故事。如果您正在开发电子邮件营销产品，请不要只与电子邮件营销人员交谈。与运营电子商务渠道的产品经理交谈。了解他们对公司最大的营销挑战的看法。这可能很困难，因为不熟悉您的产品的人可能不太愿意为您腾出时间，但只要有耐心和明确的指导，您的一些客户就会向您介绍那些会给您完全不同（且非常有价值）观点的人。

  • Talk to a variety of personas, including the buyer, your primary/secondary/tertiary users, and more. Remember, you’re trying to get a feel for how a company is growing or not growing, and many roles factor into that story. If you are working on an email marketing product, don’t just talk to the email marketers. Talk to the product managers who run the ecommerce funnel. Get their take on what the company’s biggest marketing challenges are, too. This can be difficult, because individuals unfamiliar with your product might be less willing to make time for you, but with patience and clear instruction, some of your customers will introduce you to people who will give you a completely different (and very valuable) perspective.

  • 除了您可能对特定产品领域或问题集提出的任何问题之外，还提出一系列一般性问题。如果您正在开发商业智能产品，那么您可能会在每次发现面试中提出以下一组问题：

    • 您认为贵公司开展商业智能的方式有何独特之处？贵公司对待数据的方式有何独特之处？

    • 哪些集成对于您的业务发展最重要？

    • 什么是典型的客户旅程？您认为您的公司如何利用当今的数据和见解影响该客户旅程？明年？

    • 您的组织以及您周围的组织的结构如何？

    • 您与其他各个团队的互动是如何进行的？渠道？频率？请求的语气和类型？

    • 怎么有___过去两年这里发生了变化吗？

    • 阻碍您的业务发展的三大因素是什么？

    • 为什么您的商业智能组织是这样构建的？

    • 你的策略是什么向前走？

    • 您雇用商业智能来做什么？

    • 您的高管如何看待/思考商业智能？

    • 告诉我一次分析（在任何情况下）让你看起来像摇滚明星的经历。

    • 告诉我一次我们的产品让您感到高兴的经历。

    • 您喜欢使用的产品的例子是什么？

    • 您想用目前很难做到的数字数据和客户数据做什么？它为什么如此重要？

    • 您最依赖商业智能/数据的三到五个非分析师角色是谁？他们的日常生活是怎样的？

    • 您的组织如何设定目标？你如何预测结果？

    • 与竞争对手相比，数据和分析如何为您带来竞争优势？您认为您的竞争对手在哪些方面比您更好地利用商业智能？

    • 贵公司现在正在努力利用数据解决哪些六个月前还没有解决的三大业务问题？

    请注意，这些是开放式问题。避免是/否问题，因为它们无法帮助您深入挖掘个人的动机或潜在需求。

  • Bring a series of general questions in addition to any that you might have about a particular product area or problem set. Here is a set of questions that you might bring to every discovery interview if you were working on a business intelligence product:

    • What do you think is unique about the way your company does business intelligence? What is unique about the way your company thinks about data?

    • What integrations are most important to the growth of your business?

    • What is a typical customer journey, and how do you see your company influencing that journey with data and insights today? Next year?

    • How is your organization—and the organization around you—structured?

    • How do your interactions with various other teams take place? Channel? Frequency? Tone and types of requests?

    • How has ___ changed here over the past two years?

    • What are the top three things preventing your business from growing?

    • Why is your business intelligence organization structured the way it is?

    • What is your strategy for going forward?

    • What do you hire business intelligence to do?

    • How do your executives view/think about business intelligence?

    • Tell me about a time that analysis (in any context) made you look like a rock star.

    • Tell me about a time that our product delighted you.

    • What is an example of a product that delights you to use?

    • What are you trying to do with your digital data and customer data that is really difficult to do today? Why is it important?

    • Who are your top three to five nonanalyst roles who rely on business intelligence/data? What are their daily lives like?

    • How does your organization set goals? How do you forecast results?

    • How are data and analytics a competitive advantage for you versus your competition? In what ways do you think your competition uses business intelligence better than you?

    • What are the top three business problems that your company is working on solving with data today that you weren’t six months ago?

    Notice that these are open-ended questions. Avoid yes/no questions because they won’t help you dig deep into an individual’s motivations or underlying needs.

  • 如果您询问客户整个企业面临哪些挑战，他们可能会也可能不会抓住问题的核心，但这就是为什么（没有双关语）我们喜欢“五个为什么”根本原因分析方法采访。其理论是，在询问一个人“为什么？”（大约）五次迭代之内。您可以找到所描述的初始问题背后的根本原因。你问企业面临什么问题，他们就会给出答案。你问为什么这是一个问题。他们回答。你问为什么这是一个问题。他们回答。起泡沫，冲洗，重复。到第五个“为什么”时，您应该找到问题的根本原因，从而激励您正在采访的用户采取重大行动。这应该是客户问题或者非常接近客户问题。例如：

    问：为什么贵公司的人员不使用您团队构建的仪表板？

    答：我想是因为仪表板并不能真正回答他们的问题。

    问：为什么仪表板不回答他们的问题？

    答：因为我们无法以对领导层有意义的方式可视化我们的销售和制造数据，而且如果没有领导层的兴趣，就不值得任何人花时间。

    问：为什么不能以对领导层有意义的方式可视化数据？

    答：因为他们从供应链的角度思考，但我们向他们报告的软件选项自然不会那样思考。

    问：为什么他们会从供应链的角度来思考？

    答：因为这确实是我们行业赖以生存的地方。减少供应链摩擦是像我们这样的公司降低成本、促进销售和保持竞争力的最佳途径。

  • If you ask a customer what challenges the business as a whole is facing, they might or might not get right to the heart of the matter, but this is why (no pun intended) we love the “Five Whys” root-cause analysis method of interviewing. The theory is that within (roughly) five iterations of asking a person “why?” you can get to the root cause behind the initial problem described. You ask what problems are facing the business, and they give an answer. You ask why that’s a problem. They answer. You ask why that’s a problem. They answer. Lather, rinse, repeat. By the fifth “why,” you should be at a root cause of a problem that motivates the users you’re interviewing to action in a big way. That should either be the customer problem or very close to it. For example:

    Q: Why are people at your company not using the dashboards your team builds?

    A: Because the dashboards don’t really answer their questions, I suppose.

    Q: Why don’t the dashboards answer their questions?

    A: Because we can’t visualize our sales and manufacturing data in a way that makes sense to leadership, and without leadership’s interest it isn’t worth anyone’s time.

    Q: Why can’t you visualize data in a way that makes sense to leadership?

    A: Because they think in terms of a supply chain, but our software options for reporting back to them don’t naturally think that way.

    Q: Why do they think in terms of a supply chain?

    A: Because that is really where our industry’s bread is buttered. Reducing supply chain friction is the best way for companies like ours to reduce costs, boost sales, and stay competitive.

在这个例子中（实际上只提出了四个“为什么”，但很容易包括第五个“为什么”，深入探讨为什么供应链管理是该行业增长的关键），产品经理提出的问题确立了业务增长的核心，而不是停留在业务增长的核心。专注于软件。作为产品经理，这正是你想要的。改善产品或客户体验的方法有无数种，但如果没有基本了解这些改进可能会如何影响客户的增长能力，您很可能会抓住救命稻草。请注意，此示例中的产品经理可能会在第一个“为什么”之后中断并询问“我们如何改进我们的仪表板？” 这是许多产品经理进行客户访谈的一种相当常见的方式。面试官可能收到这样的回复：“我们需要更好的可视化。” 客户甚至可能会说：“我们需要一种方法来可视化我们的供应链。” 但是，通过执行根本原因分析并深入挖掘问题，您可以为自己提供所需的基础，以找到客户尚无法想象的解决方案。
