In this example (which actually only took four “whys” but could easily have included a fifth that dug into why supply chain management is the key to growth in that industry), the product manager asking questions established the core of business growth rather than staying focused on the software. As a product manager, this is exactly what you want. There are countless ways to improve your product or your customer experience, but without a fundamental understanding of how these improvements might affect your customers’ ability to grow, you are likely grasping at straws. Note that the product manager in this example could have broken off after the first “why” and asked, “How can we improve our dashboards?” That is a fairly common way that many product managers might approach a customer interview. The interviewer might have received a response such as, “We need better visualizations.” The customer might have even said, “We need a way to visualize our supply chain.” But by performing a root-cause analysis and digging deeper into the problem, you give yourself the foundation needed to come up with solutions that your customer can’t even imagine yet.

观察

Observation

人们经常重复的格言是“客户经常说一套做一套”，这意味着仅靠访谈并不总能揭示所有令客户烦恼的事情。因此，只要有可能，请考虑将观察纳入您的客户互动程序中。观察有时可能是最难完成的访问类型，具体取决于最终用户如何使用您的产品，但通常是最有价值的。观察，有时称为人种学研究，实际上意味着与产品的最终用户坐在一起，看看他们如何与之交互。与发现式访谈不同，这种类型的访问的内容不受你的提问方式控制；而是由你的提问方式决定。它由最终用户的日常角色决定。工作见习也可以属于这一类别，并且可能会为您的产品及其潜在输出在客户组织中的实际使用方式添加更多背景信息。

The oft-repeated maxim that “customers often say one thing but do something else” means that interviews alone won’t always reveal everything that is vexing your customer. Thus, whenever possible consider including observation in your customer interaction repertoire. Observation can sometimes be the most difficult type of visit to pull off depending on how end users consume your product, but often the most valuable. Observation, sometimes referred to as ethnographic research, means literally sitting with end users of your product to see how they interact with it. Unlike discovery interviews, the content of this type of visit isn’t controlled by your line of questioning; it is determined by the end user’s day-to-day role. Job shadowing can also fit into this category and might add even more context for how your product as well as its potential outputs are actually used in your customers’ organizations.

理想情况下，在进行人种学研究时，只有当您不理解观察对象所做的事情时，您才会提出问题。除此之外，您让他们工作并注意他们在哪里遇到障碍、工作流程在哪里失败、他们需要在哪里与其他人合作等等。

Ideally, when doing ethnographic research, you would ask questions only when you don’t understand something that the subject of your observation did. Other than that, you let them work and notice where they run into roadblocks, where workflows fall down, where they need to work with others, and so on.

与发现访谈相比，您的目标是通过倾听和提问来尽可能多地了解客户问题，而观察更有可能揭示改善客户或用户体验的方法。

Compared to discovery interviews, where your goal is to learn as much as you can about customer problems by listening and questioning, observation is more likely to reveal ways that you can improve your customer or user experience.

季度业务回顾

Quarterly Business Reviews

季度业务评论 (QBR) 有很多名称，但无论您的组织如何称呼它们，在企业软件中，它们代表客户团队有机会与客户核实并播下下一笔交易的种子。几乎总是，您会受到邀请加入这些活动，通常是为了展示产品路线图或讨论产品的最新更新。与任何提出而不是倾听的要求一样，作为产品经理，您面临的挑战是充分利用这种情况。

Quarterly Business Reviews (QBRs) have many names, but whatever your organization calls them, in enterprise software they represent an opportunity for account teams to check in with customers and sow the seeds of the next deal. Almost always, you will join these by invitation, usually to present the product roadmap or discuss recent updates to your product. As with any request to present rather than to listen, your challenge as a product manager is to make the most of the situation.

您需要与您的管理层合作，找到适当的 QBR 参与程度；如果不加以控制，这些最终可能会消耗您太多的时间并分散您对构建和交付软件的注意力。当 QBR 被要求时，您并不总是需要参与其中。

You will need to work with your management to find the right amount of involvement in QBRs; left unchecked, these can end up consuming too much of your time and distracting you from building and shipping software. You don’t always need to be involved with QBRs when asked.

尽管您不想成为一台机器，按照命令重复您的产品路线图，但加入 QBR（以及通常在客户会议上展示您的产品路线图）有很多好处。当然，当您分享团队正在构建的内容时，您有机会提出探究性问题，并将这些问题转化为客户问题发现会议。但即使没有这些，展示路线图也可以帮助您在销售团队和客户中广为人知，这有助于在内部和外部建立您的品牌。此外，当您根据给定行业中的特定客户调整对路线图功能和用例的解释时，您会发现自己正在思考以前可能错过的新用例和要求。最后，它可以帮助您内化您的产品策略，

Although you do not want to become a machine, regurgitating your product roadmap on command, there are a number of benefits to joining QBRs (and to presenting your product roadmap in customer meetings generally). Of course, there is the opportunity to ask probing questions as you share what your team is building, and to turn those questions into customer problem discovery sessions. But even without that, presenting the roadmap helps you to get your name out there with your sales team and with customers, which helps build your brand both internally and externally. Additionally, as you adapt your explanation of roadmap features and use cases to a specific customer in a given industry, you will find yourself thinking up new use cases and requirements that you might have missed previously. Finally, it helps you internalize your product strategy, which will not only help you obsess about how you solve customer problems related to that strategy, but will also help you explain your product vision and strategy to internal stakeholders as you work to convince them of your ideas.

用户测试和原型设计

User testing and prototyping

我们将在本章中讨论的最后一种客户会议（尽管与客户互动的方式有很多）是用户测试和原型设计。尽管我们讨论的其他三种类型的会议可能与特定项目或功能想法相关，也可能不相关，但用户测试和原型设计始终如此。关于原型制作主题的书籍已经有数十本，并且有无数的软件公司可以很好地满足这一特定需求，因此我们在这里仅对其进行粗略的关注。

The last type of customer meeting that we will discuss in this chapter (although there are many more ways that you will interact with customers) is user testing and prototyping. Although the other three types of meetings we discussed might or might not be tied to a specific project or feature idea, user testing and prototyping always are. There have been dozens of books written on the topic of prototyping, and there are myriad software companies that serve this particular need quite well, so we will give it only a cursory attention here.

在制作原型时，您向最终用户展示产品设计（模型），或者理想情况下，向您打算构建的产品的交互式工作版本展示，以了解他们如何参与并获得反馈。原型设计是小型“敏捷”初创公司产品开发的支柱，但在企业软件中却往往被半途而废，这是不幸的。无论您当前的开发方法是什么，如果可以的话，请与您的工程同行合作，将原型设计添加到流程中。您从频繁、快速的原型设计中获得的反馈有助于确保您发布的功能实际上解决了您首先要解决的客户问题。没有它，你只能猜测，即使是最精明的产品经理也会有一半（或更多）猜错。

When prototyping, you are showing to an end user either a product design (mock-ups) or, ideally, an interactive, working version of something you intend to build to see how they engage with it and get their feedback. A pillar of product development in small, “agile” startups, prototyping tends to fall by the wayside in enterprise software, which is unfortunate. Whatever your current development method, work with your engineering counterparts to add prototyping to the process if you can. The feedback you get from frequent, rapid prototyping helps ensure that the feature you ship actually solves the customer problem that you set out to solve in the first place. Without it, you’re only guessing, and even the most astute product manager will guess wrong half the time (or more).

当我们说“快速”原型设计时，我们的意思是原型设计越多轮次（与客户会面、测试原型并将他们的反馈落实到原型和产品需求中）就越好。

When we say “rapid” prototyping, we mean that the more rounds of prototyping—meeting with a customer, testing your prototype, and implementing their feedback into the prototype and product requirements—you can do, the better.

召开客户会议

Getting Customer Meetings

安排和计划客户会议也可以通过多种方式进行。如果您已经在您的产品或行业工作了一段时间，您可能在各个品牌都有联系人，您可以直接与他们合作安排任何上述类型的客户会议（QBR 除外，QBR 通常由客户团队）。稍后会详细介绍这一点。

Getting customer meetings scheduled and planned also happens in a variety of ways. If you’ve been working on your product or in your industry for a while, you might have contacts at various brands, with whom you can work directly to schedule any of the aforementioned types of customer meetings (except QBRs, which are typically led by account teams). More on this in a moment.

如果没有，别担心；您可以通过两种好方法来寻找会面的客户。其中只有一个附有警告。

If not, don’t worry; there are two great ways for you to find customers to meet. And only one of them comes with a warning attached.

首先，使用数据。如果您对客户问题有一个假设并想要验证它，或者如果您有一个所有权领域希望帮助您的产品迈出下一步，那么各种数据可以帮助您找到可能是完美目标的客户讨论或观察。即使是像“不使用我们最近发布的功能的客户”或“位于美国的 10 亿美元 GMV（商品总价值）零售商”这样简单的内容，也可以缩小您的搜索范围，并帮助您找到合适的候选人。

First, use data. If you have a hypothesis about a customer problem and want to validate it, or if you have an area of ownership where you are looking to help your product take its next big step, various data can help you find customers who might be perfect targets for discussion or observation. Even something as simple as “customers who aren’t using our recently released features” or “one-billion-dollar-GMV (Gross Merchandise Value) retailers located in the US” can narrow down your search and help you identify good candidates to meet.

其次，利用您的现场组织。作为产品经理，您拥有整个客户群的权限，这意味着您经常会了解很多客户，但不如优秀的客户团队了解得那么深入。当您准备好深入研究客户问题时，请与您的客户成功团队或销售团队交谈，找出谁可能愿意进行对话。在许多情况下，这些团队很高兴能帮助您与他们的客户建立联系，因为产品团队的关注表明每个人对客户业务的关心程度。相比之下，在一些组织中，客户团队可能会对接触客户保持谨慎或保护态度，要么是因为有让客户不知所措的风险，要么是因为他们不了解产品对客户输入的需求。在这些情况下，首先向销售组织领导者解释你的方法可以打开很多大门。

Second, use your field organization. As a product manager, you have purview over your entire customer base, which means that you often get to know a lot of customers, but not as deeply as good account teams do. When you’re ready to dig into customer problems, talk to your customer success or sales teams to find out who might be open to brokering a conversation. In many cases, these groups are thrilled to help you connect with their customers, because attention from the product team shows how much everyone cares about the customer’s business. In some organizations, by contrast, account teams can be cagey or protective of access to customers, either due to the risk of overwhelming them or because they don’t understand product’s needs for customer input. In these cases, explaining your approach to sales organization leaders first can open a lot of doors.

不过，这里有一些警告。请注意不要让销售团队参加这些客户访谈。通常，以微妙但有意义的方式，一个明确目标是销售更多软件的团队的存在会改变客户回答问题的方式。您需要客户有完全的自由发言权，而不必担心这会在未来的谈判或销售推销中伤害他们。通常，产品经理在这方面具有可信度，这有助于客户向他们敞开心扉。通过客户团队安排客户会议时，您需要有礼貌但坚定：您请求帮忙，但他们没有被邀请参加舞会。（通常有效的妥协方法是在会议中安排一部分销售内容，并在他们离开时安排一部分时间，

A few warnings here, however. Beware of allowing the sales team to sit in on these customer interviews. Often, in subtle but meaningful ways, the presence of a team whose expressed purpose is to sell more software will change the way a customer responds to a question. You need the customer to have complete freedom to say anything, without fear that it will come back to hurt them in a future negotiation or sales pitch. Typically, product managers carry credibility in this regard which helps customers open up to them. You will need to be polite but firm when scheduling a customer meeting through an account team: you are asking for a favor, but they are not invited to the dance. (A compromise that often works is to have a portion of the meeting during which sales is included, and a part when they step away, or—even better—to meet alone with the customer and then have sales take everyone to dinner afterward!)

产品经理面临的常见问题之一是优先向哪一组客户学习。这在很大程度上是 B2B 软件特有的挑战，因为实施、用例和合同通常差异很大。您是否专注于高端市场、最大、最响亮的客户？您是否从客户群的每个细分群体中进行抽样？这里没有一个答案。这取决于多种因素：产品的成熟度、增长策略（您是否试图进入高端市场？还是进入低端市场以对冲颠覆性竞争对手？您是否正在向邻近市场扩张？等等）以及许多其他因素。然而，这是需要深思熟虑的事情。为了收集知识，您不会总是平等地对待每个客户，但这没关系。

One of the common questions that a product manager faces is which set of customers from which to prioritize learning. This is a challenge largely unique to B2B software, because implementations, use cases, and contracts often vary so widely. Do you focus on the high end of your market, your biggest and loudest customers? Do you sample from each segment of your customer base? There isn’t a single answer here. It depends on a variety of factors: the maturity of your product, your growth strategy (Are you trying to go upmarket? Or downmarket to hedge against a disruptive competitor? Are you expanding into an adjacent market? etc.), and many other things. However, it is something to be deliberate about. For the purposes of gathering knowledge, you will not always treat every customer equally, and that’s okay.

在每种类型的客户会议中，请确保您提前明确需要会见的人。如果您对希望解决的客户问题有所了解，您应该能够亲自挑选能够最有效地告诉您该问题的角色。如果没有，与对组织面临的挑战有深入了解的高管或高级资源人员会面是一个不错的起点。

In each type of customer meeting, make sure you are clear ahead of time about who you need to meet. If you know a bit about the customer problem you are hoping to solve, you should be able to hand-pick the roles that will be able to tell you about that problem most effectively. If not, meeting with executives or senior resources who have good visibility into the challenges facing the organization is a good place to start.

贸易媒体

Trade press

如果你在一个大的、成熟的行业中竞争，很可能已经有人写过相关文章了。当然，零售、旅游/酒店、医疗保健、营销、金融、非营利组织等大型行业领域都有大量的行业杂志、博客、时事通讯和其他媒体，它们除了研究自己的行业外什么也不做。您很可能不可能阅读有关您所在行业的所有内容（对于我们来说当然如此），并且您当然不应该尝试。随着您更加熟悉该行业的动态，您将能够浏览主要媒体并了解他们所关注的广泛主题。

If you compete in a big, mature industry, there are likely to be people writing about it already. Certainly, big industry segments like retail, travel/hospitality, healthcare, marketing, finance, nonprofit, and others have any number of trade magazines, blogs, newsletters, and other outlets that do nothing but study their own industry. It may well be impossible for you to consume all of what’s written about your industry (it certainly is for us), and you certainly shouldn’t try. As you become more familiar with the dynamics of the industry, you’ll be able to skim the major outlets and get a sense for the broad themes they’re focusing on.

分析师/研究报告

Analyst/research reports

尽管行业分析公司远非完美，有时甚至可笑地简化，但它们在市场知识领域有一个有价值的目的：它们与每个人交谈。他们与您的客户交谈。他们与你的竞争对手交谈。他们与竞争对手的客户交谈。他们会跟你说话。他们发布的报告是该研究的结果，并且经常指出现有产品背景下的市场问题。这些公司还经常发布有助于量化市场问题的调查。例如，如果知道 74% 的 COO 预计在未来 18 个月内增加支出来解决特定问题，这将为您提供构建特定产品所需的部分证据。分析师报告通常并不便宜，但它们通常免费提供一些信息，如果您认为它们包含对您的论点有很大帮助的见解，那么它们可以很好地利用预算。较大的组织可能会订阅分析师报告，因此，请咨询您的分析师关系团队，了解您可能已经拥有哪些访问权限。不过，请注意不要过度依赖分析师的言论。他们是一个很好的投入，但最好的产品经理已经是他们自己的分析师。

Although they are far from perfect, and occasionally laughably reductive, industry analyst firms serve a worthwhile purpose in the market knowledge sector: they talk to everyone. They talk to your customers. They talk to your competitors. They talk to your competitors’ customers. And they talk to you. The reports they put out are the result of that research, and often point out market problems within the context of existing offerings. These firms also frequently publish surveys that help to quantify market problems. For example, knowing that 74% of COOs expect to increase spending to solve a particular problem in the next 18 months gives you part of the evidence you need to go make the case to build a certain product. Analyst reports usually are not cheap, but they often provide some information free of charge and can be a good use of budget if you believe they contain an insight that will substantially help your argument. Larger organizations might have a subscription to analyst reports, so check with your analyst relations team to see what access you might already have. Be careful not to over-rely on what the analysts are saying, though. They’re a good input to have, but the best product managers are already their own analysts.

消耗一切

Consume everything

这可能是不言而喻的，但要利用公开渠道：博客、论坛、播客等。您会在您意想不到的地方找到市场知识。在您的产品中寻求帮助执行某些实用任务的论坛帖子可以提供有关他们试图解决的根本问题的线索。此内容的作者也可能成为很好的采访主题，以帮助您更深入地研究他们的挑战。

This might go without saying, but take advantage of publicly available channels: blogs, forums, podcasts, and so on. You will find market knowledge in places you might not expect. A forum posting asking for help doing a certain pragmatic task in your product can give clues about the underlying problem they are trying to solve. The authors of this content might also make great interview subjects to help you delve deeper into their challenges.

竞争对手

Competitors

像阅读竞争对手的博客一样简单的努力将帮助您了解他们如何看待市场以及他们的产品策略是什么。您可以决定是否要尝试在他们自己的游戏中击败他们，或者通过追求不同的利基或一组用例来采取补充方法。阅读他们的博客还可以帮助您了解他们的营销方式，这就是大多数科技公司传达其产品路线图的方式。这将告诉您他们如何看待市场，以及他们的买家和进入市场策略，所有这些都会影响他们的产品。如果他们对市场的看法与你的截然不同，请注意——他们错了吗？或者你可能是？

Efforts as simple as reading your competitors’ blogs will help you understand how they view the market and what their product strategy is. You can decide whether you want to try to beat them at their own game, or take a complementary approach by going after a different niche or set of use cases. Reading their blogs also helps you to understand their marketing, which is how most tech companies telegraph their product roadmaps. This will tell you how they view the market, as well as their buyers and their go-to-market strategy, all of which influence their product. If their view of the market seems significantly different than yours, take note—are they wrong? Or might you be?

赢/输分析

Win/loss analysis

最常被忽视的市场智慧来源之一是赢/输分析，您应该与销售团队合作帮助进行。与销售代表合作达成交易后，了解客户（或非客户）做出购买决定的原因：最重要的因素是什么，您的公司可以采取哪些不同的措施来赢得交易，等等。需要明确的是，对于产品经理来说，了解为什么输掉一笔交易通常比了解为什么赢得交易更有价值一个交易。两者都有助于传达市场知识，但前者给出了更清晰的信号，表明您当前的产品缺乏什么，这将帮助您在未来更好地竞争。同时，不要陷入“我也是”或“勾选”模式；在知道你的产品缺乏什么之后，找出如何让它以新的方式解决问题，尤其是当它预测了你的市场的未来趋势时。现在甚至有第三方公司专门帮助软件供应商进行赢/输分析（如果您有兴趣，我们可以帮助推荐一些很棒的软件）。

One of the most commonly overlooked sources of market wisdom is win/loss analysis, which you should help conduct in partnership with the sales team. Work with sales reps after a deal to understand why the customer (or noncustomer) made their buying decision: what the most important factors were, what your company could have done differently to win the deal, and so on. To be clear, understanding why you lost a deal is typically more valuable to a product manager than understanding why you won a deal. Both help convey market knowledge, but the former gives a much clearer signal about what is lacking in your current offering that will help you compete better in the future. At the same time, don’t slip into “me too” or “check the box” mode; after you know what your product lacks, figure out how to make it solve the problem in a new way, especially when that anticipates future trends in your market. There are even third-party firms that specialize now in helping software vendors perform win/loss analysis (and we can help recommend some great ones if you’re interested).

调查

Surveys

我们发现，定期调查我们自己的客户群可以提供独特的市场知识，就像分析公司进行的调查一样，可以为您的市场知识提供定量元素。这里一个明确的考虑因素是选择偏差，因此请确保提出的问题不会受到受访者已经是您的用户这一事实的影响（太多）。如果您有办法进行真正的随机抽样或对非客户和客户进行调查，我们强烈建议您这样做。如果不是，请认识到并坦诚地接受这样一个事实：调查结果可能会因对您的公司及其产品的熟悉程度和偏好而受到影响。

We have found that periodically surveying our own customer bases can provide unique market knowledge that, like the surveys conducted by analyst firms, gives a quantitative element to your market knowledge. One clear consideration here is selection bias, so make sure to ask questions that won’t be influenced (too much) by the fact that respondents are already your users. If you have the means to do true random sampling or to survey noncustomers as well as customers, we strongly advise it. If not, recognize and be open about the fact that the survey results can be colored by familiarity with, and preference for, your company and its products.

客户咨询委员会

Customer Advisory Boards

最后但同样重要的是，建立（如果尚不存在）一小群客户来为您的产品提供咨询委员会服务。组织和管理客户咨询委员会 (CAB) 的方法有很多种，但要确保由能够传授真实市场知识的人员担任。这些人很可能是你产品的执行“买家”，但也不一定。他们应该是对自己的公司和您的行业足够了解的人，可以帮助指出您产品策略中的漏洞，或者警告您需要注意的即将出现的趋势。如果您幸运的话，他们甚至可能既不购买也不使用您的产品，但可以与您和 CAB 的其他成员分享对相邻市场或角色的独特视角。

Last but certainly not least, establish (if it does not already exist) a small group of customers to serve on an advisory board for your product. There are a variety of ways to organize and conduct a Customer Advisory Boards (CAB), but ensure that you fill it with individuals who can impart real market knowledge. These might well be the executive “buyers” of your product, but not necessarily. They should be people who know their company and your industry well enough that they can help point out holes in your product strategy, or warn you about upcoming trends to be aware of. If you are fortunate, they might even be people who neither buy nor use your product, but who can share with you and the other members of the CAB a unique perspective on an adjacent market or persona.

让 CAB 配备产品的“高级用户”可能很诱人，但我们发现这些人可能在战术层面上进行操作，并且缺乏对预算决策、公司战略等主题的洞察力。请记住，您希望人们能够审视自己的公司并回答以下问题：“是什么让我们的首席执行官彻夜难眠？” 你还需要那些极其诚实的人，但他们也希望看到你的公司和你的产品取得成功。您需要定期与 CAB 会面，但节奏和媒介（面对面、视频会议等）将根据您的需求而有所不同。

It can be tempting to staff your CAB with “power users” of your product, but we have found that such individuals might operate at a more tactical level and lack insight into topics such as budgetary decisions, corporate strategy, and so on. Remember, you want people who will be able to look at their own companies and answer the question, “What keeps our CEO awake at night?” You will also want people who will be brutally honest, but who also want to see your company and your product succeed. You’ll want to meet with your CAB regularly, but cadence and medium (in-person, video conference, etc.) will vary based on your needs.

行业会议

Industry conferences

在这里，我们指的不是科技活动（尽管这些活动在其他方面也很有用）。如果您的目标行业定期举行会议，重点关注其内部正在发生的主要趋势……那么，您可能会想参加。即使在大型会议上，只需参加演讲会议、小组讨论和仔细浏览供应商展示区，也能学到很多东西。小型会议也具有独特的价值。两端的参与者类型往往不同，这可能会产生令人耳目一新的不同观点。当我们的一个团队成员参加这样的会议时，标准做法是写一份旅行报告，并在返回后与团队其他成员分享，解释他们所看到的内容以及团队其他成员可能学到的东西从中。

Here, we don’t mean tech events (though those can be useful in other ways). If your target industry holds conferences periodically that focus on major trends going on within it…well, it’s a no-brainer that you might want to attend. Even at the mega-conferences, there is much to be learned simply by attending speaking sessions, panels, and perusing the vendor showcase floor. The smaller conferences can be uniquely valuable, too. The types of attendees at either end of the scale tend to be different, which can result in refreshingly varied perspectives. When members of one of our teams attend such a conference, it’s standard practice to write up a trip report and share it with the rest of the team when they return, explaining what they saw and what the rest of the team might be able to learn from it.

社交媒体

Social media

你知道我们要到这里了，对吧？@BenjaminGaines和@BlairReeves都是热情的Twitter 用户。在我们的行业（营销技术）中，社交媒体是一个主要的市场情绪、竞争情报以及（通常）用户反馈的来源。几乎所有行业在社交媒体上都有一些用户社区（不一定只是 Twitter，但尤其如此），产品经理在这些在线社区中占有一席之地也是明智之举。我们都相信 Twitter 和博客对于我们的企业产品管理职业生涯绝对至关重要。您的里程可能会有所不同，当然，不要在这个领域投入太多时间；但作为行业知识的来源，社交媒体可以成为主要资源。

You knew we were getting here, right? Both @BenjaminGaines and @BlairReeves are enthusiastic Twitter users. In our industry (marketing technology), social media is a major source of both market sentiment, competitive intelligence, and, not infrequently, user feedback. Almost any industry has some community of users on social media (not necessarily just Twitter, but there especially), and it’s a smart move for product managers to have a presence in those online communities, as well. We both believe that Twitter as well as blogging has been absolutely key to our careers in enterprise product management. Your mileage may vary, and, of course, don’t pour too much of your time into this area; but as a source of industry knowledge, social media can be a major resource.

客户访谈后

After the Customer Interview

与客户共度时光的部分价值来自于学会像客户一样思考，并通过寻求理解来培养同理心。花时间与客户交流是非常有价值的，这样您就可以代表他们与开发人员和设计师一起在众所周知的房间里，确保提供更好的产品。但是，当你能够从同事那里得到你的笔记和印象时，你就能从客户那里学到很多更务实的知识。如果您是产品管理团队的一员，希望您的队友也出去走走，进行采访并了解客户问题。通过共同分享和分析您的经验，您通常会得出以前不明显的新结论。

Part of the value of spending time with customers comes from simply learning to think like they think and developing empathy by seeking to understand them. There is a lot of value in simply spending time with customers so that you can represent them in the proverbial room with your developers and designers, ensuring a better product. But much of your more pragmatic learning from customers will come when you can bounce your notes and impressions off of colleagues. If you are part of a product management team, hopefully your teammates have also been out and about, holding interviews and learning about customer problems. By sharing and analyzing your experiences together, you will often reach new conclusions that hadn’t been apparent to you previously.

实现这一目标的方法有很多种，但没有一种方法适用于所有公司、团队、产品成熟度等。以下是一些可能对您有效的常见方法：

There are a variety of ways to do this, and there is no one recipe that works in every company, team, product maturity, and so on. Here are some common approaches that may be effective for you:

  • 召开团队会议（每周、每两周或每月）以审查客户互动。与您的同事讨论您遇到的人、您选择他们的原因以及您希望学到什么。此外，讨论对话的进展情况、您获得的关键见解以及会议中提出的任何行动项目。这应该不是一次演示，而更像是一次讨论，您可以邀请同事更深入地探讨您在采访中分享的某些主题。您最终可能会转向与客户访谈无关的其他方向，但这没关系。访谈成为丰富信息海洋中的一个数据点，即使在您自己的产品重点之外，也可以帮助您识别模式。

  • Hold a team meeting (weekly, biweekly, or monthly) for the purpose of reviewing customer interactions. Talk with your colleagues about whom you met, why you chose them, and what you hoped to learn. Further, discuss how the conversation progressed, key insights you picked up on, and any action items coming out of the meeting. This should be less a presentation and more a discussion, where you invite your colleagues to probe deeper on certain topics that you share from your interview. You can end up veering off in other directions not related to your customer interview, and that’s okay. The interview becomes a data point in a rich sea of information that can help you identify patterns even outside of your own product focus.

  • 在内部 wiki 页面或类似的广泛使用的内部网站上分享您的面试笔记，并向您的团队成员提供链接以及具体信息请求输入或反馈。（这种方法的一个优点是它几乎可以无限扩展；如果房间里的人数超过少数，讨论就会变得无效，但您可以将 wiki 页面发送给数百名产品经理、开发人员、设计师、营销人员等。当这些角色无法与客户共处一室时，确保他们看到您学到的东西是下一个最好的事情。）从这种方法中获得价值的关键是要求您的同事查看文档中的特定要点并分享他们的想法。由于产品经理通常会被拉向一千个方向，因此除非您要求同事回应三到五个明确且具体的事情，否则指向一组注释的链接通常会被忽略。例如，您可能会问，“在这些说明中，您会看到 XYZ 公司表示，他们没有预算用于软件和从软件中获得真正价值所需的咨询。我希望您能帮助回顾一下他们对此的看法。根据您的经验，这是我们必须接受的挑战，还是您可以看到我们在软件中做一些事情来限制对服务的需求？” 向你的队友提出一些这样的问题，然后观察想法（以及想法的模式！）开始流动。

  • Share your interview notes on an internal wiki page or similar widely available internal site, and provide the link to your teammates along with specific requests for input or feedback. (One advantage of this approach is that it scales almost infinitely; discussion becomes ineffective with more than a handful of people in the room, but you can send the wiki page to hundreds of product managers, developers, designers, marketers, and so on. When these roles can’t be in the room with the customer, making sure they see what you learned is the next best thing.) The key to getting value from this approach is to ask your colleagues to review specific points in the document and share their thoughts. Because product managers are typically pulled in a thousand directions, a link to a set of notes will often go ignored unless there are three to five clear and specific things to which you are asking colleagues to respond. For example, you might ask, “In these notes you will see that XYZ Corp said they don’t have budget to spend on both software and the consulting required to get real value out of the software. I would love your help reviewing what they said about this. In your experience, is that a challenge we simply have to accept, or is there something you could see us doing in our software to limit the need for services?” Give your teammates a few questions like that, and watch the ideas (and patterns of ideas!) begin to flow.

  • 将客户问题提炼成书面故事或用例，并将其分发给团队成员以获取反馈。这样做的好处是简洁，并将你的教训变成具体的东西，看起来像是做某事的理由。这也可能是让你的客户对他人产生同理心的最有效方法。您可以要求您的同事审查这些客户问题，并讨论这些问题是否值得在产品中解决，而以牺牲您可以做的其他事情为代价。我们看到产品经理将这些故事变成了实际录制的视频，“演员”（通常是产品经理和同事）扮演客户，他们试图（但失败了）使用软件完成某件事。当做得好时，

  • Distill the customer problem into a written story or use case, and distribute that to teammates for feedback. This carries with it the advantage of conciseness, and turns your lessons into something concrete that looks like justification for doing something. This can also be the most effective way to produce empathy for your customer in others. You can ask your colleagues to review these customer problems and speak to whether these problems would be worth addressing in the product at the expense of other things you could do. We have seen product managers turn these stories into actual recorded videos, with “actors” (usually the product manager and colleagues) playing the customer, who is trying (and failing) to get something done using software. When done well, this approach to sharing what you learned in a series of interviews can be extremely effective in deepening awareness of, and empathy for, customer problems.

无论您采取什么方法，都不要让您从客户访谈中获得的知识停止。如果整个产品团队有机会从每次客户互动中共同学习，他们将更成功地生产有价值、可用的产品。

Whatever approach you take, don’t let the knowledge that comes from your customer interviews stop with you. The entire product team will be more successful in producing valuable, usable products if it has the opportunity to learn together from each customer interaction.

挑战您对市场的了解

Challenging What You Know About Your Market

你知道他们怎么说：打破所有规则，首先掌握它们是有帮助的。（从歌德到毕加索，许多历史伟人都对此做出了不同的贡献。）要了解市场的转变可能有多么重大，并能够识别预示这一转变的趋势，通常需要对市场动态有微妙的了解。能够及早识别这些变化，并将其与无意义的背景噪音区分开来，是他们所谓的“软心智”的一个特征，即对某个领域有深入的了解，但又足够谦虚和接受的能力。知道科技领域唯一不变的就是变化。

You know what they say: to break all the rules, it helps to first master them. (Variations on this have been attributed to many of history’s greats, from Goethe to Picasso.) Understanding how significant a shift in your market might be and being able to recognize the trends that portend it will often require a subtle appreciation for the dynamics of the market you compete in. Being able to recognize those shifts early on and distinguish them from meaningless background noise is a characteristic of what they call a “soft mind”—one that has a deep knowledge of a field, but is humble and receptive enough to know that the only constant in tech is change.

让我们举一个例子：企业软件即服务（SaaS）本身。

Let’s give an example: enterprise Software as a Service (SaaS) itself.

回到过去的糟糕日子，我们都被告知云计算永远不会完成“真正的业务”。所谓的专家们都信誓旦旦，有时甚至是众所周知的，“企业”永远不会采用这种软件即服务的胡言乱语。我们被告知你不能在云中执行“真正的企业工作负载”。现在听起来很奇怪，但即使到了 2010 年代初期，我们仍然记得那些老牌人（他们总是让你想起他们在该行业拥有数十年的经验），他们发誓 SaaS 作为一种模式“根本行不通” ”对于企业来说。我们不会在这里指名道姓，以免那些本来非常聪明的人感到尴尬。但这些人可能已经在某种技术和商业模式中生活了很长时间，以至于他们无法想象它以根本不同的方式运作，而且他们对尝试不太感兴趣。无论好坏，现在事实证明他们是错误的。

Back in the bad old days, we were all told that no “real business” would ever be done with cloud computing. The so-called experts all swore up and down, sometimes (in)famously, that “enterprises” would never adopt this software-as-a-service nonsense. We were told that you just couldn’t do “real enterprise workloads” in the cloud. It sounds bizarre now, but even as late as the early 2010s, we remember old established types (the ones who always remind you of the decades of experience they have in the industry) who swore that SaaS as a model “just wouldn’t work” for the enterprise. We won’t name names here to save those otherwise very smart people some embarrassment. But those folks had probably lived inside a certain technology and business model for so long that they just couldn’t imagine it working in a fundamentally different way, and they weren’t very interested in trying. For better or worse, they’ve been proven wrong now.

值得不断地重新审视你关于你所竞争的市场的前提，并且可能只是假设其中一些总是不正确或不完整的——你只是还不知道哪一个。企业 SaaS 不断发展并征服的许多业务用例和利基市场实际上是早期软件甚至现有软件已经服务的领域。其中一部分是 SaaS 提供的功能和成本模型的转变，其中一些可能是世代相传的。最近，我们开始看到更新的下一代 SaaS 解决方案通过针对特定用途或行业定制的功能来攻击根深蒂固的解决方案。灵活的现有企业正在快速获取和扩展功能，以跟上步伐。

It’s worth constantly revisiting your premises about the market you compete in, and probably just assuming that a few of them are always incorrect or incomplete—you just don’t know which, yet. Many of the business use cases and niches that enterprise SaaS has grown to conquer have actually been areas that earlier or even existing software already served. Part of this is a shift in the capabilities and cost models that SaaS provides, and some of it is probably generational. What we’ve begun to see more recently is newer, next-wave SaaS solutions attacking entrenched ones with functionality tailored for specific uses or industries. Nimble incumbents are acquiring and expanding feature functionality at a rapid clip to keep up.

换句话说，产品经理还有很多事情要做。

In other words, the product managers still have an awful lot to do.

概括

Summary

行业知识可以说是企业产品经理需要培养的最重要的领域专业知识。尽管许多垂直行业的内容几乎无穷无尽，但只有凭借来之不易的经验，产品经理才能开始理解什么是信号，什么是噪音。行业研究的形式有很多种，但向那些提供客户反馈的人提供信息至关重要。访谈、跟踪、调查等等——产品经理可以从客户（和用户！）那里获得的反馈形式几乎是无穷无尽的。这种初级行业研究最终使产品经理成为他们正在构建产品的行业的独特专家，而这是任何第三方研究报告都无法学到的。

Industry knowledge is arguably the most important type of domain expertise for an enterprise product manager to develop. Although there is nearly endless content available out there to consume about many industry verticals, only with hard-won experience does the product manager begin to understand what is signal and what is noise. There are many forms of industry research to begin with, but it is critical to inform those with customer feedback. Interviews, shadowing, surveys, and more—the forms of feedback product managers can take from customers (and users!) is nearly endless. This is the kind of primary industry research that eventually makes product managers unique experts on the industry they’re building products for, and which can’t be learned on any third-party research report.

项目经理简介

姓名：迈克·苏克马诺夫斯基

Name: Mike Sukmanowsky

职位： Parse.ly 产品副总裁

Title: VP of Product, Parse.ly

您工作中最难学习的部分是什么？

What have been the most difficult parts of your job to learn?

从解决问题到设定愿景。早期，我们专注于寻找人们关心并愿意花钱解决的问题的解决方案。好消息是，这些问题并不缺乏。坏消息是，并非所有这些问题都是相互关联的。我们收到的功能请求从客户的角度来看完全有意义，但似乎它们是沿着产品愿景的两个不同轴对齐的。对于小团队来说，您可以暂时忽略这种紧张局势，因为容量一次仅限于一项功能，并且您需要快速行动。但当你变得更大并释放在多个战线上前进的能力时，这种紧张感再次浮出水面。我们意识到我们没有一个很好的框架来评估我们应该接受哪些不同的请求，并开始提出更难的问题：我们想要创造什么样的未来？我们存在的理由是什么？哪些事情是我们相信而没有人相信的？我不知道大多数成年人是否能回答这些问题，因此公司也会发现这是一项困难的工作也就不足为奇了。

Going from problem solving to vision setting. In the early days, we focused on finding solutions to problems that people cared about and would pay money for. The good news was, there was no shortage of those problems. The bad news was that not all of those problems were connected to one another. We’d get feature requests that made complete sense from our customers’ point of view, but seemed like they were aligned along two different axes of product vision. With a small team, you can ignore this tension for a bit since capacity is limited to one feature at a time and you need to move fast. But as you get larger and unlock the capacity to advance on multiple fronts, this tension boils up to the surface again. We realized we didn’t have a great framework for evaluating which of these disparate requests we should accept and started to ask harder questions: what future do we want to create? What’s the reason that we exist? What things do we believe that no one else does? I don’t know if most adults can answer these questions, so it isn’t surprising that companies can also find this a difficult exercise.

企业产品经理最重要的三项技能是什么？为什么？

What are the most important three skills for an enterprise product manager to have, and why?

与小型组织内的产品经理相比，领导企业需要更多的专业技能。最重要的是，企业产品经理需要：沟通、范围管理和商业头脑。

Navigating an enterprise requires a bit more skill specialization than a product manager inside of a smaller organization. Above all else, an enterprise product manager needs: communication, scope management, and business acumen.

沟通是任何产品经理的必备条件，但企业内部人员的数量使得这项技能变得更加重要。与工程主管喝 15 分钟咖啡聊聊与向高级管理层展示路线图同样重要，因为如果不了解情况，两者都可能阻碍您的进度。

Communication is a requirement for any product manager, but the number of people inside enterprises makes this skill all the more important. A 15-minute catch-up over coffee with the head of engineering is equally as important as presenting a roadmap to senior management because both can, if uninformed, stall your progress.

企业通常存在官僚主义和遗留系统，这使得它们很难遵循 Facebook 的格言“快速行动，打破常规”。熟练的企业产品经理可以通过将解决方案从范围广泛的解决方案简化为仍能解决问题并提供价值的最简单版本来应对这些复杂性。看待范围管理技能的另一种方式是，它有助于在组织内部“推销”想法。如果系统重写因为相对于成本而言效益较低而不受欢迎，那么产品经理可以在数据支持下设计一个较小规模的步骤改进，这有助于建立案例。优秀的产品经理是快速获胜和确保动力的大师。

Enterprises often come with bureaucracy and legacy systems which can make it difficult to follow Facebook’s adage to “move fast and break things.” Skilled enterprise product managers can navigate these complexities by boiling a solution down from one massive in scope to the simplest version that still solves the problem and delivers value. Another way to view this scope management skill is that it helps to “sell” an idea inside the organization. If the system rewrite is unpopular because of a perception of low benefits relative to costs, a product manager can engineer a smaller-scale step improvement, backed by data, that helps to build the case. Good product managers are masters in quick wins and ensuring momentum.

当你面试潜在的产品经理时，你在寻找什么？

What are you looking for when you interview a prospective product manager?

超越通常的“设计、技术和商业”技能交叉点：对问题空间以及倾听和沟通的个人兴趣。

Beyond the usual “design, tech, and business” skills intersection: personal interest in the problem space and listening and communication.

当然不需要构建类似产品的经验，但需要对我们的产品解决的问题和我们服务的客户感兴趣。候选人是否对行业和我们的客户群进行了研究？他们对事情的发展有什么看法吗？更好的是，他们是否对我们为什么要做我们正在做的事情有很大的疑问？这种最初的兴趣火花是基本要求，因为坦率地说，它表明了你的关心。当您已经与一群充满热情、想要解决棘手问题的人一起工作时，您最不想做的就是与那些只将其视为提升经验的工作的人一起工作。如果您即将面试 PM 职位，但发现自己对公司的业务并不真正感兴趣，请花 15 分钟研究他们的产品、客户和竞争对手。如果你还是觉得无聊，那就继续吧。

Experience building a similar product is certainly not needed, but interest in the problems our product solves and the customers we serve is. Did the candidate do research on the industry and our customer base? Do they have opinions about where things are going? Better yet, do they have great questions about why we’re doing the things we’re doing? This initial spark of interest is the base requirement because, frankly, it shows you care. When you already work with a team of passionate people who want to solve tough problems, the last thing you want is to work with someone who just views this as a job to level up their experience. If you’re about to interview for a PM role and don’t find yourself genuinely interested in what the company does, take 15 minutes to research their product, customers, and competitors. If you’re still bored, move on. There are lots of great companies and products out there.

1优势、劣势、机遇、威胁：http://bit.ly/2EilG3p。

1 Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats: http://bit.ly/2EilG3p.

第 8 章产品经理

Chapter 8. The Product Managers

进入企业软件产品管理领域可能与消费软件领域的职业道路有所不同。同样，你如何看待建立和管理产品经理团队会在许多值得注意的方面体现出企业的倾向。

Making your way into product management in enterprise software might look different than career paths in consumer software. Similarly, how you think about building and managing a team of product managers takes an enterprise slant in a number of noteworthy ways.

我们在这里撰写了大量关于产品经理如何最有效地与其他业务职能部门（如开发、设计、营销、运营、销售和领导力）合作的文章。所以现在，也许是时候将我们的注意力短暂地转向内部，对产品管理团队本身进行一些自我审视。

We’ve written extensively here about how product managers can work most effectively with other business functions like development, design, marketing, operations, sales, and leadership. So now, maybe it’s time to turn our attention ever so briefly inward for a bit of navel-gazing about the product management team itself.

在撰写本书的目标中，我们不仅希望帮助指导有抱负的产品经理为这一角色做好准备，而且还为经验丰富的产品经理提供有关如何发展、扩展和改进团队的建议。本章正是致力于实现这一目标。

Among our goals in writing this book, we wanted to not only help guide aspiring product managers prepare for the role, but also advise experienced product managers on how to grow, scale, and improve their teams. This chapter aspires to do just that.

进入产品管理

Getting into Product Management

所以，您认为产品管理听起来很酷，并且想加入其中。好决定！这是我们关于您应该做什么的最佳建议。

So, you think product management sounds like a cool gig and you’d like to get into it. Good call! Here’s our best advice on what you should do.

产品管理几乎不应该是你在技术领域的第一份或唯一一份工作。我们强烈建议不要将其作为进入科技领域的第一步。产品管理作为一个多面手角色，从其从业者可以从其他学科获得的丰富经验中获益匪浅。无论这种经验是在制作令人信服的客户叙述、理解业务挑战、构建软件还是其他方面的经验，拥有可转移技能的产品经理候选人在第一天就能比没有这些技能的候选人提供更多的价值。高效的销售人员、精明的营销人员、出色的工程师等等都可以成为一流的产品经理，根据我们的经验，很难说任何一个群体比另一个群体更好。

Product management should almost never be your first or only job in technology. We strongly advise against aiming for it as a first step into tech. Product management, as a generalist role, benefits enormously from the depth of experience its practitioners can bring to bear from other disciplines. Whether that experience is in crafting compelling customer narratives, empathizing with business challenges, building software, or something else, possessing transferable skills positions a product manager candidate to provide substantially more value on day one than a candidate without them. Effective salespeople, savvy marketers, brilliant engineers, and many more can all become first-class product managers, and in our experience, it’s very difficult to say that any one group is any better than another.

如果您是技术新手，并且您认为产品管理是您的目标，那么实现这一目标的一个好策略是首先花一些时间在另一个相邻的职能部门中学习诀窍。如果您有技术倾向，开发人员或运营角色，甚至销售工程或咨询工作都是很好的机会；如果您不是，也总是需要优秀的营销和销售人才。正如我们在本书前面所讨论的，作为一名成功的产品经理，你不需要具备“技术”，尽管通常需要一定程度的技术熟练程度。花一些时间学习，失败，然后再学习更多（别担心：我们都经历过！），例如产品营销或售前。你对你的市场、其中的公司、客户和用户问题了解得越多，当然，

If you’re new to tech, and you’re thinking that product management is your goal, a good strategy to get there would be to spend some time in another, adjacent function learning the ropes first. If you’re technically inclined, developer or operations roles, or even sales engineering or consulting gigs are great opportunities; if you’re not, great marketing and sales talent is always in demand, too. As we’ve discussed earlier in the book, you don’t need to be “technical” to be successful as a product manager, though a certain level of facility with the technology is usually warranted. Spend some time learning, and failing, and then learning some more (don’t worry: we’ve all been there!) in, for instance, product marketing or in pre-sales. The more you learn about your market, the companies within it, customer and user problems, and, of course, the product in question, the more valuable you’ll become, both to your current company and to others in the same segment.

除此之外，标准问题的职业建议也适用：向你自己和你的经理明确你的职业目标，公开讨论它们，当你觉得你的学习曲线开始趋于平稳时——至少在入职几年后——考虑进行转换。

Beyond that, the standard-issue career advice applies: be clear with yourself and your manager about your career goals, openly discuss them, and when you feel like your learning curve is beginning to level off—at least a few years into the role—consider making a switch.

企业产品经理如何度过一天？

How Do Enterprise Product Managers Spend Their Day?

这是各种产品经理都害怕的问题之一，因为没有真正好的答案。产品管理的本质通常意味着每天都是不同的。当然，还有站立会议和其他重复发生的事情，但我们认为，建议大多数企业产品经理应该每两周完成一份清单，而不是构建“生活中的一天”，可能会更具启发性。

This is one of those questions that product managers of all stripes sort of dread, because there is no really good answer. The nature of product management usually means that every day is different. Of course, there are standing meetings and other recurring things, but instead of structuring a “day in the life,” we thought it might be more illuminative to suggest a list of things that most enterprise product managers should aim to accomplish every two weeks.

  • 掌握发展状况

    • 每周回顾一下您的开发团队正在做什么。确保队列中的所有故事都具有正确的验收标准，并且您的下一个即将到来的冲刺已计划好。至少每隔几天在不间断的时间与该团队的人员联系一次。

    • 至少每两周与您的开发经理举行一次常务会议。这可以是快速的一对一，也可以根据需要进行更深入的讨论，但要确保您讨论的是未解决的问题、当前的冲刺以及下一个冲刺的规划注意事项。

  • Stay on top of development status

    • Review what your development team is working on every week. Ensure that all stories in the queue have the right acceptance criteria and that your next upcoming sprint is planned. Connect with the folks on this team at least once every few days at a nondisruptive time.

    • At least once every two weeks, have a standing meeting with your development manager. This can be a quick one-on-one or more in-depth as necessary, but make sure you’re talking through outstanding issues, the current sprint, and planning considerations for the next one.

  • 获取销售人员的意见

    • 始终保持与销售团队的渠道畅通——如果您没有收到即时/Slack 消息、电子邮件、或者卖家定期打来电话，您可能没有足够的时间（或者更糟糕的是，他们还没有发现您有用）。每隔几天就找一个卖家，非正式地看看情况如何。询问他们看到了什么以及他们在和谁说话。

    • 参加与您的产品相关的销售团队的会议。您不需要全程在场，远程加入也可以，但展示旗帜并让自己有空也很重要。

  • Get input from Sales

    • Always keep channels with your sales team open—if you’re not getting instant/Slack messages, emails, or calls from sellers on a regular basis, you might not be available enough (or, worse, they don’t find you useful yet). Pick on a seller every few days and just informally see what’s up. Ask what they’re seeing and to whom they’re talking.

    • Join meetings with the sales teams relevant to your product. You don’t need to be there for the entire thing, and joining remotely is fine, but showing the flag and making yourself available is important.

  • 收集客户反馈

    • 正如我们在第 6 章中讨论的，有时说起来容易做起来难。您当然不需要每两周拜访一次客户（不过如果您这样做，那就太好了！）。但您可以查看客户支持部门提出的问题，并在有时间的情况下提供帮助。如果客户的成功是与客户通电话，那么他们通常也会欢迎产品管理人员的参与。您可以观察正在进行的实施吗？服务团队是否正在与您可以拜访的客户一起开展项目？

    • 您可能无法每两周获取一次产品使用数据（不过，如果您这样做了，那就太好了！）。但如果可以的话，一定要留出时间来回顾这一点。

    • 如果它与您相关（而且可能是），请查看与行业相关的社交媒体。客户或潜在客户是否提及您的产品？一个竞争对手？

  • Gather customer feedback

    • As we discussed in Chapter 6, this is sometimes more easily said than done. You certainly don’t need to make a customer visit every two weeks (though if you do, that’s great!). But you can check on questions coming into customer support and lend a hand if you have time. If customer success is having any calls with customers, they will often welcome product management participation, too. Is there an implementation underway that you can observe? Is the services team working on a project with a customer you can drop in on?

    • You might not be able to get product usage data every two weeks (though again, if you do, kudos!). But if you can, definitely set aside time to review this.

    • If it’s relevant for you (and it probably is), check in on industry-relevant social media. Are customers, or potential ones, mentioning your product? A competitor?

  • 与营销同步

    • 我们在第四章中大篇幅讨论了与营销合作的重要性。嗯，我们是认真的。作为产品经理，您应该最感兴趣的是营销与哪些类型的潜在客户以及通过哪些渠道建立联系；谁出席您的活动，以及他们担任什么业务角色；他们认为哪些信息能够引起共鸣，哪些信息不能引起共鸣？

    • 确保你们在内容和附属品生成方面保持一致。除非两个团队都明确角色和职责，否则这可能会变成真正的混乱。确保营销人员不会等待产品管理人员处理任何您不知道的突出问题，并查看即将发布的内容日历。

    • 也许不太频繁——更像是每个季度一次——从战术层面的细节中退一步，根据营销同事对市场的看法，询问他们如何看待你的客户。和PM有区别吗？如果是这样，请仔细询问。

  • Synchronize with marketing

    • We make a big fuss in Chapter 4 about the importance of working with marketing. Well, we mean it. As a product manager, you should be most interested in what types of prospects marketing is connecting with, and via which channels; who is showing up to your events, and what business roles do they hold; what messaging do they see is resonating, and what is not?

    • Make sure you are aligned regarding content and collateral generation. This can turn into a real mess unless both groups are clear on roles and responsibilities. Ensure that marketing isn’t waiting on product management for anything outstanding you don’t know about, and review the upcoming content calendar.

    • Perhaps less often—more like once each quarter—stand back from tactical-level detail and ask your marketing colleagues about how they see your customer, based on their own view of the market. Does it differ from PM’s? If so, interrogate this closely.

  • 预留时间学习行业知识。这可能意味着要赶上市场、分析师研究、竞争对手营销等的广泛趋势。外面的东西可能远远多于你有时间消耗的东西。不要试图喝掉整个消防水带——要有选择性。

  • Reserve time for industry knowledge. This might mean catching up on broad trends in your market, analyst research, competitor marketing, and so forth. There is probably far more out there than you have time to consume. Don’t try to drink the whole firehose—be selective.

  • 与产品团队合作。您很可能与产品经理团队合作，无论是在一个大型软件解决方案上还是在具有许多模块的平台上。无论是什么，您的整个直接团队应该每周至少开会一次。毫无疑问，您在计划、协调和共享信息方面会有很多工作要做，但始终让这些会议集中在预先安排的议程上。准时结束。每个人都很忙。

  • Work with the Product team. Chances are good that you work with a team of product managers, whether on one large software solution or a platform with many modules. Whatever it is, your entire immediate team should meet together at least once each week. You will doubtless have much to go over in terms of planning, coordination, and sharing information, but always keep these meetings focused on a prearranged agenda. End on time. Everyone is busy.

  • 思考和计划。看，我们的工作通常就像气体一样：它会膨胀以填充任何可用的体积。如果你没有刻意地抽出时间去思考，无论是安静地、独自思考还是与同事进行头脑风暴（无论什么对你有用），这项关键的认知工作往往是第一个被搁置的事情。别让。安排时间深入思考你的产品、你的客户以及你正在解决的问题。考虑一下您想要解决哪些中长期问题以及如何解决它们。这是您的行业、组织和产品知识必须综合在一起的地方。不要着急，但也不要跳过它。

  • Think and plan. Look, our work often acts like a gas: it expands to fill any available volume. If you don’t purposefully block out time to think, either quietly and alone or in brainstorming with colleagues (whatever works for you), this critical cognitive work is often the first thing to fall off the plate. Don’t let it. Schedule time for deep thinking about your product, your customers, and the problems you are solving. Think about what medium- and long-term problems you want to solve and how you could solve them. This is where the synthesis of your industry, organizational, and product knowledge must come together. Don’t rush it, but do not skip it.

如何知道你是否还在成长

How to Know Whether You’re Still Growing

一个好的经验法则——这适用于几乎任何职位的人，而不仅仅是产品经理——就是关注你是否仍在自己的角色中成长。如果你不这样做，也许是时候采取行动了。这就是我们的意思。

One good rule of thumb—and this applies to people in almost any role, not just product managers—is to pay attention to whether you’re still growing within your role. If you’re not, it might be time to make a move. Here’s what we mean.

正如任何运动员都会告诉你的那样，成长只能通过奋斗和努力来实现。当你在某件事上变得更强、更快、更好时，你会发现自己不断面临挑战。您必须不断学习和吸收新的知识体系，以新的不同方式应用它们，并锻炼一开始可能很弱的技能。有时，这意味着您失败或需要寻求帮助。（顺便说一句，这样做是可以的。）随着你在这个角色中的成熟，它会变得更容易，你能够接受更大、更复杂的挑战。

As any athlete can tell you, growth comes only through struggle and exerting yourself. When you’re getting stronger, faster, and better at something, you find yourself constantly challenged. You’re constantly having to learn and absorb new bodies of knowledge, apply them in new and different ways, and exercise skills that might start out weak. Sometimes, this will mean that you fail or need to ask for help. (It’s okay to do that, by the way.) As you mature in the role, it becomes easier, and you’re able to take on bigger, more complex challenges.

但我们都有过学习曲线趋于平稳的工作。当这种情况发生时，你就不再感到有挑战了。你发现自己没有灵感并开始变得无聊。这是一个艰难的处境。如果您正处于职业生涯中期，并且职业进步对您很重要，那么您需要找到一条新的前进道路。这可能意味着从您之前所做的任何事情转向产品管理本身，或者如果您已经在那里，这可能意味着承担新产品或一系列职责。在某些情况下，这可能意味着搬到一家新公司。（顺便说一句，研究一再表明，到目前为止，换工作也是增加薪酬的最佳方式。）

But we’ve all had jobs where the learning curve just sort of levels out. When that happens, you’re no longer feeling that challenged. You find yourself uninspired and begin to become bored. This is a tough place to be in. If you’re mid-career, and professional progress is important to you, you need to find a new path forward. This might mean moving into product management itself from whatever you did before, or if you’re already there, it might mean taking on a new product or set of responsibilities. In some cases, it might mean moving to a new company. (By the way, research shows over and over that switching jobs is also, by far, the best way to increase your compensation.)

另一方面，请记住，挫折，甚至偶尔产生的无聊也是任何长期、困难和复杂项目的自然副产品。你当然不想用它们作为中途放弃某些事情的借口。我们所有人都经历过不会消亡的多步骤工作项目。相信我们，坚持到底。在项目本身进入书中很长一段时间后，它会继续教你一些东西，而且你不会因为过早退出而毁掉任何桥梁。

On the other hand, keep in mind that frustration and occasionally even resulting boredom are also natural byproducts of any long, difficult, and complicated project. You certainly don’t want to use them as an excuse for quitting something mid-stream. All of us have gone through the multistep work project that just wouldn’t die. Trust us, see it through. It will continue teaching you stuff long after the project itself is in the books, and you won’t burn any bridges by tapping out early.

对于管理者：建立你的团队

For Managers: Building Your Team

如果您负责领导自己的产品管理团队，那么有几个问题是（或应该）始终是首要考虑的问题。以下是我们听到的一些最重要的声音。

If you are in the position of leading your own product management team, there are a couple of questions that are (or should) constantly be top of mind. Here are some of the biggest ones we hear.

发现和培养新人才是任何优秀管理者的首要任务。在产品管理中，了解在新候选人中寻找什么是至关重要的。尽管许多不同背景的人都可以成功担任此职位（您最了解您的公司背景），但我们始终发现成功的新产品经理具有以下几个共同特征：

Spotting and nurturing new talent is a priority for any good manager. In product management, knowing what to look for in new candidates can be essential. Although many different backgrounds can be successful in this role (you know your company context best), we’ve consistently found a couple of attributes to be shared among successful new product managers:

  • 他们已经拥有几年的技术经验；最好是同行业的；甚至更优选地具有相同的产品或产品组。正如我们在上一节中所说，工程、营销和销售等内部职能是您必须选择的最丰富的人才发展库。（你们的两位作者都是从此类职能部门进入产品管理领域的。）

  • They come from a few years of experience in technology already; preferably in the same industry; and even more preferably with the same product or product group. As we said in the previous section, internal functions like engineering, marketing, and sales are some of the richest pools of talent development you have to pick from. (Both of your authors came into product management from functions like these.)

  • 他们对产品表现出明显的热情，并表现出超越其正式工作职责来了解更多信息的意愿。想想变得非常擅长使用产品的营销人员，或者参与销售周期的工程师，或者充当自己的销售工程师的卖家。这些人中的每个人都将带来一套跨职能的技能和观点来构建该产品的未来。

  • They are demonstrably passionate about the product and have shown a willingness to go above and beyond their formal job responsibilities to learn more about it. Think about the marketer who becomes deeply adept at using the product, or the engineer who becomes involved in sales cycles, or the seller who acts as their own sales engineer. Each of these people will bring with them a cross-functional set of skills and perspectives into building the future of that product.

  • 他们了解更广泛的行业格局，包括您公司的销售对象和您所在领域的软件供应商。这不仅仅是了解您的竞争对手是谁（尽管充分了解竞争对手非常方便）——谁是您的解决方案的相邻供应商？您的总潜在市场 (TAM) 是多少？他们是否深入思考过该产品面临的更广泛的市场挑战？

  • They understand the broader industry landscape, both that which your company sells into and that for software vendors in your space. This isn’t just knowing who your competitors are (though knowing the competition well is very handy)—who are adjacent vendors to your solution? What is your Total Addressable Market (TAM)? Have they thought deeply about the broader market challenge for the product?

  • 他们具有出色的沟通能力。一名优秀的产品经理需要能够以多种形式（书面、口头、非语言）与不同受众进行非常有效的沟通。他们需要能够轻松地与工程师、销售人员、高管和客户等交谈。

  • They have excellent communication skills. A good product manager needs to be able to communicate very effectively, in multiple formats (written, spoken, nonverbal) to different audiences. They need to be able to talk with ease with engineers, salespeople, executives, and customers, among others.

  • 他们——请原谅这个表达方式——在乎。没有什么可以真正取代工作的内在动力，无论你想称之为激情、内心的火焰还是其他什么。在产品管理中，就像在生活中一样，没有什么可以替代“不在乎”。这个人需要做好打球的准备。如果他们这样做了，那就是你想要加入你的团队的人。

  • They—excuse the expression—give a shit. There is just nothing that can really replace internal motivation for the job, whether you want to call it passion, fire in the belly, or something else. In product management, as in life, there is just no substitute for giving a shit. This person needs to show up ready to play ball. If they do, that’s a person you want on your team.

当然，扩大产品管理团队需要雇用合适的候选人，但它还涉及复杂的组织决策，包括谁负责什么、谁与谁合作/向谁报告以及产品经理如何协调。许多组织坚持让一名产品经理直接负责一种产品，这通常很有效。有时，对于可能包含大量离散产品的企业软件即服务 (SaaS) 平台，将多个产品与单个 PM 协调可能是有意义的。

Scaling up your product management team involves hiring the right candidates, of course, but it also involves complex organizational decisions about who covers what, who works with/reports to whom, and how product managers are aligned. Many organizations stick with a straightforward alignment of one product manager to one product, and that often works. Sometimes, as with enterprise Software as a Service (SaaS) platforms that might include numerous discrete products, it might make sense to align more than one product to a single PM.

在其他情况下，如果一个极其复杂的产品对于一名产品经理来说太过分了，那么在向一名组经理报告的多名合作产品经理之间划分职责需要明确的职责划分。（问问本就知道了！）这会深入到具体情况的判断，对于像这样的书来说很难提供广泛的指导；但一般来说，这里需要仔细考虑的一些问题是产品知识如何从一个人转移到另一个人；谁与该产品相关的开发团队合作、如何合作以及使用什么带宽；以及相关产品在其成熟度曲线上的位置。

In other cases, in which one extremely complex product is far too much for just one product manager, dividing up responsibilities between multiple cooperating product managers who report up to one group manager involves clear delineations of responsibilities. (Just ask Ben!) This gets deep into context-specific judgments that are difficult for a book like this one to give broad guidance about; but generally, some of the issues to be carefully considered here are how product knowledge is transferred from one person to the next; who works with development teams relevant to that product, how, and with what bandwidth; and where the product in question is on its maturity curve.

将产品经理作为人来管理

Managing Product Managers as People

当然，产品经理也是人，有自己独特的情感、野心、不安全感等等。任何人、任何角色都可能难以管理。然而，根据我们的经验，优秀的产品经理是企业技术中最具内在动力的人之一，因此在某些方面，在其他条件相同的情况下，也是最容易管理的人才群体。对于几乎没有经验的产品经理来说，微观管理通常是不必要的。经验丰富的产品经理将拥有与企业中不同团队合作的丰富经验，并且最需要有人来扫清道路并充当力量倍增器。即使是经验丰富的产品经理（尤其是新产品经理）也需要您的帮助来在公司其他地方找到合适的人员，以帮助他正在从事的项目或功能顺利进行，并且作为经理，

Of course, product managers are people, with their own unique emotions, ambitions, insecurities, and more. Anyone, in any role, can be difficult to manage. However, in our experience, good product managers are among the most intrinsically motivated people in enterprise technology, and therefore in some ways the easiest group of talent to manage, all other things being equal. With all but the very least experienced product managers, micromanagement will typically not be necessary. A more seasoned product manager will have had many experiences working with diverse teams in the enterprise, and will mostly be in need of someone to clear a path and act as a force multiplier. Even an experienced product manager (but especially a newer one) will need your help to find the right individuals elsewhere in your company to help grease the skids for a project or feature he is working on, and, as a manager, you should seek to cultivate relationships with managers of other teams so that you can make those connections for your product managers when needed.

优秀的产品经理在从事能够激发他们热情的项目时往往会感到最快乐。在企业软件组织中，让产品经理始终与他们关心的项目保持一致可能很困难或不可能。太多的团队中发生了太多的事情，以至于每个人都无法一直做自己喜欢的事情。（正如布莱尔喜欢说的，你所拥有的最好的工作，你只会在大约 70% 的时间里喜欢。）与你的团队成员合作，了解产品或业务的哪些领域点燃了他们各自的热情，并做如果产品经理参与到她喜欢的事情中，不要害怕在一个项目上安排多个产品经理。一位敬业的产品经理会加倍周围人的努力。还，典型的企业产品经理总是被拉向一千个方向，双重或三重覆盖会有所帮助。因为产品管理从本质上来说就是一个协作角色，所以最好的产品经理会喜欢有同事在他们需要离开时可以替他们顶替。

Good product managers tend to be happiest when working on projects that bring out their passion. In an enterprise software organization, it can be difficult or impossible to always align your product managers with the projects that they care about. There is simply too much going on across too many teams for everyone to be doing what they love all the time. (As Blair likes to say, the best job you’ll ever have, you’ll only love about 70% of the time.) Work with your team members to understand what areas of the product or business light their respective fires, and do not be afraid to pair up multiple product managers on a single project if it gets a product manager involved with something she loves. An engaged product manager multiplies the efforts of those around her. Also, with the typical enterprise product manager being pulled in a thousand directions at all times, having double or triple coverage can help. Because product management is by its very definition a collaborative role, the best product managers will appreciate having colleagues who can cover for them if they need to step away.

产品管理迎合那些希望看到别人成功、具有高度分析能力的人。当然，并不是每个优秀的产品经理都是这样，但很多都是。因为作为产品经理，我们几乎处于不断评估客户问题、产品设计等的状态，所以我们很容易将注意力集中在自己身上，并反省我们自己是否是一个值得保留的功能（借用本书其他地方的一句话）。有一天，我们可能会觉得自己是出色的产品经理，并且确切地知道如何成为有效的领导者，而第二天我们就会想知道我们是如何仍然受雇的。我们经常提到“产品管理的正弦波”，它会引起许多优秀产品经理所经历的成功和成就感与沮丧和困惑感之间的频繁振荡。

Product management caters to highly analytical people who want to see others succeed. Of course, not every good product manager is that way, but many are. Because we, as product managers, are in a state of nearly constant assessment of customer problems, product design, and more, it is easy for us to shine the spotlight on ourselves and wonder introspectively whether we are, ourselves, a feature worth keeping around (to borrow a phrase from elsewhere in this book). One day we might feel like we are great product managers and know exactly how to be effective leaders, and the next we wonder how we are even still employed. We often refer to “the sine wave of product management,” evoking the frequent oscillation between feelings of success and accomplishment and feelings of discouragement and bewilderment that many good product managers experience. As with any employee, be sensitive to how the team around you is feeling at any given moment, and be aware that product management can be an especially fickle practice for even more senior individuals.

对于产品经理：下一步是什么？

For the Product Manager: What’s Next?

如果您跳到本节，我们可能会告诉您您已经知道的事情：产品经理通常在各种相邻职能中需求量很大，尤其是行政领导。随着许多软件公司朝着“产品第一”的方向发展（特别是在 SaaS 领域，我们可能会在未来的博客文章中详细说明原因），产品管理正日益成为该领域最引人注目的角色之一。“产品”选择并加倍强化密集的跨职能运营经验，这些经验可以培养许多其他角色难以获得的技能。

If you skipped to this section, we’re probably going to tell you what you already know: product managers are generally in high demand in a variety of adjacent functions, most notably executive leadership. As many software companies evolve toward a “product-first” orientation (particularly in SaaS, for reasons we might elaborate on in a future blog post), product management is increasingly becoming one of the most high-visibility roles in the field. “Product” selects for, and then doubles down on, intensively cross-functional operational experience that develops many skills that are difficult to obtain in other roles.

也就是说，许多人要么没有准备好，要么只是没有兴趣晋升到行政领导层。这就是为什么我们认识的许多转型的产品经理选择追求更专业的道路。一些产品经理利用他们的技术好奇心并担任开发角色。前产品经理往往会成为出色的销售工程师，他们可以运用自己开发的面向客户的技能以及战略、业务视角和实际的技术兴趣。营销领导力是另一种流行的途径，它建立在产品经理的沟通优势之上，将产品的商业价值转化为客户。（正如我们之前所说，做好这件事的技能是独一无二的，而且确实非常罕见。）

That said, many people either aren’t ready for or just aren’t interested in climbing the ladder into executive leadership. That’s why many product managers we know who transitioned on chose to pursue more specialized paths. Some product managers capitalize on their technical curiosity and go into development roles. Ex-product managers tend to make terrific sales engineers, where they can put to use the customer-facing skills they’ve developed alongside a strategic, business perspective paired with down-in-the-weeds technical interest. Marketing leadership is another popular path which builds on product managers’ strengths in communication to translate product business value to customers. (As we’ve said earlier, the skills to do this well are inimitable and really quite rare.)

产品管理本身的领导力是另一种选择。关于产品管理领导角色需要记住的一件事是它们与一线产品经理的工作有多么不同。产品管理领导更多的是关于管理人员和解决方案级别的能力和价值。它涉及不同产品领域（而不是产品本身）在 10,000 英尺高度上的显着更高的优先级，并且经常需要更多地说“不”。这对某些人来说可能很困难，但它也带来了巨大的回报。具有管理成功企业产品记录的高级产品领导者供不应求，但需求量很大，这种情况似乎不太可能很快改变。

Leadership within product management itself is yet another option. One thing to keep in mind about product management leadership roles is how different they are from the front-line product manager gig. Product management leadership is much more about managing humans and solution-level capabilities and value. It involves significantly more prioritization at the 10,000-foot level across different product areas (instead of products themselves) and frequently entails much more saying “no.” This can be difficult for some people, but it also brings with it significant rewards. Senior product leaders with demonstrated track records of managing successful enterprise products are in short supply and high demand, a situation that seems unlikely to change very soon.

最后的想法

Last Thoughts

我们知道，市场上不乏通用的、高级的产品管理建议，因此到目前为止，我们一直在努力使我们的建议尽可能发挥作用。不过，为了让大家了解一下哲学，请记住，产品经理的角色通常是故意设置的，以便快速且频繁地失败。我们的角色是运营角色，如果做得正确，从业者通常会遇到他们尚未完全理解的技术、财务、战略或其他问题。这可能非常令人沮丧，而且产品管理依赖于与其他团队的协作才能最终取得成功，这一事实使情况变得更加复杂。

We’re aware that there is no shortage of generalized, high-level product management advice out there, so we’ve tried to keep ours as functional as possible up until now. To get all philosophical for just a second, though, just remember that the product manager role is often set up, deliberately, to fail fast and often. Ours is an operational role in which, if you’re doing it right, practitioners will routinely run into technical, financial, strategic, or other issues that they don’t yet completely understand. This can be very frustrating, and is compounded by the fact that product management relies on the collaboration with other teams to ultimately be successful.

如果您感到头晕，请深呼吸并放松。这意味着您可能处于正确的成长位置。确保你保持“温和的心态”，一次只解决一个问题，并集中注意力。喝很多水。拉紧。你会做得很好。

If you feel in over your head, take a deep breath and relax. That means you’re probably in the right place to grow. Make sure you maintain a “soft mind,” take issues one at a time, and focus. Drink lots of water. Stretch. You’re going to do fine.

概括

Summary

如果您正在考虑进入产品管理，请确保您拥有科技行业内的相关技能，或者更好的是，与您想要为其构建产品的行业或同一家公司处于同一行业。产品管理不应该是软件行业的第一份工作——这是一个高度跨职能的角色，它可以从使用先前的领域经验中受益匪浅。产品管理领导者应该始终寻找有前途的新人才。最好的候选人表现出热情、对细节的关注、领域专业知识以及持续自我激励的能力。如果您现在担任产品角色，请考虑一下您希望它带您去往何处，并确保您正在设计的工作能够实现这些目标。

If you’re looking into getting into product management, make sure you have adjacent skills from within the tech industry—or even better, in the same industry as the one you want to build products for, or at the same firm. Product management should not be a first gig in the software industry—this is a highly cross-functional role, which benefits greatly from using prior domain experience. Product management leaders should always be on the lookout for promising new talent. The best candidates show passion, attention to detail, domain expertise, and an ability to consistently self-motivate. If you’re in a product role today, think about where you want it to take you, and be sure you’re designing your job to meet those goals.

第 9 章结论

Chapter 9. Conclusion

嗯，就是这样。这就是我们对企业产品管理的了解。有点。

Well, that’s it. That’s what we know about enterprise product management. Kinda.

正如我们一开始所说的，我们着手描述我们认为可以应用于大多数企业软件业务的理想原则。最重要的是，请不要灰心如果您的公司看起来与我们在这里描述的相去甚远！产品管理已经够困难的了，即使没有几位书籍作者告诉你你做的都是错的。这些都是理想，即使对于许多最好的产品团队来说，它们也与现实相去甚远，所以无论你做什么，都不要给你的角色增加完美主义的负担。您仍然可以做一些伟大的事情来取悦和增强客户的能力。您仍然可以成为一名出色的企业软件产品经理。通过缓慢、仔细地实施我们在此描述的一些内容，您可以在很大程度上帮助您的公司。企业软件中的变化通常发生得很慢，我们的目标是为您提供一些起点。

As we said at the very beginning, we set out to describe what we believe are the ideal principles that could be applied to most enterprise software businesses. Above all else, please don’t become discouraged if your company seems very far from what we’ve described here! Product management is difficult enough without a couple of book authors telling you that you’re doing it all wrong. These are ideals, and they’re far from reality even for many of the best product teams, so whatever you do, don’t add the burden of perfectionism to your role. You can still do great things to delight and empower your customers. You can still become a great product manager for enterprise software. And you can help your company in big ways by slowly, carefully implementing some of what we’ve described here. Change often happens slowly in enterprise software, and our goal here was to give you a few places to begin.

写这本书最困难的部分之一就是试图将我们各自经验的所有庞大分支提炼成组织良好、易于使用的部分，我们希望您会发现这些部分很容易使用。在进行精简的过程中，我们遗漏了很多不适合任何地方的东西。我们还遇到了更多的企业产品经理，我们希望在个人资料中分享他们的故事和经验，就像您在此处阅读的那样。因此，出版后，我们计划在本书的网站BuildingForBusiness.com上发布更多内容作为一次性博客文章。我们希望您能检查一下，看看我们还想出了什么。

One of the most difficult parts about writing this book was trying to distill all the sprawling branches of our respective experiences into well-organized, consumable sections that we hoped you would find easily usable. In doing that streamlining, we left out a lot of stuff that just didn’t fit anywhere very cleanly. We also ran into even more enterprise product managers whose stories and experiences we wanted to share in profiles like the ones you’ve read here. So following publication, we plan to post more content as one-off blog posts at the book’s website, BuildingForBusiness.com. We hope you’ll check that out to see what else we came up with.

当我们写这本书时，令我们双方都感到惊讶的是我们的一些经历之间的对比。成熟产品与不成熟产品；市场领导者与斗志旺盛的失败者；大公司与小公司；不同的组织和公司实践。产品管理的实践在企业软件行业的许多部分确实存在很大差异，这使得它现在成为一个非常令人兴奋的工作场所。规则仍在制定中；界限仍然极其模糊。因此，我们敏锐地意识到，很多人可能不同意我们在这里表达的所有关于产品管理的观点，但这没关系。正如我们在简介中所说，我们仍在了解哪些有效、哪些无效。当你觉得自己已经把所有事情都弄清楚时，要非常小心；机会是，

Something that surprised both of us while we wrote this book was the contrast between some of our experiences. Mature versus immature products; market leaders versus scrappy underdogs; big companies versus small ones; different organizational and company practices. The practice of product management truly does vary widely across many parts of the enterprise software industry, which makes it a really exciting place to work right now. The rules are still being written; the boundaries are still extremely fuzzy. Accordingly, we’re keenly aware that a lot of people might not agree with all of the views on product management that we’ve expressed here, and that’s fine. Like we said in the introduction, we’re still learning about what works and what doesn’t. Be very careful when you feel like you’ve got things all figured out; chances are, you’re closer to being left behind.

我们希望这本书能够从企业软件的角度对产品管理的新兴文献做出有意义的贡献，而我们认为这一点经常被忽视。我们希望它在某种程度上对您有所帮助，并且希望您能让我们知道我们的表现。

We wanted this book to make a meaningful contribution to the emerging literature on product management from the enterprise software perspective, which we feel is too often ignored. We hope it’s been helpful to you in some way and that you’ll let us know how we did.

现在您没有积压的工作需要优先处理吗？

Now don’t you have a backlog to go prioritize?

外面见，

See y’all out there,

布莱尔和本

Blair & Ben

@布莱尔里夫斯

@BlairReeves

@本杰明盖恩斯

@BenjaminGaines

关于作者

About the Authors

Blair Reeves是 SAS Software 的首席产品经理。他此前曾在 Demandware（现为 Salesforce Commerce Cloud）和 IBM 担任产品和营销职务。布莱尔是一位狂热的徒步旅行者，擅长创造性地写作和编码，并相信充满灵感的产品首先是在健身房中打造出来的。他在自己的博客BlairReeves.me上撰写有关企业软件、产品管理和广泛主题的文章，并且有一个恼人的 Twitter 习惯：@BlairReeves。他和他的妻子带着女儿和狗住在北卡罗来纳州的皮茨伯勒。 

Blair Reeves is a Principal Product Manager at SAS Software. He has previously held product and marketing roles at Demandware (now the Salesforce Commerce Cloud) and IBM. Blair is an avid hiker, writes and codes creatively, and believes inspired products are built first in the gym. He writes about enterprise software, product management, and wide-ranging topics at his blog, BlairReeves.me, and has an annoying Twitter habit at @BlairReeves. He and his wife live with their daughter and dogs in Pittsboro, North Carolina. 

Ben Gaines是 Adob​​e Analytics Cloud 的集团产品经理。在此职位上，他与 Adob​​e 客户密切合作，了解他们的需求并指导产品策略来解决他们最紧迫的问题。本是土生土长的波士顿人，移居盐湖城，他痴迷于打篮球，还喜欢烹饪、旅游以及与四个孩子一起玩耍。您可以通过 Twitter @benjamingaines 了解 Ben 的每一个醒着的想法。

Ben Gaines is a Group Product Manager for Adobe Analytics Cloud. In this role, he works closely with Adobe customers to understand their needs and guide the product strategy to address their most pressing problems. A native Bostonian transplanted to Salt Lake City, Ben plays basketball compulsively, and also enjoys cooking, tourism, and playing with his four kids. You can consume Ben’s every waking thought on Twitter at @benjamingaines.

版画

Colophon

《企业建筑产品》封面上的动物是图勒麋鹿。

The animal on the cover of Building Products for the Enterprise is the tule elk.

图勒麋鹿仅分布在美国加利福尼亚州，分布范围从中央山谷到海岸。当欧洲人抵达加利福尼亚时，据信约有 50 万只图勒麋鹿。在 19 世纪初的淘金热期间几乎濒临灭绝，目前野生种群数量约为 4,000 只。

The tule elk is found only in the U.S. state of California, ranging from the Central Valley out to the coast. There were believed to be around 500,000 tule elk when the Europeans arrived in California. Almost driven to extinction during the Gold Rush of the early 19th century, the wild population now numbers around 4,000.

它是最小的美洲麋鹿，雄性体重 450-550 磅（200-250 公斤），雌性体重 375-425 磅（170-193 公斤）。它们的体型介于较大的驯鹿和普通白尾鹿之间。成年公牛（超过 2 岁）的鹿角有 5-7 个角，在早春（即发情季节之后）脱落，并在夏季重新生长。

It is the smallest of the American elk, with males weighing 450–550 pounds (200–250 kilograms) and females 375–425 pounds (170–193 kilograms). They are about midway in size between the larger reindeer and the common white-tailed deer. Full-grown bulls (over 2 years old) have antlers with 5–7 points that shed in early spring (that is, after rutting season) and regrow over the summer.

这只麋鹿所吃的土勒植物是一种高大的草丛，生长在加利福尼亚海岸的沼泽和湖畔。该地区的土著人民用图勒制作睡垫、独木舟，甚至庇护所。

The tule plant on which this elk feeds is a tall, grassy brush that grows in the marshes and lakefronts of the California coast. The indigenous peoples of the area used tule to make sleeping mats, canoes, and even shelters.

奥莱利封面上的许多动物都濒临灭绝。所有这些对世界都很重要。要了解有关如何提供帮助的更多信息，请访问animals.oreilly.com。

Many of the animals on O’Reilly covers are endangered; all of them are important to the world. To learn more about how you can help, go to animals.oreilly.com.

封面插图由凯伦·蒙哥马利 (Karen Montgomery) 绘制，基于Meyers Kleines Lexicon的黑白版画。封面字体为 URW Typewriter 和 Guardian Sans。文本字体为 Scala Pro，标题字体为 Benton Sans。

The cover illustration is by Karen Montgomery, based on a black-and-white engraving from Meyers Kleines Lexicon. The cover fonts are URW Typewriter and Guardian Sans. The text font is Scala Pro, and the heading font is Benton Sans.
